I mean I don't mind paying but this was just too much for something that didn't feel like a legit service. 

But than again this is just me. Go on and experience it if you would like. But I think their overall review says it all
 
*You're better off with the small food shops. Those seem more authentic than this place  

Never Again!
author: Nelida H.

description: I would give it a 0 star if yelp let me. Absolutely the worst decision I've made coming here. It was our first day in SF and we went to chinatown to get dinner. There were ladies on the streets with flyers on every block trying to get people to go in so we went in. It felt like a mistake from the start, and it was. Food was overly oily, salty, and meat was cold. They gave us 4 pot stickers as complimentary dish. It tasted and looked like frozen dumplings. We ordered a dan dan Noodle and it was so salty we had to send it back. It was so salty it was bitter. We thought it was a mistake so they remade it for us and it was worse. We ordered 2 appetizers that came out to $28. Needless to say, I'm never coming back here!!
author: Anna H.

description:
I highly don't recommend this place only because it is a tourist trap. I would rather eat at Panda Express than this place! The shrimps smell pretty vulgar and taste pretty sour; Its as if it were the shrimps were frozen and thawed out in a toilet.

Please save yourself time and money and try other dim sum places like around Jackson street. Or go down to a mom and pop resturant because you will definitely have a better experience than here. I tried giving benefit of the doubt here.
author: Austin L.

description:
You probably came here because one of the pushy ladies on the street coralled you in. Well, be ready for a wait, because they are the only ones working. In three words: SLOW. OVERPRICED. RUDE.  My tip?  Go across the street. You'll have your food in front of you in less time than it takes this place to notice you exist.

Honestly, leave, now. When my cousin was visiting from out of town they forgot his Pina Colada and didn't bring us any drinks. When he mentioned it he just said nevermind just water would be nice.  She insisted it was done & ready and will bring it from downstairs.  We literally heard her go in the back, yell a bunch of things, then heard a blender going a minute later.  This restaurant is ran so badly it's almost on purpose.  That was 6 months ago.  Why am I writing this now? I was hungry, got coralled again, walked in and said "no not this place.... oh F it I'm hungry." Sat there 20 mins and walked out.  Nobody noticed.  It wasn't busy.  Across the street I got my food within 15 mins.

Go across the street.
author: Paul Z.

description: Like every other reviewer, we apparently had the "I'm a sucker tourist" look about us as we wondered around China Town. We flew in early and should have ate before wondering about. So, starving, we were looking for anything to eat. We got haggled in to this place off the street. Seriously, this lady walked us from the street corner all the way into the restaurant itself, sat us at a table and yelled into the back, then dashed back outside. First red flag was the completely empty restaurant. We ordered some Oolong and as we chewed our tea we contemplated a way out of the sketch situation we were in. Ultimately we decided to roll the dice and just try it. The shrimp dumplings tasted like glue. Do not order them! The walnut shrimp wasn't bad. The chow mein was good. The chicken fried rice was plain and clearly made with frozen veggies. The potstickers were good. It was FREEZING in the restaurant. Each entree came separately to our table half an hour apart. Two of the three plates at our table were dirty. We personally had to exchange them for others around us. Again, the place was empty, so we got to play a fun game of 'find a clean plate'. The bathrooms downstairs reminded us of the lodge in the Goonies... we were waiting to hear Sloth pulling his chains from the wall or something. Sometimes, a place is a dive, but the food is good enough that you can overlook the sticky tables and stained carpets. Sadly, this was not the case. All around, this place is bad news! I'm so surprised none of us got sick. We've got a great story out of the adventure though.
author: Danielle P.

description:
This night was a family Christmas night.  We have decided to go to SF and spend it there.  At the end of our grand tour, we walked around China town for quite a bit.  Parking as you know was horrendous.  My mother I law wanted for us to look for a good restaurant to eat.  There were people (I assumed) from this restaurant handing out advertisement and discount for that day and kept insisting to try their restaurant.  Well, this was a bad choice.  We should have not rush and took time tin look for a better place to eat.  There were plenty of people when we got there around 6:35 pm I believe and got sitted.  Well that's just the only time that we were punctually catered.  Next 1/2 hour, our waitress came back and took our orders, we ordered initially to get some sizzling rice and then our main dish to come after ..... After a few and "hour" or so... We got boys and pieces of our entrees (Mongolian beef, walnut shrimp) before we got our fried rice and our sizzling rice.  It was back wards.   The food was great and IT Tate's good but the service was Awefull.  Not only that our waitress hardly understood us but was hardly around . We got out and finished our meal a little after 845pm.  You can imagine the wait we have over 3 hour long.  

I don't think the staff was adequate for the volume of customers they have for that night.  This place is big and I counted 3 floors.  I don't know I gave this place a two star for the "lack" of good service.
author: Diomedes L.

description:
Don't go here! Here's why: Food is not good, restrooms are dirty (floor was wet and dirty), quality of food is not worth the price, and I found bits and pieces of I-don't-know-what in my Chinese broccoli. We ordered Chinese broccoli, sesame chicken and two beers - total was 49.80 because they include the tip in the check for a party of two.

I wish I had checked Yelp before spontaneously going in.
author: Jesse N.

description: The generals chicken was great! Good flavor and not dry as many places are. Spring rolls were nice and crunchy.  Dumplings amd wontons were good as well. To top it off was the green tea ice cream. It was very clean.  Food was hot when we got it . No complaints. I'm glad I read reviews so I knew about the tip.
author: Amy E.

description: The food was ok. It's Chinatown, can't expect amazing but their take on Chinese food was interesting to say the least. Tofu and vegetables in egg drop soup wasn't my favorite. The Seasame chicken tasted like BBQ sauce. Oh and you have to pay for your water. Finally, the bathroom was not in good shape. The service was better than the food I thought. They gave us green tea ice cream at the end which wasn't bad. If we come back to San Fran, we won't come back to this place.
author: Amanda G.

description:
First off to start off we got here ordered our food took forever to get there, then FINALLY got our food, some plates of food were cold, food had no taste, 3$ for nasty tea? No thanks ! 
If I could give this place no star I would ! 
Horrible place to eat, waiter never checked on us, flagged her down and she said one minute and never came back didn't ask us if we needed refills or anything. Very disappointed didn't see our waiter until we got our bill. They didn't even apologize for their horrible service. 

Will never return there. Lady stopped us at the street and since we were hungry we ate the nasty food. 
Big thumbs down
author: Aseneth P.

description:
If I can this place NO star I would! Not only they were over priced they total the tax and automatically tip themselves.. They even round off the tip as well! Bad business and I hope it gets shut down. Also they hid their Resturant score which was 74 - needs improvement! Never again. I wished I Yelped it before sitting down but the hubs was hungry! I'm so pissed! 

STAY AWAY FROM THIS HORRIBLE PLACE!
author: Vany P.

description:
I would LOVE to give them zero stars. 
The sh*ttiest place EVER. Food tastes like complete SH*T. They add $9.90 for tip. Like why? The food was terrible... repeat after me.. TER RI BLE. 

I ordered a plate of beef and let me tell you this.. it tasted NOTHING like beef. NOTHINGGGGGG. 

I cannot express how bad this place is. The worst f*cking place ever.

I apologize for using such words but this is how I feel about this place. It sucks how my phone died..I would've yelped this place first, but it's too late now.
author: Jen Z.

description:
Oh my god, this place is a TOURIST TRAP! DO NOT EAT HERE...I REPEAT DO NOT EAT HERE. We came here for lunch on a friday with 3 of my friends. We got the deal for $17 a person. However, since they were  4 of us, the server said we can get an additional entree since the deal is exclusive for 3 people. It seems like she implied that we get an additional entree for free. WRONG! We were charged an additional $11 for the plate!! What a rip off!!! The food is very very average...I repeat AVERAGE. In the end, our total  came to be about $100!!! What???!? It turns out a 20% tip was added. It was written in Chinese characters so I didn't understand the breakdown of the bill. The service was horrible and I did not think they deserve a 20%. So, I immediately cross off the tip amount and asked to be charged for the food alone. Please save yourself some money and find a better Chinese place to eat at!

I HIGHLY DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE!
author: Arbie M.

description: Paid $35 for 2 beers and a 4 piece of shrimp dim sum...? Plus they tipped themselves $5 and asked for another tip? Never going to this place again. Over priced! For nothing!!
author: Jovie V.

description: Horrible restaurant. We were overcharged and treated unfairly. They gave us tea we did not ask for, and our $17 entree was extremely small. Our bill came back $71 when it should have been $52. We had to argue with the staff and have them tally up each item in front of us and they even couldn't get it to $71. Food was good but not worth the fight.
author: Kody H.

description:
Good food! They validate! Service was basic. 

My boyfriends and I came to the seat to watch The Beauty and the Beast play they drove to china town. After parking in Portsmouth square garage we head to the Main Street of china town some women stopes us to had us there restaurants advertisement. After walking around we decided to eat here. We looked at the review but we're optimistic. 

We got the taste of Chinatown special for two. It was a great choice! We had a bit of everything! Spring rolls, shrimp dumplings, potstickers, Mongolian beef, cashew chicken and bbq pork chow main, white rice and green tea ice cream. The food was really delicious and came out quick. I must say their Thai tea wasn't the best a bit watery and not very sweet. 

The service was basic nothing special but they weren't rude or taking for ever. 

All in all the food was great and the pricing was a lil much for sea food. But it is family style and the one we had was $20 a person but you get quite a bit of food. 
The only thing that was odd is that they include the tip in your bill but they don't tell you and they give them selves about 20% tip.
author: Stesie ..

description: COCKROACHES and fruit flies don't know how this place is still open!
author: Jenn A.

description: terrible food, horrible service, and very overpriced. I had to ask 3 different waitresses for a refill on my water which took 30 minutes to receive. when we received a bill we were charged 9.00 for beverages which was 2 iced teas. not Thai iced teas regular iced teas. for 3 people we had automatic gratuity added on. do not waste your time here
author: Ashley C.

description:
No. No. No. if people are handing out coupons for a restaurant don't go!

We thought this place looked alright but the food sucks and service is HORRIBLE!
I went with my boyfriend and visiting family.
When they asked what we wanted to drink we said water, everyone else has cups of water at their table. The lady tried to convince us to buy water bottles for $2 and we said NO. she came out with bottled water and we told her AGAIN we want cups of water. She thought she would fool us because his family were tourist.
We ordered shrimp friend rice. There was only ONE PIECE. PIECE. not even half a shrimp. I complained to the manager and in front of us she shuffled through the rice and couldn't find any herself but that one orange piece. She claimed the pieces we cut so small we can't see them. Yup, and that was the manager. I had never been more disappointed at any restaurant ever.
author: Alyssa R.

description: Woefully, I got enticed here with a coupon for free potstickers with the purchase of an entree. I wish I hadn't. The spicy szechuan noodles weren't spicy. They were basically cold noodles and some bland sesame sauce. We used the sauce from the spicy eggplant dish to make it taste like something. I would not go back, and I would not recommend this place. I've definitely had better. It was disappointing.
author: Jen A.

description:
I see from reading other reviews that even Chinese people were charged their tip ahead of time. ABSOLUTELY TRUE. Tip was added to bill without our knowledge and if we hadn't asked we would have paid double+ tip. 

Dim sum was pretty good and most was fresh. A few other items were not so good. You can see from my ratings I usually give 5 star reviews and am only motivated to give a low review if it is highly deserved.

HIGHLY DESERVED. Do not patronize this restaurant. The food is exactly as the others describe, overpriced - and then they want to try to fool customers into paying a double tip. When asked about this, the staff gave several different explanations. We believe it is fundamentally illegal - when the bill comes it says PRE TIP AMOUNT- the one with the tip added in already, i.e. quite a bit more than your already expensive meal. This is why the lady chases you down in the street.
author: Amy Sterling C.

description:
This place is dishonest. They added 18% tip to the bill without label(luckily I caught it but still felt disgusted). Overly priced food came in a much smaller portion compared to a regular Chinese restaurant. In conclusion, this place will make you feel like you are being tricked after dining. Shame on them!! I hope you can avoid a bad experience by reading this review. 
Pick up any other place in Chinatown!
author: Jasmine W.

description: We had 24 people and this was the only place that could accommodate - first red flag. They give us potstickers on the house because the wait to order was so long - sweet!! We pour the soy sauce for dipping and there were 5 fruit flies, ONE STILL ALIVE!! We tell them and the response was "We can't help it if the flies get into the soy sauce. I can get you a new one but that's all we can do." WUT. The waitress is also a total B. We already ordered for all of us so we're still sitting here waiting but WTF. NEVER AGAIN. AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COSTS.
author: Lauren Q.

description: There is no reason to explain why an $85 bill for food that was completely unacceptable on every level needs further explanation.  I didn't check Yelp first, what a rookie mistake! Don't eat here!
author: Russell M.

description: The food was good. No doubt. The service was slow and they included a $9 tip. Since when do restaurants include a tip for a party of 3? I am aware if it's for a large group of people but for three people?
author: Kristin N.

description:
Most people (tourists) are lured in by the women giving out coupons for free potstickers. The restaurants that we wanted to go to were all over an hour wait. This was the closest one to go to. 

As for food wise, extremely salty. We had to ask for a pot of hot water just to dip the food in to limit the saltiness and spiciness. In addition, it was pretty pricey for what we were getting. One of the beef dishes we ordered (don't remember what it was) was completely raw on the inside of most of the beefs. The ice cubes in the water also had brown specks on it which seemed dirty. Also the wooden chopsticks seemed like they were reused. They were all bent and had a weird color to it.

As for service, it was ok. It wasn't terrible but it could have been a lot better. At least they got out the food at a reasonable time. 

Definitely do not recommend and don't fall into the trap of free potstickers, wifi, and ice cream. 

15% tip is also included just as a heads up.
author: Noah C.

description: Got the spicy cold noodles. The sauce was hardly good and the noodles were not spicy at all. Got served free pot stickers which were delicious. Also got the spicy eggplant which was very good, but I feel like I could find better. Free green tea ice cream was also very good. Don't think I'll go here again though.
author: Kyle L.

description: Tourist trap! I should have checked reviews before but we just wanted a quick wonton soup. Their menu specified that it comes with shrimp and chicken as well as the pork dumplings. We ordered a regular size and it had just broth and dumplings. When we asked they tried to tell us that you only get the shrimp and chicken if you order the $18 family size. Which we knew was bull**** to be honest but we were realizing what kind of place this was and didn't feel like arguing. When we received the bill (handwritten), they had added their own almost 20% tip. Just so everyone is clear this tip isn't required and is actually illegal under CA law so you can take that as a suggestion. I left 15% instead and the server hovered over me as I put my cash in the book, counted it out on my table in front of me, said "OK" and walked off. Avoid avoid avoid
author: Brian P.

description:
Jun 8th 2015 4 pm 
Had a great time at this restaurant and decided to check it out on yelp afterwards. 
Whhaaaaat? Its crazy how many poor reviews. Sat on balcony over the street.
Ordered a bar b q chicken kebab dish, spicy eggplant and spring rolls. Waiter was prompt. Brought out pot stickers on the house. Them within 10 minutes food was out and delicious. Asked for hot sauce as well and it was a textured spicy paste. Excellent  after meal was finished the waiter quickly took the dirty plates, and brought out green tea ice cream also on the house. was a perfect counter for the spice of the eggplant. Definitely would go again. Walked out for 35 dinner for two.
author: Michael C.

description:
Read the Yelp reviews before you go. I went to this restaurant without reading the Yelp reviews and am super regretting it right now.

This is the worst Chinese restaurant ever...food is overpriced and salty.

I am Chinese and have been to many good and bad Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. However, compared to all the restaurants I have been to, this is the worst. The food is more pricey than many of the good Chinese restaurants in SF Chinatown. If you do plan to try this place, make sure to check if they have already charged you for tip on the bill. When we received our bill, we were charged an extra 20% on top of our bill. We found out that this extra charge was a tip charge after asking the waiter. If we did not check our bill, we would have paid double the tip instead!

My friends and I order Sichuan food, so we cannot comment on the dim sum and other dishes. However, I can say that if you want Sichuan food, you should not go to this restaurant! There is a better Sichuan restaurant a couple blocks away. The Tan Tan Mien was extremely salty and the Ja Jiang Mien was nasty (cannot describe the awkward taste).

The sad part is the only good part to this meal was the free mediocre-tasting pot-stickers which comes with any order of appetizer and the free ice cream and fortune cookie dessert.  

**The highlight of my meal was when someone sitting on the table next to us said: "This isn't Chinese food. It's Malaysian."
author: Chloe A.

description: We ordered regular Wonton Soup and we didn't get everything, then the manager brought us our bill and said we refuse to serve you anymore. If they are planning on hosting people they better learn to translate their menu properly. RIP OFF!
author: Robert M.

description: When I went in, wanted to give it a try despite the reviews! Never again. This place is baad! So I came in and was greeted by a nice girl. I ordered water and tea. It was only me (party of 1) and this girl decided to bring me the upgraded large tea without asking me what size which is more money! As if it was 2-3 people drinking tea. I let it slide , then I got the chicken dumplings which she put it supposedly then came back 10 min later and asked me if I wanted the 3 only or the 8 on the apetizer. I told her the 8. Not even 1 minute after did she come out with 8 dumplings that seemed not fresh at all just reheated like if they were made the night before. Then I order the kung pao chicken and she kept saying and what else you want soup do you want this or that trying to upsell and I told her no just the chicken. I got so grossed out when I tasted the dish (not the actual site) the chicken and veggies tasted dirty like they were made on a dirty pan or cooked with dirty oil. I barely ate and the bill came out  to $35. Unbelievable ! Do not come here! I also had bad diereaah after for the day. Stay away
author: Justine Y.

description:
Ah...Chinatown Restaurant.  I seemed to fall into the same trap as so many others. Walking around Chinatown we were hungry and not thinking rationally.  My wife had made fun of the non-specific sign/name  (Chinatown Restaurant?  In Chinatown?  Creative!), when I remembered seeing them mentioned in either a guide book, or on the hotel's tourist channel (probably both). The source said it  was a "must try," so we decided to give it a shot.

The woman handing out coupons and ushering people inside was quite happy to have a couple that seemed to go inside willingly.  We went up the stairs, and the first thing that I noticed was that the only people eating in the dining room were white. Not a good sign for a Chinatown restaurant.  

We opted for a seat outside. They have a very cramped balcony and we were placed under the aforementioned sign. This we actually enjoyed because we had a nice view of the  street below.  

While waiting for our server I pulled out my phone and checked Yelp. Oooops! I had checked every other place before even considering going in, and  just by chance we ended up in the place with the WORST reviews.  However, we decided to try to not pre-judge and let the overall experience speak for itself.  At the very least the food couldn't be worse than the one Chinese place we have (had; it finally closed) in our town.

I liked this place more than most other reviewers, which is why I'm giving it 2 stars instead of 1. The wait staff was actually friendly with us. I did order a water that never arrived, but looking at the other reviews, that is a good thing because they charge for water.  The tip was not automatically included on our bill for two, but that would not have mattered either way because I was prepared for it; but I was glad to see it was not on there this time. We also were not overcharged for anything. Yes, the prices were too high for what we received, but they matched the prices on the menu.

It is true; the food is not good. The free potstickers were flavorless, and the dipping sauce was inedible.  The Combination chow mein was not horrible, but all of the meat in the dish was dry and stringy.  We also tried the General Tso's chicken...  The batter smelled a little of fish, but otherwise it tasted all right. Yes, you could have slightly better food at Panda Express, but it  doesn't come  with the cool  balcony.

Oh, and  the Green Tea ice Cream was actually pretty good.  But we were feeling a bit ill, so we gave it, along  with half our leftovers, to a nice homeless woman across the street.  At least we knew  she'd appreciate it.

Definitely a tourist trap.  I don't imagine many people go there more than once.  I'm very disappointed I didn't try another place in Chinatown that day, but fortunately there  will be other opportunities.
author: Aaron D.

description:
I am usually wary of places that hand out flyers to passerby, but this place enticed us with its offer of free chicken potstickers. Also, the places that looked more promising were crowded.
I had the Szechuan cold spicy noodles, one of my favorite dishes. I thought it was delicious.
My friend ordered the pea shoots and Chinese broccoli, and that was also good. The only snafu was when the waitress asked us if we wanted tea. We said, no tea, but please bring water. She brought tea, and no water. I was so thirsty I drank the tea. It was jasmine and very soothing. Also, as others have noted, be sure to check your bill because the restaurant includes a 20 % tip with the amount.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Service was excellent. While I was waiting for my dishes to come out, they gave me free dumplings to start out with. I ordered dim sum, a Chinese style bacon and veggie dish, and some mixed fried noodles. After I was done, they gave me free green tea ice cream. I have been there three times and they never failed to impress me but I just don't understand how it is so dead there, food and service was impeccable. I do recommend this place to whoever visits San Francisco's Chinatown!
author: Keung P.

description:
DON'T eat here unless you wanna pay 17% MANDATORY TIP that's added to your bill!
Their menu states, a gratuity of 15% will be added to bill for parties of 5 or more and this was just my wife and I, 2 people!!  Food was alright but if your a business that's desperate to bring customers in by handing out fliers for free potstickers if you dine with us, then don't subject your patrons to an automatic outrageous tip.  Unbelievable!  TIP Is optional and should be based on service and should be the customers decision/option not up your discretion!
Your Fliers for free appetizers is a TRAP to lure customers in charge them whatever you want...btw, potstickers are prob tainted/old/dirty...my wife was the only one who ate them and had Gastrointestinal issues immediately after...in other words, the food is free for a reason!  Please do something about this if you wanna stay alive as a business!
author: Marc C.

description:
For those of you that like horrible service but decent Chinese food, my only complaint about the food was that the meat was very oily. They validate parking for the garage across the street which is great considering how difficult it is to find street parking. They say free wifi but it's locked, and when you asks the server to get on wifi they never get back with the password. 

After sitting for 20 minutes our waitress comes over asking if we're ready to order I responded, " can we at least have something to drink first."
We had to ask 3 times for water and finally they just put a carafe with water on the table for us So we wouldn't ask anymore.

Definitely will not come back or recommend this place to anyone compared to the plethora of other authentic restaurants in the area then to try to settle for the mediocre experience my family and I had, worst part is they added gratuity to the bill for my family of 6.
author: Ernest R.

description: I wished I had seen the reviews of this place earlier. We were attracted by the sunny balcony with a nice view. We ordered dumplings and spring rolls. The food was served cold, tasteless and the service was just lame and very rude - just awful. This is the worst Chinese restaurant in America. Stay away from here! STAY AWAY!!!
author: Sebastian A.

description:
When I was seven, my brother used to tease me for no reason and I would chase after him and practice all the expletives I had acquired from kids of my age. One time I was caught by my dad and he smacked me so hard, I literally passed out. I regained my consciousness and began to have this feeling of hatred of my brother for 4+ years.

That's the exact feeling you'll experience after you walk out of this restaurant.

To get customers, they have people standing at the corner of Grant and Washington practically trying to pull you in with the promise of all day dim sum. Don't fall for it!!! They have dim sum but the shrimp smells obscene and the chicken tastes vulgar. Those are the only two words that can sum up their food.

And as a kicker, they will include tip for two people. That's the same feeling as my brother taunting me after he witnessed my punishment.

Yelp wants me to give at least 1 star. I wanted to give 0. Seeing they have 1.5 star, the least i can do is to bring down their average.

It'll take more than 4+ years for me to forget and forgive Chinatown Restaurant
author: H N.

description: Don't use your card here! I would not trust them with my card. This place  is so sketchy I would not be surprised if my card got  skimmed or have my card number written  down. Their other Yelp page was so bad, they had to make 2 Yelps for their restaurant. This one is 1/2 a star better. They automatically add a tip to their bill! The food was horrible! The steamed pork dumplings were very undercooked! The service was bad. This place should be ashamed of itself. They lure people in with old ladies harrassing you to go in and a large picture of the food outside with none of it on their menu. They lure tourists in and serve them crappy food and rip them off. This place has no soul. How can you lure people visiting from other countries and rip them off with crappy food and overcharging them? Sorry if you decided not to read the Yelp reviews before eating here. The fact that this place even has 2.0 stars blows my mind! It should be a 1.0 at most! If the positive reviews are not from the owner's family, friends, people whose have no taste buds, or people who have a fetish for crappy Chinese food, then holy moly! Anything is possible
author: Vicente L.

description:
FOOD POISONING! DONY GO THERE!

If I could give 0 stars I would. 

We were also chased by this lady with a coupon. Must've seen suckers on our foreheads.

Food: Oily, salty, sour. CRAP! Plus offering Spare ribs in the Dim Sum menu but never got it.
Service: The usual rude Chinese service. Worth: Overpriced! Plus they tack on a 20% tip for service we never received.

I wanted to throw up the minute I finished eating. 

Left feeling like we were not only ripped off, we must've landed the worst Chinese restaurant in the world.

As for this toilet? YUCK! I can't imagine what the kitchen must look like. 

This Chinatown restaurant should be closed down. My boyfriend has been sick (food poisoning, fever, night sweats) the past 2 days since eating there. 

Please don't go there! Toilet. 

WORST RESTAURANT IN THE WORLD!
author: Ndidi B.

description:
My family and I were lured in by ladies on the street. We were a bit desperate and willing to try anything so they caught us at the perfect time. Dim Sum was what we wanted and they had an extensive amount of options for our craving. 

There were some questions about the specials we could not have answered which was the first problem we ran into: the language barrier. My family enjoys laughing and being loud, so were a bit let down to enter a very quiet environment. The second story was being used for the main dining area which was relatively full, but it felt like a library. If a nice quiet dinner is what you are interested in then you will find that here. 

The food itself was not bad. If you order a entree you get free pot stickers, but the catch is that even if you order six entrees you still only receive one free serving of pot stickers which amount to about five. We got the family meal which was a little bit of everything. There were these pieces of chicken on a stick which were "like chicken McNuggets," according to my sister. I enjoyed the honey glazed shrimp along with the rest of my family who quickly ate it up. 

My mother described the meal as "nothing to write home about," which is exactly how I feel. There is nothing extraordinary about this place and nothing horrible either. 

Pros: 
Free wifi 
Free Potstickers with purchase of entree
Roundabout table for uncivilized fun 

Cons:
Too quiet for me
Language barrier with hosts
Slightly expensive
author: Frankie Z.

description:
We are so grateful for Chinatown restaurant for letting us dine with our fur babies. We thought they were going to sit us outside. To out surprise we were seated in the dining room. Nice and cozy :)
The food dishes we ordered: spicy Kung Pao, orange chicken, beef broccoli and shrimp fried rice were superb!! Service was excellent too
author: Betty V.

description:
THIS PLACE IS HORRIBLE. 
I realized I ate here twice, both times by accident, because my girlfriend and I were really hungry while walking through Chinatown. They approach you in the street with a coupon for free potstickers and green tea ice cream. Don't take the bate. 

Reasons why this place sucks:
1.  We ordered Peking Duck.  It arrived cold after we waited forever. We notified them that it was cold, they took in the back, and we heard the microwave door slam shut. THEY MICROWAVED OUR DUCK.  I asked them if they microwaved it, and they said, yes of course--all the duck is cooked earlier in the day and then microwaved. Our waitress said, "the cook forgot to microwave yours." 

2.  The food was bad. Service was terrible. Everything is overpriced. 

3.  They include the tip on your bill. I left cash, but they did not bring me change. So I asked for my change, and they brought me insufficient change, and said "we don't have anymore change for you, sorry." This was irritating, so I told them to round up and bring me change to the nearest dollar. 

Go eat somewhere else. There are plenty of other options.
author: Michael W.

description:
This place needs to be shut down.  I'm typing this for a friend who doesn't have a yelp account.  She say's she'll sign up for an account and post her story tomorrow, but this is a freaking EMERGENCY.  

Long story short, my friend's family came to town and the flyer lady drew them in here.  My friend takes a few bites of dim sum, and freaking THREE FRUIT FLIES FALL OUT.  She freaks out, but doesn't speak Chinese and the servers don't speak English, so her dad starts yelling at the server in Chinese.  No wonder why everyone is getting sick here!

Oh yea, if that isn't bad enough, after they pointed out the fruit flies, the server unapologetically still billed them for the meal, as if her family did something wrong.  Pathetic and appalling.

refer to pic:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/chinatown-restaurant-san-francisco?select=KWyku084OQjdvFM1CHgDBA#KWyku084OQjdvFM1CHgDBA
author: Alan C.

description:
My dining companion was interested in eating here, so we decided to give it a try for lunch.  It looked like the dining room downstairs was closed, so we were led upstairs.  Looking around I saw my first red flag: the Asian people in the room were greatly outnumbered by the non-Asians.  Not a good sign.

But we had already sat down and it was too late to leave.  After perusing the menu (there were fewer items on the menu than at a typical Chinese restaurant), we ordered Shanghai style dumplings, sweet potato pancakes, and a plate of beef chow fun.

Apparently if you walk by a nearby corner, women are passing out coupons for Chinatown Restaurant.  It entitles you to free pot stickers and green tea ice cream for dessert.  Even though we didn't have a coupon, they gave us the deal anyway.

The pot stickers arrived first.  They were middle of the road.  I've had much better, and I've had much worse.  Then came the sweet potato pancakes.  They arrived hot, fresh, and crispy.  We liked them a lot.

The Shanghai style dumplings came next.  They were very good, but not the best I have ever eaten.  The beef chow fun came last.  That was the most disappointing part of the meal.  It was rather bland and didn't come steaming hot from the kitchen for some reason.

After our meal was over, we received a small styrofoam cup full of green tea ice cream, topped with a fortune cookie.  It was pretty good.  Service was just okay.

We will not be coming back.
author: The Bottomless Pi T.

description: Not as bad as the reviews. Good Chinese food got the lobster and lemon chicken . Will be back
author: Maritza L.

description: There was a fly in the tea. The food was cold. The service was slow. When I asked where the restroom was, I was talked over by one server, the other one looked at me and walked away. Finally, I asked a male server and he pointed me in the right direction (literally). It was dirty with pee on the floor. To make it all worse, after we left, the waiter came running down the stairs yelling. He confronted us on the stairs and said, "you didn't pay for a tip," shoving a bill in my husband's face. My husband said, "I paid for the food. There was a fly in the tea." I patiently explained the meaning of gratuity or tip. We left never to return...Crazy...
author: Tammie L.

description: If restaurant employees approach you with coupons luring you to eat there, run. This place is expensive, a rip-off, and disgusting. Customer service here is by far the worst. For a restaurant that's been around for over 100 years (1913), you'd expect the place to look a little nicer than most, but it's the exact opposite. My first time here will be my last. The bathroom floors are wet and sticky, the wall where I was seated against had a large cockroach crawling around, you have to pay for a glass of water, and an 18% tip is already included in your tip despite how small your party is. When I asked the waiter to get rid of the roach, he just brought out a broom and chased it around the restaurant. This place is a joke. Save yourself and don't go here.
author: Randy P.

description:
I've been here several times and I used to really like this place, but never again after the fraud they committed.

I arrived with a friend and asked for a table for two. With half the tables available, the hostess thought it would be a good idea to seat us between the kitchen door and a screaming baby. We requested a table outside, away from the screaming. Then we sat there and waited, and waited, and waited for service. I finally stood in the doorway until someone came over.

We ordered the dim sum sampler which was definitely NOT worth $16.95pp, and after delivering a small plate of wontons we were left waiting and still hungry again. Our drinks arrived but the water I had requested never did. We were completely ignored throughout the meal and by the end had to rush to leave. I stood at the hostess station waiting for our check and watching the hostess repeatedly try to seat people in the least desirable tables - what is with that?!

I noticed that tip had been added automatically and I asked that I only be charged for the meal ($46 for two people for dim sum, with no alcohol, is pretty steep). The lady took ages bringing my card back to me. When I checked my bank balance today, I saw that she charged $46, then charged $55 on top of that. Now I have to go through a whole dispute with my bank to get back money they were never owed in the first place. This is fraud and my next call will be to the police.
author: Mary F.

description:
Cant keep up with orders, little food per servings, rude servers, cant write english, DONT come here.

Potato cake is good though.
author: Therese W.

description: Bill wasn't in English and 4 dollars more than the menu price - food also didn't tasted bad
author: Natalie N.

description:
BE WARNED: This is a tourist trap.

Due to the long lines at other restaurants and my boyfriend's raging hunger we unfortunately found ourselves lured into Chinatown Restaurant. At first glance it seems pretty chill, it's a very large restaurant and the menu looked pretty good. However, the service is pretty sparse, aka it takes forever to order, get your food and receive your bill. 

We ordered the mongolian beef, the eggplant with garlic sauce and the xiao long bao. When they asked us what we wanted to drink we of course said tea, but also water. THEY CHARGE $3 FOR TEA! WTF. And it's not even that good quality tea -____- Be careful, I'd just get water and save my money. The food took awhile to arrive and when it did it was so-so quality. I liked the eggplant the best; the dish looked very pretty with the purple eggplant but the sauce was mediocre and the chilis weren't even that spicy. The mongolian beef was okay, but it kinda tasted Panda Express-y which isn't what you want when you go to a restaurant. The XLB took an extra 10-15 minutes to even show up and by that time I was kinda full. Even so don't order the XLB, the outer skin is too thick, there is barely any soup/juice inside and the meat quality is meh. Definitely a disappointment. 

We did receive a free plate of gyoza and ice cream for dessert since we ordered an entree. The gyoza was so-so but the ice cream was pretty good I'll give them that. However, once we received our bill we noticed the charged us for tea (which I already talked about), rice (lame) AND they added a 15% gratuity!! Service was nowhere near deserving this amount but my boyfriend was fed up at that point and we just paid and left. So shady.

In the end I'm NOT coming back here anytime soon. They definitely rope in the tourists and charge $2-4 MORE for each dish than any of the other authentic places nearby. Save your money and go somewhere else! You may have to wait to be seated at another restaurant but at least you will be getting legit food.

P.S. The downstairs bathrooms smell bad, avoid using if possible.
author: Sam F.

description: After being followed on grant street by employees that work here to strum up business we decided we would give it a try. Our initial waitress seemed very crabby with us. We ended up with 3-4 wait staff buy the end. Ordered the sweet and sour chicken(good) the chefs rice(good) and the vegetarian spring rolls(excellent). We were not disappointed with the food however the service could be much better. We had to ask three separate times for a box and still did not receive one. Finally we had to get one ourselves. When we got our bill it was all in Chinese(yea I know I'm in China town) but you really don't know what is what. Also something we found out from other yelpers and then looked closer to our bill is that they include a tip on there already.   They could have explained that a little bit better. THe food was the only thing that got stars. The service would not have gotten any
author: Angie B.

description:
DANGER!!! WARNING!!!! Do not eat at this place. It's all a scam!!!!!!!Please for the love of God go anywhere else. They serve food that is greasy and full of sugar. The quantity, nor the quality of the food is worth the high price. 

Their street team harasses you until you finally go to the restaurant. They will give you a coupon for free potstickers, but if you included their MANDATORY 20% TIP!!! You are really not getting anything free. I always give generous tips, but when a business tells me to give them money.... WELL F**K THIS RESTAURANT FROM HELL. They will try to sell you anything they can to up their tip. By the way the potstickers are from Safeway, because I have had them before. 

There are so many better places to eat in Chinatown, but if you still want to try this restaurant well good luck to you.
author: Antonio M.

description:
Despite the Yelp rating, I ventured to eat here. It's like the teacher is telling you the truth, but you try to experiment in the lab anyway!! 

I ended up being sick, so sick..that I threw up and suffered through a night of tummy travails. 

Several ladies, standing on either side of the restaurant, on opposite sides of the street, literally grab you by the elbow as you're walking and lead you to this restaurant. The dining area, upstairs is not busy, but not empty either. I noticed a lot of tourists frequent this restaurant; saw a lot of Germans (heard them rather!) and some English and French. 

Service is prompt, but in a bad way. I wasn't even seated fully (like pull my chair in and set my bag down) when a table host asked me what I wanted to eat - I asked for a minute. 45 seconds later, I'm asked to order food. So, I rushed through the menu and ordered some rice and two vegetable dishes.

I was served complimentary pot-stickers; I gently turned down the offer, for which I received some mumblings. I explained, "I'm a vegetarian."

Then I was asked if I'll have tea - naturally, anything warm on a foggy, cold night is comforting, so I said yes. I realized later that I should have said , "NO." (they charged me for it!!!!!!!!!!!)

The food was hot, seemingly fresh. But of course, the next 9 hours - hapless and miserable. 

My order:

1. Eggplant in garlic sauce -- read that as Eggplant in oily sauce
2. Bitter Melon - see the pictures...I used several napkins to absorb the oil, which oozed and oozed and oozed!!
3. Veg fried rice -- I returned the order once it was set on the table - 3 strands of hair :O(((

The rest - complimentary green tea ice cream -- whatever. 

Unforgettable -- a service fee and forced 20% tip for 2!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I asked for it to be voided and stated that it's up to me to decided whether I give them a 12%-15% or 20%...for which I'm sure they cursed me out. They DID NOT void the transaction. 

Long story short, this turned out to be a bad experiment - but money spent here is worth it -GOOD lesson learnt!
author: Me Iz S.

description: Service is bad and food is so so.  They automatically add a 20% tip which is ridiculous for a party of 4 and with bad service.  STAY AWAY- DO NOT RECOMMEND.
author: Trang P.

description: The food is excellent and the services.. Contrary to others , I will recommend this Restaurant..
author: Rusty B.

description:
ADVOID THIS PLACE!! 

Eh, they lure you here with "free" potstickers and ice cream. But they over charge on the bill and add an 18% tip. Their service did not deserve that by the way.
author: Lei L.

description: It's a major tourist trap. Food is okay, but not for the price. They scam you for the most expensive without telling you.
author: Samantha S.

description:
I would give it no stars, if i could! DO NOT eat here.  

My wife and I went here because it looked decent on the outside and a little bit nicer than the other places in chinatown.  At first it was ok, other than the servers staring at us the whole time before we ordered.  Then of course we looked at them, and they turned away as if we wouldn't notice.

Once the food arrived, it was ok at best, but not terrible, but then a cockroach climbed on the table.  When i notified the staff, they got the cockroach and said "we just opened the door, it must've came in" but we were eating on the 2nd floor! There is no  way you opened the door (on the 2nd floor) and a cockroach just waltzed in.  

Of course, we lost our appetites at that point.  My wife and I looked at each other and just asked for the bill.  We had only eaten 2 items at that point (before we vomited as we left) and they didn't even try to offer a discount.  We had a couple items we didn't even touch and didn't want to, at this point. Yet they still tried to charge us full price.  

They ended up giving us 50% off, AFTER the table across the room, found a hair in their food!  

STAY AWAY! Eat elsewhere! This place is disgusting and customer service is even worse!

I used to wait tables, so i generally tip well even if the service is bad, and certainly comp people (when i was a server) if they had a bad experience like this, but they did no such thing.  I have never stiffed anyone before, but they made no effort, were rude, and the food was barely mediocre at best.  

Please, save your time and money and go elsewhere!
author: Kim R.

description:
To be honest, due to the reviews, I wasn't really sure about this place. The ladies and I were walking around Chinatown when this lady approached us and gave us some coupons. We were already hungry and some of the other girls needed restrooms, so we followed her. I immediatly yelped it and was nervous. I told my sister in law that the reviews weren't that great, but we decided to give it a shot anyway.

We had a group of 8, including me. Service was pretty friendly, we sat around with our waters and hot tea for a while as we waited for our food. We all went with the $13.95 special, it did come with a lot of dishes though, so that was a plus. I wasn't a huge fan of some of them, but there were some decent ones. I do have to say that the green tea ice cream, was the best I've had by far. Some dishes came out a little cold, which shouldn't be since we're the first customers there. Others were salty as some were not at all. Overall, it's not the best out there, but it's not the worst.
author: Nani V.

description:
After so many flyers being handed to me on Grant St, and after admiring their fire escape patio dining from (the sadly now-closed) Empress of China, we finally gave Chinatown Restaurant a try last weekend. It was a solid middle of the road experience.

We sat outside on the patio. Service was slow despite the restaurant being barely full, but at least they brought the hot tea out quickly- which was nice for a cold day. We ordered the beef noodle roll, the pork dumplings and the lotus buns (because they were out of steamed pork buns, BOO.). The food tasted OK, nothing particularly stood out. The bill was around $35 which seemed fair. The only two things we really liked about our meal was the view of Chinatown from the patio and the free dessert of green tea ice cream topped with fortune cookies.

Chinatown Restaurant wasn't an amazing experience but it got the job done. We'd probably go again.
author: Summer M.

description:
Not satisfied and ridiculously overpriced.

Usually when you go to a Chinese restaurant in Chinatown, you are looking for an authentic place for a good cheap meal. Well, let me tell you, this is no such a place. They charge 18 bucks for a tiny bowl of chili fish with only 5-6 pieces of fish in it. And the chili pepper potato slices are as thick as a chopstick... What's more outrageous is we had one hot tea and one water, they brought us the regular flavorless free hot tea you can find in any Chinese restaurant and one of those a sixty-cent bottle water. In the bill, they charged us five dollars for beverage?! 

The only plus we had with this place is the free pot stickers that we got from the coupon girl at the door... With this quality of food and this much overpriced, no wonder why you need to hire a bunch of girls chasing people on the street and lure them in with free potstickers.
author: Ran L.

description: A friend wanted to go here. Having been here before I refused. He agreed that he would treat me to dinner if I would agree to eat here. He said his friend in LA said it was good and he wanted to try it. OK, but only because you are paying. Sure enough once seated we were ignored. Isn't this great I asked. He put his hands in the air and flagged down a waitress. Still no hot tea. The menu's came. more waiting. Our order was taken. Still no hot tea. More waiting. The siu mi arrived. Still no hot tea. The low bok gow arrives. Could we have some hot mustard? Hot mustard arrives with hot tea. A few minutes later water arrives. Then we are handed the bill. Where is our har gow? We never got the har gow, yet we are charged for it. They adjusted the bill and my friend said this still isn't correct. I told him they add an automatic 18% plus the prices are all higher than on the menu for late at night. He said that isn't right. I said, I didn't want to come here, thanks for dinner. The food was average at best. I do not understand why people from out of town do not listen to the locals.
author: Alan H.

description:
Would have given them two stars... then read the reviews and saw that we were completely scammed too! Didn't even realize that tip was included in the bill (we tipped twice.. no wonder the bill seemed ridiculous) 

We didn't eat half of the food. Dirty crab... fishy smelling shrimp... bland soup. Bill came out to $75 for lunch. Let me repeat. FOR LUNCH. 

1 star for the patio view.
author: Ann B.

description:
Not terrible. I expected to be severely disappointed since they got us in here (as they seem to do everyone else) via guerilla street warfare tactics. They have people all over Chinatown attacking every passerby with flyers and then literally trying to drag you into the restaurant. Not the best idea, imo, but moving on..

We tried a variety of dishes and found most to be above average. The portions are also HUGE and you will very likely leave with leftovers. Service was decent. Prices are about average for the area.
author: Melissa T.

description:
THIEVES! After eating here with my wife, I paid with my credit card. The following morning, my bank blocks my card. Someone had ripped my card and tried using it at a 7eleven for $645.

Not f***ing happy.
author: Spike D.

description:
ONe of my fave spots in chinatown . Of course Sam Woo was my number one fave. I am sorta lost with Sam Woo gone, I know for sure this is a place I will frequent tho.   I don't quite no where to place this place on the list but it is a really great place.    They even had this place in some scenes in the rush hour movies and one of leo dicaprio's movies. 
This seems like the place to go for celebs in sf wanting some chinese .

The prices are great and hey you get free ice cream with your meal.

They've also had great customer service and smiled everytime I came in here drunk from partying in Broadway.  They always served my beer nice and chilled wink wink. 

The food is also very very good. 

THis is a great meet up spot for before going to a comedy club, some other happy hour spots, or ha Broadway .

Great place for parties too and taking dates. IF you sit up top you can get a great view of the entire area.
author: Luke S.

description:
You don't have to pay the 18% tip they include on the bill!! 
Food was okay, service wasn't the worst, but they added an 18% tip to our group of 3 that they figured we wouldn't notice, when we asked the waitress she was incredibly rude, but took it off. We ended up giving her a much lower tip than she may have gotten if she hadn't tried to trick us.
author: Gabriella P.

description:
First full morning in San Fran and we fell into the trap. Walking in, I already knew it was a tourist trap but my boyfriend wanted to try it anyways. We sat outside but it smelled like pee, it was disgusting. We then went inside instead and things were old, falling apart, and instead of running the AC, they had a fan per table. 

We ordered only 3 dimsum dishes, they were mediocre, I wanted to try sf dimsum to see if it tastes better than nyc. But after that experience, we didn't try another dimsum spot. They had icecream, it was tinted green but did not taste like green tea at all...

It wasn't a great experience, I wanted to get out quickly.
author: Louise C.

description:
Other reviews are correct. Mediocre food at best and overpriced for this area. We had pork dumplings, fancy fish dumplings, pork buns, Hong Kong style crispy noodles and soft shell crab (at $9.95 it was totally not worth it, small and fishy tasting... Don't order). + 4 sodas. Total bill with tax n tip= $67 for 4 people. No alcohol. I think this is the most expensive meal I've ever had in Chinatown. Should have cost closer to $40 out the door.

First the good- 
1) green tea ice cream. Free with meal. 
2) Nice atmosphere- authentic Chinatown ambience.
3) not overcrowded and no wait (probably due to bad reviews) 
4) the pork dumplings were very juicy and fresh (they gave us 6 for $3.95 so not bad)
5) pork buns (3 for $3.95, again tasty and reasonable price)

Now the bad
1) never a good sign in Chinatown when no Chinese people are eating there... This should have been my first clue 
2) soft shell crab for $9.95. Very fishy taste  and possibly the very worst I've ever had
3) Hong Kong style crispy noodles with chicken, BBQ pork n shrimp for $12.95. Expensive compared to other places nearby where I've paid an average of $7.95. The pork tasted old/leftover, the shrimp tasted fishy, and the chicken seemed boiled and flavorless. The noodles weren't as crispy as I like
4) sodas were $2.00 each... I suppose that's probably average.
5) service once we put our order in seemed slow. Then they brought our check pretty quickly without asking if we wanted more, which we did... Then we waited forever for our pork buns and our revised check and then the return of our credit card.

If you go here, I recommend getting nothing except the dumpling dishes, and just water to keep lunch costs down. The pork dumplings were about as good as I've had anywhere else, even if slightly more cost.
author: Chrys K.

description:
This restaurant is definitely a tourist trap. They hook you up with potstickers "on the house". The food was ok, not good enough for me to want to come back. At the end of our meal, they gave us green tea ice cream with fortune cookies, also "on the house". 

When the bill came, we were charged $6 for bottles water and $4 for a pot of tea. They included a 20% tip. LOL. 

Don't come here.
author: Maida C.

description: It was an old, historic restaurant that opens its door since 1911. However, I believed that it was under new boss recently as it had changed its menu from traditional Hong Kong style to Chinese Sze Chuan style. The dishes are quite pricey, tastes were OK. The most uncomfortable thing was they added 18% gratuity automatically to the bill during lunch, which we felt bad about, and had to crossed it out manually. I guessed it was a common practice in this tourist area, but very unpleasant. We would not come back again.
author: Eric H.

description:
The WORST restaurant I have ever been to, DONT GO. 
The woman on the street referred us to here, ehhh
We wanted to throw up the minute we finished eating. 
1) They added 20% tip on top of your bill even before you tip. And they don't tell you about this (so you could double dip)
2) Extremely BAD SERVICE, after we asked for the wifi, she said it didn't work, w/o apology
3) The food doesn't taste authentic!! This is not real Sichuan food.
4) OVERPRICED before the tip.! For the boiled water fish fillet, I had an authentic dish in Boston for 6 dollars less. Heh. They added 20% tip because they knew you wouldn't tip them!!!
5) Other reviews talked about FOOD POISONING. Heh
author: Jess G.

description:
We went to this place because someone on the street corner was hustling on the street with brochures.  Big mistake, very communist in they way they treat the customer. 

We ordered the won ton soup... no flavor, it was more like tea.  We ordered the prawns and our teeth were popping grains of dirt or sand, they obviously didn't wash the shrimp.  We ordered the Shanghai Steak and it was FLOODED with salt.  I finally put my foot day and sent the steak back after a couple of bites and they told me I was wrong because they liked the taste. They tried to convince me to order more rice to mask the saltiness.  

I then spotted them taking my same plate of Shanghai beef to another table who ordered it.  My plate had a large chip in it, so did the plate they brought to the other table.  So they recycle food to finish it off.  Very gross, don't go there
author: Tommy M.

description:
One of the largest warning signs is when a restaurant needs people to lure people in with coupons for free potstickers. We were searching for a dim sum place in Chinatown and were lured by people offering coupons to this restaurant. 

The service is pretty bad, but the food is even worse. We ordered tea, pork buns and Shanghai soup dumplings. The Cha siu pork buns seemed like they were microwaved and served to us; the taste was quite inauthentic and awful. The Shanghai soup dumplings were also horrible; the meat filling was too chewy and the broth inside didn't have its normal flavor. 

In addition to the terrible food and service, they charged us for tea. Overall, I would highly recommend avoiding this restaurant if you can.
author: Lillian C.

description: First I went to this place and had to wait more than 40 minutes for my foods to come. In fact it wasn't even busy at that time even the customers came after me got their food and expect for my meal. Plus including the terrible service they already had the services charges in the bills add to the total.
author: Minuwantha D.

description: This place use to be one of our favorite's (my girlfriend and I), the food has been good and the price was right. We love the traditional Beef Chow-Fun and Honey Walnut Prawns are always a succulent choice. But recently when paying for the check were given one amount as the "Total" and then when we got the credit card charge, the employees decided to pre-charge their own determined amount for tip on top of the "Total." Kind of disgruntled by this, granted, yes the tip amount they calculated was 20% but on this evenings visit the service was slow, we had to ask for water three times, and the FREE potstickers ended up coming later in the meal when we asked to have those first. Sadly we might not be returning to this establishment and would advise making sure you know what the true total is before having your credit card swiped.
author: Austin D.

description: Bad bad!!! Tourist trap, bad food, bad service, we had METAL in our $13 fried rice. For some hungry musicians on the road, we were severely disappointed
author: Jess M.

description:
First the money-we went here because we had a restaurant.com certificate and figured what the heck. We asked if we could use it, and the hostess said yes, no restrictions. It was a spend $100, get $50 off. After ordering $110 in food and drinks, when we received the check, our total was $150. According to the waitress drinks aren't included in the $100 minimum, so our total food cost before tax was 99.50. When we questioned the waitress, she said she would talk to the manager. He agreed to honor the certificate, but our bill was still over $100, because of tax and the 18% gratuity charged for our party of 4. I'm still not positive everything was added properly on our bill, and the ticket wasn't in english, so there was no way to really verify it.

Now the food! Some of our dishes, like the coconut seafood soup and the house special beef were a little bland. The creamy honey walnut prawns were outstanding, as was the sweet and sour pork. The thai style shrimp were awesome, all our food was hot and came very quickly. We were here during the Chinese New Year Celebration so the restaurant was full, not an empty table anywhere, so the speed was impressive.

Service-seconds after being seated they wanted to take our order. We felt a little rushed when they came back 2 minutes later to take our order. We never got the straws or napkins we asked for twice. 

Based on a few of the dishes, I'd probably go back, but I would definitely watch the bill.
author: Char C.

description:
Chinatown Restaurant 
744 Washington St
San Francisco, CA 94108 

Where is the no star button?!

I just want to let everyone know how horrible my experience was at this place in San Francisco, Chinatown. After being chased down on the street by a lady with a "coupon" please RUN the other direction and go somewhere else to eat. A part of me wished I walked a couple blocks to find a decent restaurant for my family (party of 14) to eat. The service sucks and the waiter wasn't all that great. She was rude and I know she wasn't happy begin there. Their version of a "family style" dish ISN'T a "family style" more like a single serving for 1 person!! They gave us dirty ice for our water and their lazy susan was hard to turn. For the price it was bloody expensive and they add addition charges on the bill. Charges!? You are scratching your head wondering where it came from?! They automatic put it on the bill you have no choice.

I had family from out of town and it was embarrassing for me. All I can do was shake my head. NEVER GO THERE AGAIN!!

I am surprised they pass restaurant health inspection. There is 14 of us and they are not good accommodating a large group. $45+ a person wasn't worth it includes tip/surcharges and other charges they added on to it.
author: Ann Marie A.

description:
I'm not sure where all the hate is coming from in the negative reviews here, because my boyfriend and I had a perfectly good experience. In fact, the dim sum was delicious and there was a lot of it. At $16/person for the sampler menu, it's a great deal for what you get.

It's a tourist trap (we were bombarded by people a block away trying to usher us in), but we were hungry and just looking for a place that would take credit cards since a lot of spots in Chinatown are cash only and we had none. Some of the dim sum items seemed Americanized (bacon wrapped shrimp?), but I'm not exactly a Chinese food connoisseur so I wasn't bothered by that. Everything was really tasty and settled well. The free pot stickers and green tea ice cream were also a nice touch.

Our bill did not have an automatic gratuity added to it like some others mentioned.

If you're in the area and looking for a tasty meal, you could do a lot worse than this restaurant.
author: Lisa A.

description:
After sitting down to eat (we were enticed by the coupon and we were really hungry when we walked past), we then looked at the reviews on Yelp. We read the reviews about issues with the ticket, and the quality of the food and got a little nervous. 
Here's the net of it: the food was great (holy cow was the fried rice awesome, as well as the sweet and sour chicken), but maybe we Texans just don't get it. And the bill was totaled correctly, with the tip amount at the bottom. When they ran my credit card, it was for the total less the top, which I promptly rounded up and added. 
We had a great experience, and I'm glasses we only saw the Yelp reviews after sitting down to eat.
author: Robert D.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE. It's a trap.

Asked for tap water 3 times and was continually pressured to buy bottled water because it's "healthier". They also automatically add 20% tip to the bill, so read your bill carefully! Don't fall for the $19 pp menu they try and get you to purchase - it's too much food. Food is mediocre, service terrible - please read all the other reviews here on yelp and AVOID.
author: James M.

description:
I have never given a restaurant a one star review but in this case I had to. After being chased down on the street by a lady with a "coupon". I was hungry and decided to eat there. To begin, you have to walk up stairs to get to the restaurant. It's not like a few stairs but very steep stairs. I have no idea how a person who has trouble walking would be able to eat here. 

Just from walking in there something didn't feel right. It was scorching hot and not very clean.  I went through a few pages on the menu and was astonished at the ridiculously high prices. $17 for calamari, are you kidding me. The dishes coming out didn't look very well. I went onto yelp and saw the reviews. After reading the multiple reviews, my decision was made. I walked out hungry. 

Do not fall for the trick in the street. Avoid at all costs!!
author: May S.

description:
Never written a bad review before now but that is probably because I Usually check Yelp before I eat  somewhere.  

Perhaps it was the pushy lady on the corner of the street who guided me to this place; perhaps the pushy waitress who needed the order right away because the place was half empty and well...???; no it was reading a Yelp review about roaches when I started to order that finally did the trick.  

I cannot review the food because I was out of there before I could order anything.
author: C A.

description: This place is great! The service was above and beyond. Food was plentiful & delicious. The hostess was very helpful. We were a large group (18 people) and this place was able accommodate us within mins.
author: Marty R.

description: The worst experience in California. Food was pathetic, hosts were rude and not pleasing, and they also add tip on bill by self. One star only due to sitting on balcony.
author: Himanshu Shiva A.

description:
Their street team rushes you in with a coupon for free wontons and ice cream.
Crappy service and they didn't like that we wanted separate checks.
Our waitress didn't understand our requests so they got us a different one. 

The soup was not hot enough.
author: Isabel A.

description:
DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY OR TIME...KEEP WALKING
I fell for the coupon woman and could just slap myself. The place we wanted to go was closed and I didn't have a back-up. Watch out for the soup. My wife ordered egg drop soup. You would think a cup would come as in any other Chinese Restaurant. NOPE, a bowl with a ladle and two bowls shows up for both of us ($8.95). Nothing comes with your entree...no rice, broccoli...nothing. They off you the "opportunity" to purchase those items. I got the SMALL mixed veggies $7.95. Wouldn't have ordered it if I had been given a chance to find out how much my little addition was going to cost. The Gen Tso's was a soft fried greezy coating. I can get that quality in the frozen food section at Safeway. Our bill for a mediocre meal with the tip that they chose to help themselves to was $75.
author: Tim J.

description: This is my first the ever writing a review but this particular restaurant was absolutely the worst ever! Not only the service was bad but the food was not even good. We order a shrimp noodle roll ( it had a hair on it) and soft shell crab (it had a fishy taste almost threw up) the appetizer that had a hair on it - we wanted to cancelled it they still made us pay for it - a server which wasn't our server yelled at me infront of a crowed of people because I wanted to cancel the shrimp roll that was made that had the hair on it (we ended up paying for it to aviod the delimma) me and my boyfriend sat outside to enjoy the view although it was a bit cold, when we wanted to move inside they didn't  acknowledge us.... It hate to write this but I'm very upset it happen us.....
author: Karina C.

description:
DO NOT GO HERE!! 
We ordered 2 cocktails and 8 beers for a group of 4. 
The bill came out to $90!!! RIDICULOUS!
author: Stacey N.

description:
My husband and I came in since we wanted to see the New Years Celebration.

OVER EFFING PRICED!!! DO NOT ENTER!!!

61.50... TIP INCLUDED AT 20%%

Pot stickers were free and very tasty. 

Shrimp rice noodle were bland and did not have a whole shrimp, SOME had half of a small shrimp and got one with maybe a 1/4 of the tail.

Shrimp dumplings were very delicious flavorful and great. 

Sui mai had no shrimp, had a pico De gallo garnish which was odd to us.

Egg Fu Yong delicious... It was have spectacular if the onion wasn't so raw. It was super crunchy... I need to buy gum now.

Food came out at separate times about 5 minutes apart, we didn't mind so much since it gave us a chance to enjoy what we were eating.

Service was okay/friendly. We only wanted to order a few items and waitress keep bugging for us to get another entrée; we got another order of dim sum. It is located upstairs and the has a nice atmosphere, clean.
author: Diana F.

description: Worst Chinese food. Over priced. And they will help you add the 20% tips secretly(party of 3). Be sure not to double tip.
author: Wenqian W.

description: I'd have to agree with most that the food is subpar. Got suckered in by the coupon. I think it could have  earned more stars if the service wasn't so shi**y! Example: we were trying to box up our leftovers (large amount) and the waitress refused to give us more than 2 boxes. And the plastic bag she gave us had a white sauce at the bottom; obviously used. Will check Yelp reviews before deciding my next meal in Chinatown. Smh.
author: Yael G.

description:
They include the tip in your bill. I don't have a problem tipping but the menu states that grat is only included for parties of 5 or more, and they put a 15% for me and my girlfriend. Obviously after that we didn't leave anything extra and because of that we received a long and obvious glare from our server after he stared directly at out check. I'm a waiter and I would never pull that move. 

BEST CHINESE FOOD IN SF IS ON IRVING STREET
author: Taylor L.

description: 0 stars, no choice for ZERO star!!!! Do not enter this place! You have been warned! Do not follow the old chicks on the street!!! Everything is overcharged at this joint. They have automatic 15% tip no matter how many people are with you. On top of the automatic tip, they will try to get more tip on top of their tip. And their "on the house" potstickers are not on the house!!! Look at your receipt!!! Their meals are for midgets and your gonna end up paying for MR. T
author: Mary Ann A.

description: This was the worst experience of my life. First they wouldn't just give me a glass of water. The food was not the best and they gave a major attitude when we wanted to split the check. Do yourself a favor and skip it. Very terrible service.
author: Danielle W.

description:
I came to SF from Denver to visit family a few years ago and we came to this restaurant while visiting the city.  We had about 12 people in our party so we did one of the family style menus and passed everything around.  Every single dish we got was good, but the Kung Pao Chicken BLEW MY MIND!  I'd never tried it anywhere before, but I've since tried it in several restaurants here in Denver and I've yet to find its equal.  

This past July, we made another trip out to SF and I insisted we stop here again.  I've often found that the second time I try the same dish at a restaurant it fails to meet my expectations because either the memory of it got blown of of proportion or the restaurant just isn't that consistent.  Not the case here:  the Kung Pao Chicken was just as good as I remembered it!  

Seriously, if I ever see a good deal on airfare, I would fly from Denver to SF for the day just to go to this restaurant.  I don't know what all the low ratings are about.
author: Sarah H.

description: **Warning** this place has to be shut down ASAP. I would give no stars but that's not a choice. We got pulled in by one of the flyer ladies outside so decided to try it out. Servers wore rude we ordered long story short there were FRUIT FLIES in our food! We told the waitress and rudely accused US  for putting them in there for a "free meal" I never been through this in my life!  She told us we had to pay for the whole meal We didn't even eat any of it! She also said she was going to call the police I said call them but then she threw us out when We started getting loud. We walked out disgusted and grossed out! if you look at more reviews there are tons of them having the same issue with the fruit flies. No one eat here!
author: Stavos L.

description:
It's not the best place to get Dim Sum and like many Yelpers have stated, there's a reason why they pass out flyers on every corner and try to lure you with their free potsticker promotion.

It's definitely a touristy place and they do a fine job grabbing people off the street, since I am currently writing this review ... but to be honest my dad didn't remember which Dim Sum place he wanted to go to and was too hungry to care anymore.

First con right off the bat: there are literally 2 flights of stairs, I mean you're probably sitting there thinking "So what if there's stairs you walked all uphill in Chinatown to get to the darn place!" To be honest, if you have elders with you or children, this may pose as a challenge for them.

Second con: the service is slow, not entirely of course sometimes our food came quick sometimes slow. At times however, as the upstairs room filled up it seemed like they were trying to rush us out of there.

For the food I believe it was "A-OK" the dim sum was not served in carts but picked off the menu, we got the usual: hargow, shu mai, chicken feet, multiple orders of shrimp rice noodle and fried taro cake. We also got fried rice to fill in the rest of our hungry bellies. Nothing particularly wow'ed me. You also get comp. fortune cookies and green tea ice cream which really isn't that great, plus it comes in a styrofoam cup. Talk about not being environmentally friendly.

Pro: It's really not that dirty, which I can appreciate. If you take a look at pictures from the various Dim Sum places located in Chinatown you can clearly see this place is on a higher CLEAN level. There's no stray hairs, roaches or bleach bottles in/or near their food.

Well better luck next time. Go elsewhere, you've been warned.
author: Janet N.

description:
Standing in the street in Chinatown and how do you choose which of the hundred of places to choose from??  We watched where the Chinese people were going and ignored the "hawkers" on the street trying to tempt you into their places.

Three of us ordered the Dim Sum special and one is vegan and she was prepared a special plate for her.  Everything was really well made, served hot, and the service was good.

I was surprised by the low ratings, it's not that bad - I would go back.
author: Liz T.

description: Thought the food was a little over priced for lunch but the seafood fried rice was good. Not a huge fan of Chinese food though so I probably shouldn't be rating it. The place seemed a little on the dirty side but it is also very old.
author: Shanna V.

description:
I came here after wanting to go to House of Nanking and not wanting to wait an hour to sit down.  I got lured into "China Town Restaurant" by a free potsticker appetizer and green tea ice cream.  When I was finally seated, it took 15 minutes for the waitress to come to my table (it was a party of one) and take my order.  Except when I tried to order what I wanted to eat I got a "no food, drink only" yell from her.  Thinking someone else would take my food order I thought that was somewhat reasonable at the time.  When she came back 5 minutes later with my tea, she took my food order.

Food is nothing special and "OK" at best.  For a $15 appetizer that was small/medium in proportion I was very dissatisfied with the food.  A small bowl of rice is $2- even that tasted pretty shitty.  My bill arrived and found a charge for $3.25 to my bill.  When I asked the waitress what that was for she said "tip."  WTF?! Charging for a TIP?  I have not heard of this in my entire life (unless the party size was 6+)

I will NEVER return here and strongly urge you to stay far far away from here.  Serves me right for checking out a random spot without checking Yelp first.
author: Natan O.

description: Please double check when you pay the bill, the will overcharge you and add mandatory 18% t
author: Ping W.

description: Food was good, but I never heard of automatic tip calculation for two people. 20% was calculated on top of the drinks and tax.  Food $30, drinks $3, tax $3, additional tips $6.6?!?!  For ripping me off, I would never eat here again or recommend this place to anyone.
author: Tim T.

description: OVERPRICE and FOOD IS COLD !!! For example Iced tea $3, i ordered  beef fried noodle, come out the food smell not fresh, the beef is COLD and the noodle warm. And be careful when u got the check, you should really pay attention on the bottom !!! They put tip automatically
author: Mid W.

description:
If you are that much of a ham & egger tourist to come here and expect an amazing Chinese food experience, please stop writing reviews.
