description: We made the mistake of eating here last night.  The food was not good. Some of it was too salty to eat. They give you a coupon for free dumplings and green tree ice cream on the street. It was pricey and not authentic at all. Don't waste your time. I wish we would have read the reviews before falling for this tourist trap. The best thing about this place was the ice cream.
author: Aaron L.

description: ATTN!! please read it al!!  Not worth a freaking star at all!!!!, Delete it off YELP!!, , Run, U-Turn, Whatever you do, "Do Not Enter!".Worst place i have ever, ever eatin, & i love food!!!.....Free potstickers, yea right, its on your bill!!. They flag you down on street, walk you to resturant, rush you in to sit you at a table then there gone,  waitress are super rude, just cuz you ask to repeat what there saying, they will bring you individual order then charge you family order, food was cold in certsin areas of noodle, then they microwave it, lol, we heard them put it in, & even told us thats what they do!!, no flavor in food, .. then it gets worse, please, please contine reading... we argued the fact of them even trying to charge me for the tip that is put on your bill, i demanded not to pay for my cold microwave food & tip, they got very rude, with there language while talking to me in chinese, so i started telling them back in spanish, lol, keep reading!, then when i was pay my bill they bring this green tea ice cream and there just looking, when i notice roach legs in it, oh they got it from me, when we started telling guest about it, then people that were trying to sit, were like Hell No!! They turned and started leaving and then there s reaming at them for not wanting to eat there, lol, it keeps going, .. so i left with my wife and friends, well stupid me, i left my cell phone at the table, came back to get it, well it was not there, and they said they never saw it, and boy who clean the table and was waiter & server & cook was on break, well he comes back and says he dont have it , and there just trying to ignore me, well i start calling police and then they start looking for it, Oh wow, how they found it really quick, and my phone was even put on silence and airplane mode, phew tired of reading, sorry, but you have to know, """ THIS PLACE SUCKS, SUCKS , SUCKS, SUUUUCCCKKKKS, SO RUUUUNNNNNNNNNNNN!
author: Steven S.

description: DO NOT EAT HERE; here's the deal. I will rarely say this about any restaurant I go to, but I hate this place with a passion. Here are my reasons: the wait is insanely long, the prices are absurd, and the food was OK. My family and I had been walking all day and were starving, so having to wait 10 minutes for someone to at least order our drinks and another 40 minutes for them to bring our food did not settle well with my family. After they finally brought the food we realized how small all the portions were, and we ordered family size! The food wasn't even hot, it was warm as if it had sitting for sometime. When we were finally done the check came out to $81.55!! I was insanely pissed at my entire experience here and will never be back.
author: Amanda C.

description: I wish I had read all the reviews before I ate here. I really liked the soup, as did my wife, we ordered (some sort of shrimp, seafood broth). Ordered shrimp fried rice and house special  (chicken and pork) rice which was tasty. We also ordered two orders if shrimp dim sum. As I said the food was tasty but I did not realize they added a tip to the bill. It came to $78 and I left an additional $15 as a tip. Problem was that the bill was written in Chinese so I did not realize what I was paying for.  That's on me this time, next time I will question every entry on the bill. Would have rated higher if it wasn't for the tip scam.
author: John K.

description: We ordered 3 meals. 2 arrived lukewarm, 3rd arrived about 20 minutes later. We asked for the original meals to be reheated, they were barely room temp when they brought them back 10 minutes later. We were told we'd get extra pot stickers..we got 2. They also add a tip to your bill without asking. If I could give negative stars, I would.
author: Mary Jo S.

description:
The good: They did not give any issues about having a service dog, which can often prove difficult at restaurants.

The bad: Food came out at a decent pace, was no where near the best food that can be found in this neighborhood. I have a feeling there was a lot of MSG going on. Very underwhelmed with their 'dim sum' offerings. Gummy shrimp dumplings, bland steam bums.

The ugly: We initially ordered two items on their dim sum menu and after we informed the waitress that was all, she yelled at her coworker who sat us at the table and slammed down the menus.  We asked multiple times for our food as well as water. When they brought us the check, they had already calculated the 15% tip and argued over the actual cost of the food. 

Overall, NOT WORTH IT. There are a lot of other places that are probably more authentic and provide better service.
author: Kimberly M.

description: I went to this restaurant with high expectations being in China Town. The food was sub par, panda express would have been better and cheaper. The service was slow and I felt like I was being ignored. The restrooms need a good cleaning.  There are many other restaurants in China Town that have much better food.
author: David M.

description: If you are reading this... Do not pay attention to all the negative reviews... You have to come here and experience on your own... Personally I loved it... The fried rice and the noodles special were dope... The Fortune cookie was Hella good and the ice cream was great... Hope you get the guts to have your own experiences in life...
author: sindy d.

description: Worst service and unethical practices. What a rip off! We were expecting spend around 20 bucks like in any other place in chinatown, but we ended up there because we got some flyers on the street. First the waitress throw the straws at me in a rude way. Later, we wanted just an appetizer and a entree and the waitress asked what type of rice I wanted with that and she said, fried or white? I said fried, the she asked if we wanted wanton soup and I asked how big it was and she said not too big, one cup for each. She made it seem like these items were side orders, like normally are in any other place but when we got the bill, we got charge $50.00!!!! are you kidding me? 9 bucks for soup and another 10 for fried rice? Ridiculous. I don't tend to complaint but this place does not deserve customers. Don't make the same mistake!
author: Zarela V.

description: Food was really good, we had sweet and sour chicken, sesame chicken , Kung pao chicken and noodles everything was delicious! service was really good too, everyone was friendly and fast. They even let us take our little dog with us and we sat outside, no other  restaurant would do that. View from the little balcony was beautiful. I don't know why other people wrote bad reviews but I definitely recommend this place. The only thing I have to say is that they add 20% for tips which is fine if you consider the good service. They even served as complimentary entrees and ice cream .
author: Tonia I.

description: Awful restaurant. Went in because it is close to the Hilton nearby where we stayed but it turned out to be one of the worst restaurants I've been to in my life. The chicken still had large pieces of fat. The staff was horribly rude. A star is generous.
author: Mar C.

description: DON'T GO!! Total scam of a place .. They convince you to come in off the street with a coupon for a free appetizer. The coupon is not honored because of some fine print which makes no sense.. Food is terrible and dry and tasteless .. Servers are rude .. Plus they add a tip!! What?!! I left spending  way too much $$ and feeling very angry .Avoid this place at all costs ..
author: Jessica W.

description: ZERO STARS. I live next door and this restaurant's menu-pushers shove their crap in my face, sometimes literally touching me, between 3 and 10 times a day. They block every intersection, corner, and crosswalk trying to bully naive tourists into eating at their shitty restaurant. The place itself smells like death. People get food poisoning all the time. There are plenty of good places to eat nearby (Lucky Creation, any of the dumpling places on Kearny), so stay as far away from Chinatown Restaurant and its menu-hawkers as you can.
author: Alex S.

description: I actually liked this place. My expectations were low walking into this joint! The girls advertising on the corner is what brought me in, then when I went up stairs to the dining room it is exactly what I wanted when visiting Chinatown! There was quite a huge demographic of people.. So I went with my instincts! You must try the Hong Kong Crispy Noodles! Those were my absolute favorite! Along side with the hot tea! Yum! I wished I lived here or I will be back! The added the tip for you, but who cares anyway..?
author: Sofia C.

description: This place was deceptive, well over-priced, poor service with waiters that looked very unpleasant, and the food was not even fresh (tasted like it was frozen and then microwaved). Mainly for tourists. Don't be deceived by the people sitting outside upstairs, only for parties of two and they likely will say there is no more room. STAY AWAY!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Note: my actual score is 3 and a half stars out of 5. The app wouldn't let me do half-stars though.

Ok, so my friend, girlfriend and I were exploring Chinatown and eventually we were hungry. As soon as we said aloud "Were should we eat around here?", a Chinese woman appears in front of us, from the street corner, hands us a coupon then points to the place at the end of the block. Intrigued, we decided to follow her directions.

Once we found the place a minute later, the staff inside further instructed us "Come in. Go upstairs." Their tone was a tad pushy, but since we had gone this far, we figured we might as well go all the way.

We arrive on the second floor, and are immediately seated. The spacing between tables was a little cramped, but not insufferable. The decor, a bit rustic, with many antiques spread around for that "Chinese Ambiance". The music was modernist electronic reinterpretations of traditional Chinese themes (that was pretty legit). The place was full of patrons, but it was Dinner time, so that should be expected.

We sat, looked at our menus, and a waitress immediately arrives, takes our drink order and suggested we do one of the group specials, something along the lines of getting 4 family sized entrees and 2 sides plus soup/tea and dessert for 11.95 per person (this meal was originally intended for four people). We went for it. And the food arrived quickly.

The food comes sequencially, of tea, soup, spring rolls, pot stickers, pork fried rice, chicken chow mein, beef and broccoli and sweet and sour pork, then an ounce of green tea ice cream for dessert (though the miniscule amount made it more of a pallet-cleanser than a proper dessert, but considering the large amount of food we received prior, it wasn't entirely necessary that the serving size be that large).

The food itself was pretty much standard Chinese Food (just imagine any chinese food you've had that wasn't Panda Express, and that about summarizes the food here), though the Sweet and Sour Pork was awesome. The crust on the pork was light and crisp, as if it were wrapped in the crust of a fresh spring roll, then covered in sauce, which was bright and flavorful. And the rice had a decent range of flavor, but was kinda soft.

The check eventually arrives and the bill for the amount of food we received was kinda low, which was a plus, although that doesn't take into account the other factors of the overall dining experience you have to deal with to recieve/enjoy the food. 

Although, there was something on the bill that caused confusion amongst our group: the amount of tip suggested had been written out and highlighted on our bill. We did the math and it was 15% of our bill, which is standard, however we as a group got into a brief discussion weighing the pros and cons of this action.

On the one hand, it took the guess work out of our payment assesment. On the other hand, it took away the implied freedom to tip as we saw fit for a job well done or half-assed (we thought the service was adequate). Since we are a "go-with-the-flow" type of group, we just paid it as requested, since it was fair enough, but I'm sure this little suggestion they have may irk other customers who aren't as pleased by their services.

We eventually left, full and more or less satisfied. I was quite surprised to see the amount of bad reviews this place had received. In my experience, it was all adequate, marred slightly by mildly pushy sales tatics and mostly good, but not great, food. The environment seemed authentic enough for me, though others may not be as charmed. 

My advice: stay and drink with the fellas, or order the sweet and sour pork to go, and go to the nearby park to eat. The outdoors of San Francisco are lovely in the evening.
author: Tony O.

description: Service was poor. Took 5 minutes to order than 10 minutes to get a beer. Brought a Corona with a lemon in it! Food was mediocre at best, fried rice was good.
author: Bill L.

description:
We ordered the smoked tea duck and black bean spare ribs.  Very bad.  

When we got our checks, noticed a scribbling on the bottom, with a charge.  The waitress said it was a suggested tip.  When our credit card payment agreement arrived, the "suggested tip" was included in the bill total, and an additional line for a tip was included.  When asked about the discrepancy, the explanation was that it was "punched in wrong".  

This place is a tourist trap of the worst kind.  Be careful.
author: Darryl W.

description:
I had the misfortune of going here, without checking on yelp. We were seated by the balcony with an open door. It was very breezy and cold.
The food service was slow and wrong food appeared. The food was very greasy. The Kung pao chicken was slimy , but the mongolian beef was ok. Had to repeatedly ask for water. 
The check came and they suggested a tip amount, even though the service was so so.
They would not honor a coupon handed in the street for free dumpling and ice cream since it came with our meal--no discount either. A bit of false advertising. 
Slip this place. Bad value for your money.
author: V K.

description:
Food was pretty good and the service was excellent.  But what made this place extra special was being seated on the fire escape.  

It was there that we enjoyed a cup of tea and great views of Chinatown and the Financial District.  Definitely a must go, if only for that experience!
author: Franco L.

description:
Wife &I went there the first time last night. Bad mistake.  Service was terrible and so were the food. We ordered Hunan Pork, HongKong Chow Mein, and a bowl of plain congee. The bill came to $ 52 with 15% tip already add on.  
Plain congee was $ 9.95 and was not listed in the menu. Very dishonest people. The place was not clean and the wait staff were rude by any standard.
I saw a couple of old time pictures (not about the restaurant) hanging on the staircase wall. If the original restaurant has indeed been there for  almost a hundred years, It must have been changed a few hands during that time.
A restaurant/tourist trap like that cannot possibly lasts that long.
author: Joe S.

description: Lured in by their decoration. Dish priced way too high for the amount and qualify.  Their Szechuan cold rice noodle appetizer was priced at $9.50! As a girl from Szechuan , it was my first time seeing the rice noodle and source came in two separate bowls...... We orders spicy and boiling fish fillet. Never seen any bowl smaller like theirs used for this famous e dish. The noodle bowl in my house is even larger than that. And finally, they charged a 20% gratuity for a group of 4 adults and 1 kid. If you don't take a close look at the hand written bill, you will not likely to realize it since most of the restaurant will only include the gratuity in bill if a grp of 6. Overall, the restaurant is no good at all for selling so-so food in such a high price with an enforced gratuity. Never will go back again.
author: Bei F.

description: Place is pricey as hell. $17 for Mongolian beef?! $12 for kung pao chicken?! Like WTH ITS CHINATOWN!!! I COULD TOTALLY HAVE BOUGHT THIS ELSEWHERE FOR LESS THAN HALF THE PRICE. the only rain we came was because my mom won these two $10 "gift cards" we decided to use them... Big mistake! They charge 18% gratuity on each dish... OH AND THE BOX IF FOOD WAS PRACTICALLY EMPTY. Disappointing prize...
author: Kristina L.

description:
Food has no taste.  Waitstaff is great.  Pick another place to eat.
Seriously - the ice tea is terrible.  Order a coke and you ask for ice you get 2 inches of ice.
The only thing that was good was the free ice cream they give you with a fortune cookie when they bring you the bill.    I recommend you find another place to eat.  By the way the bathrooms are on the first floor by entrance and downstairs in the lower level.  They are so dirty and dusty I recommend you use the restroom before you go into eat.
author: Mike M.

description: Worst dining experience Ive ever had. The food was disgusting and the customer service was an absolute nightmare. They tried to rip us off numerous times then tried to force us to pay a tip after all the bullshit we endured. WHAT A JOKE!
author: Sarah B.

description: This is a tourist trap, but isn't most of Chinatown?  This place serves very Americanized Chinese food.  All the stuff you are used to eating, without having to worry about what's  actually in the dish.  Had the best Sweet & Sour Pork and Crispy Hong Kong noodles dishes I've ever had.  Skip the Egg Foo Young, too many large raw onions in it.  The free potstickers and green tea ice cream were a great bonus.  I will be recommending this place to friends.
author: Julie C.

description: Meals taste bad. The people who work there have bad attitudes. The place has flies. The oil is overuse. Never come again, not recommend my friends to go there.
author: Stella Z.

description:
Well.. Unfortunately for my fried and I, we didn't check yelp before going in.

One star for free green tea ice cream as dessert, and one star for validated parking.


The problem is that these people are extremely unorganized. The food took forever to come to our table, and as SOON AS WE WERE SEATED, THE WAITRESS BROUGHT OUR DESSERT AND CHECK. We must have waited damn near an hour for some dumplings and potstickers. The food was alright but definitely not worth the wait. Food was cold when we received it...  The food is not exceptionally cheap, so I don't understand why anyone would EVER plan on coming back.  Luckily, no upset stomach.
author: Neek W.

description:
I have to say first off that i absolutely love ChinaTown in San Francisco. I grew up in the Bay Area and was visiting on vacation with my boyfriend when we entered the infamous Chinatown. Since we visited during the beginning times of the year of the dragon celebration is was HUGE!!! We had so much fun watching the fire crackers and dragon parades....and then we got solicited by some women on the corner to eat at this restaurant. We figured why not, let's try something new and be adventurous, and because they gave us coupons for a free order of potstickers and looked like they had great combo deals for groups. 

Let me just say this, and I'll say this once.....just save your money, time, and taste buds for the grimier places across the street, which are probably a whole lot better than what you'd get at the Chinatown Restaurant. 

There's a reason this place only has 1.5 stars with almost 200 reviews.....because its worthy of its rating. We went in and promptly went to the second floor where the restaurant is located. We were sat, but solidly left alone with menus for 20 minutes in a near empty room. We finally got our servers attention and she scoffed and took drink orders and asked us if we were ready to order. To make is simple we just got the 15.95 combo per person and they send us a bunch different plates and a dessert.

Not only did we not get almost 3 or the items listed on the combo that we ordered, but when we asked about them all they told us was that "I check" and then well...nothing. So we waited some more and continued to get the same answer and still....nothing. The dishes finally arrived 20 minutes after the beginning of our meal and we were set for the bill. After finally flagging the server down we got a hold of our bill where we discovered she charged us extra for the items that we were supposed to receive, but didn't. 

Enough Said? This place was a headache. I'll definitely be back to eat in Chinatown, but not here, had I had my phone on my I would have trusted the reviews of my fellow yelpers and stayed far away from The Chinatown Restaurant....Don't be fooled...this place is gnarly gross, overpriced, and the service is by far some of the worst
author: Alex M.

description: The waitresses were so pushy, the food was underwhelming and the bill was priced higher than what it said on the menu they gave. That was the most disappointing meal in my entire life.
author: C C.

description: It is one of the worst place i have been to, the service is so bad, and the cost was terrible for the stuff i ate. When i went into the restaurant, me and my friend was waiting for hours to order. Then when i ask for a cup of ice water,they gave me a bottle of water,which cost me more. then all the food cost 44 dollars and the beverage cost 5 dollars for a cup of orange juice and a bottle of water. However they added 9.8 dollars for NOTHING, we did not even order anything else. It came out to be 64.10 dollar we gave 71.10 dollars by accident and they NEVER gave us the change back. WORST PLACE EVER, NEVER EVER GO THERE EVER AGIAN, THIS PLACE SUCKS.
author: Becky C.

description: DO NOT ENTER IT!!! I'm serious! Eat here is like paying a high price for Panda Express. Very bad and low quality food. Price is unclear and additional tip is high. At lease Panda Express's price is reasonable. It's really not a wise choice to eat here.
author: Ariel H.

description: Meh. Touristy. The place is clean. The food is pretty bland though.
author: Mark D.

description: Terrible food, terrible service, terrible prices with gratuity included. The only upside is that we got to take selfies on the balcony.
author: Cec D.

description: It's not that bad.  It's cheap Chinese food.  What do you expect?
author: Feras H.

description:
First off: TOURISTS BEWARE!!!

If I could give this place less than one star, I would! We were seated on a balcony which we had to enter through a window. Okay, it was a little charming being able to watch the city below but the dangers of being at a table on a 4 ft wide windowsill under a sign with birds on it are far too high for my liking. 

The staff was slow and super pushy. I explained twice that I wanted tap water but they still delivered and charged me $5 for a 16oz bottle. When we ordered our lunch (usually one appetizer and an entree between my boyfriend and I since we are lighter eaters) and the woman kept trying to tack on extra things... "skewer", "egg roll", "pot sticker". We kept politely declining as we had already ordered everything we wanted. Twenty five minutes later they bring our food. The chef "special" fried rice was bland and the pork in it had a vinegar-ish sourness to it. The Kung pow chicken was pretty good, however... So I guess my one star can be for that. 

As we were finishing our food we over-heard the people behind us asking for a manager. They had placed an appetizer order 5 or so minutes before we ordered and their lunch about 10 minutes after we ordered. Their appetizers never came and once they were done with lunch and got their check they had still been charged for them. When they said they were full and no longer wanted them the manager said they had to take them anyway and she would have the cook make them now. "We don't want them anymore, we are full and our tour bus leaves in 30 minutes" the lady said. The manager replies "no changes once order is placed, we make it now and you will take it with you". Their check also showed that the man ordered 5 Imported beers at $7 each instead of 1 Budweiser at $3. After arguing for 5 or so minutes, they removed the other beers. 

As my boyfriend and I were talking to them (the tables are very close) our waitress delivered our check. He laid down his card and she asked if he would like to leave a tip on the card for a minimal $1.25 fee. WHAT?! A fee to leave a tip? They must not like tips then. Needless to say, we said no... That we prefer to tip in cash. She asked "so, no tip on card?". Again, we said "no, we will leave cash". She returns with the bill and she had run his card for $5 more than the bill originally was. Wait a minute, what's THIS now? She replies "that's my tip". Oh hell no! This place is RIDICULOUS! Although, it's actually pretty funny because we had a $7 tip on the table which my boyfriend  promptly picked up and said "this WAS your tip" and put it in his pocket. She jipped herself!

It's plain to see, they're only in business to rob people. Watch your credit card statement and eat down the road. You can get a better product from honest people for 1/3 the price less than 100 ft away. Don't fall for their silly flyers and coupons. It's just a scam.
author: Sarah F.

description:
All I really have to say is disgusting...

Not even a real dim sum restaurant and the food is greasy as a mother f*****

They gave me and my friends coupons for free potstickers, but it only applied to their over MSG used entrees


never going back here!
author: -Johnson- N.

description:
This is the worst restaurant I have ever experienced. They charge you $5 on white rice which tastes dry and hard. The plate price on bill is higher than what is shown on menu, really be careful about it! Lastly, they added 15% tip on you. If you don't read the bill carefully, you might not even notice that!!
I don't know why it could still be there... the government should really close it out!
author: Mary J.

description:
I have never been motivated to write a Yelp review of a restaurant.  Until now.
I have spent a lot of time in San Francisco, but this was my sons' first time, so I unfortunately relied on some guidebook's insistence that this restaurant is a must.  It should have read "must not."
After we sat down and had gotten comfortable, the main waitress/manager herded us to another table, saying it was better for us.  It was tiny, and obviously better only for them to free up a larger table.  We ordered water for our sons and two beers for us.  The waitress argued with us, saying that we should get bottled, not tap, water for our sons.  When we insisted on tap water, she stomped off, obviously miffed.  The beers came without glasses.  After only a couple of sips, the waitress came over and asked whether we wanted more beer.  We told her no; we only wanted one each.  She then approached us repeatedly -- at least four more times -- urging us to order more beer, even though we kept reminding her that we didn't want any more.  When we placed our order, she also tried to persuade us to get fried, not white rice.  We were firm that we wanted only white rice.  
The "free" potstickers were cold and almost inedible.  Our food came one dish at a time, with long gaps between each dish, and the white rice we ordered did not appear until we had finished our meals.  After we had eaten two of our dishes, the waitress plunked down a dish of fried rice on our table.  We immediately told her to send it back, as we had not ordered it.  This caused a big commotion.  She called the manager over, and they insisted we had ordered the fried rice.  We refused to eat it, and they finally took it away.
After about 45 minutes of this long "one dish at a time" ordeal, I asked them to bring my sons more water.  The waitress asked, "Still or sparkling?"  I said I wanted them to have more tap water.  She raised her voice, and exclaimed, "What? You would give tap water to children?  It's not healthy!"  At this point, people at several tables were staring at us.  I am certain that she has used this ploy to embarrass other parents into buying overpriced bottled water for their kids, when tap water is perfectly fine.  Needless to say, I insisted on tap water, which finally arrived about 15 minutes later.
The bill was written all in Chinese characters.  My husband reviewed it, and asked the waitress about what appeared to be a double charge.  She said we were being charged for two orders of Lo Mein.  He told her that we had only ordered one (which was true) and in fact, it came at the end of our meal (with the white rice) and we had barely touched it.  She called the manager over.  The manager insisted that we had ordered, received and eaten two orders of Lo Mein.  She literally screamed at us, "I saw it with my own two eyes!"  Again, everyone in the place was staring at us.  I have traveled all over the world and eaten in many, many restaurants.  I have never been treated so shabbily.  I calmly said that as we had not ordered or eaten it, we would not pay for it.  
After a few minutes, the manager came over and slapped the bill on our table, announcing that she had taken off the charge for one of the Lo Meins, as if she had done us a favor.  My husband then noticed that they place a "service charge" of 18% on the bill -- on the total with taxes.  Nowhere on the menu or elsewhere did it say that a service charge would be included.  We did not fall for their attempt to trick us into leaving a double tip.
Oh, and the food?  Barely passable.  Never again.
author: Deborah P.

description:
Beware.... Do not eat here! Over priced and food is not authentic whatsoever, even if it's right smack in the middle of china town. This place looks filthy, customer service sucks, even the entry ways for the waitresses to deliver food again, sucks! I mean who the he'll would want to eat with waitresses walking in and out of the window/door with a big bang. So annoying! I locked this doorway multiple times to avoid my kids from walking out to the balcony where it is clearly unsafe as it was obvious there were other optional doorways, however the waitresses would not budge. 

As far as the food, let me clarify why it SUCKS! The chow mein was made with fettucini pasta noodles. Okay? The seafood soup had nothing but tons of tofu with a bland water based broth. The mongolian beef was sitting on a bed of stale fried white noodles. How horrible is that? Their rice also seemed to be sitting around for too long. It was all that nasty with a capital NAST-y. I can not believe this place is still in business. 

All in all, I know this is so cliche but if I could give this place a zero it would be sooooo worth the frustration.
author: Myhanh B.

description:
This place is the KING of tourist traps, and my friends and I fell for it.  FACEPALM.  

I really should have known better.  We managed to resist the street-corner coupon hustlers for a while, but when we couldn't find another decent-looking food joint open that late at night, we found ourselves walking back to where we had started, and that's when they went for the kill.  Three of them surrounded us and practically begged us to enter.  One of them was a little old lady.  It was a pretty chilly night.  I felt pathetic and helpless.

Alright, I told my friends.  These people worked so hard to earn just a few more customers.  And I'm freaking hungry.  Might as well.  What's the harm?

But as soon as we climbed the stairs and entered the dining area, I knew we had made a mistake.  The sea of WHITE PEOPLE!  Something you never want to see at a Chinese restaurant!  NOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!

Needless to say, the food was not too good.  It wasn't outrageously horrid enough to warrant a one-star rating and vehement reviews, but it was definitely below mediocre level.  Greasy, salty, generic.

Then, we got the bill.  DOUBLY SUCKERED!
author: Alice C.

description: Meh. We ordered the dim sum sampler. It was nothing special. I wouldn't return here again. Don't be lured in by hawkers on the street.
author: Jane J.

description: Worst restaurant ever!! The waitress are fu3king rude! They add unreasonable charges into our bill. Their food are bad, but are more expensive than other place. We have 5 people and they charge for $26 for tip, that's really unreasonable!
author: Celia P.

description: Beware!!! They add tips to your bill!  I thought that was too funny!  Food was okay, not anything exceptional that would make me say oooooh I will certainly back HOWEVER this is the second time of coming back here.  I just didn't remember until I asked the lady if their restaurant was on the second floor and as I was walking in that's when the déjà vu hit me.
author: May Y.

description: We were coaxed in to this restaurant by the free pot sticker coupon from a lady on the street . The food was OK but I expected better especially being in Chinatown. We had the salt and pepper calamari, pork bun, snow pea leaves, shrimp balls, sweet and sour chicken. The prices were a bit high for the dishes and they also added the tip automatically. I don't think we will be back here the next time we are in SF.
author: Jose A.

description: After reading the reviews I was hesitant to eat here. Employees are very pushy starting with the lady down the street handing out the coupons. Meal wasn't horrible but wasn't good. Place was dirty.
author: Francesca M.

description: Overpriced food. Very small portions. Very oily food that doesn't taste very good. We ate downstairs and the place was freezing, and they didn't want to close the doors. Terrible service too. They forgot about us.
author: Hector C.

description:
We've been here twice and enjoyed it very much.

Food was fresh and very tasty, not heavy.
Service was good, even while Saturday night slam. Both our experiences were with eight to ten people so there was a wide variety of dishes to enjoy. Every dish seemed to be as good or better than the last. We hope to get back there next time we're in California,  its becoming a tradition.

Im puzzled by other less flattering reviews; we are experienced asian cuisine fans and are able to differentiate mediocre from good. Chinatown has been very hood to us!

Try it yourself. ;-)
author: Robert B.

description: The food is good and made fresh. the only negative thing I would say about this place is, the restaurant is upstairs and the restrooms are downstairs. Also, they add their own tip no matter how many is in your party and when you charge it to your visa, it ask for more tip. so be aware that tip is already added so you don't double tip.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Not good at all.  Food is oily, not fresh.  Decor and carpet are old.  Felt gloomy sitting inside.  Service is ok though.

Tourists: walk one more block to Jackson Street, many WAY BETTER choices there for Chinese food.  Great Eastern is my best choice!
author: Portia C.

description:
Yuck, yuck, yuck!!!

There's three girls that walk the surrounding blks of the restaurant trying to get customers into their store--almost like the girls at a red light district.
This place had really appetizing pics of their food outside and multiple worker outside trying their hardest to convince you to go inside.  
We had a bad feeling already but a weak backbone after a day of walking and sightseeing.
Big mistake.
The food was horrible.  Not authentic at all, and far from good American chinese food.  This is the kind of place that gives chinese food a bad name.  Even the green tea ice cream was fake!  Artificially flavored foam cream! yuck, yuck, yuck!
author: Hannah C.

description: My friend got suckered into coming to this place because of a lady outside easily pointed this place out. I mean, they could be more creative with the restaurant's name. Anyways, the food was awful, service even worse. The decor was boring, and the options limited. We didn't come for dim sum, nor would we have wanted to. It mentioned that Leo DiCaprio ate here once, probably when he was a nobody, because I can't imagine any celebrity would come here. Avoid unless desperate.
author: Phan H.

description: It was fine, but nothing special. I can get better Chinese food in my home town. There are far better places in China Town.  They should put more effort into food and service and less into the corner people trying to heard you into this place.
author: Jim E.

description:
Trust the low reviews here on yelp.  

My girlfriend and I went here for dinner and were disgusted and embarrassed with the high prices, rude service and hidden surprise charges.

We ordered 3 dishes, tea and coke and were given a bill for $74.50. Our dishes were not exotic, Snow Peas and Shrimp, Sweet and Sour Pork and House Chow Mien.

$12.00 average per dish but the hidden charge was $10.00 for all you can drink soda and $10.00 for the the rice and $5.00 for the tea.

Then the real surprise, a 25% tip added to the bill.

I was saddened to see so many tourist in this restaurant look at their meal bill with surprise, but kindly pay the bill.

A a Chinese American, I am embarrassed by this practice.  This is not representative of the Chinese culture and Chinatown.

This restaurant disgustingly takes advantage of the trusting good people of the world who travel to San Francisco Chinatown to experience a new culture .

There are many good restaurants in Chinatown, but some restaurants are starting the same cheating practice.

Some advise for an enjoyable visit to Chinatown.  Ask for all prices upfront and enjoy the exotic food of China.

Stay away from Chinatown Restaurant and their street pushers.  You will be glad you did.
author: Sarah C.

description: I'm shocked by the low amount of stars Chinatown Restaurant received on Yelp!  I dined here on December 14, 2013 and had a wonderful dining experience.  I tried four other places in Chinatown during my trip and thought this place was better than all of them.  This wasn't he best restaurant I've ever been to but it certainly wasn't bad.  The food was good, prices were cheap and service was just fine.  Worth a visit.
author: Bobby M.

description:
OK, let me start! I love coming to Chinatown b/c the food there is normally reasonably priced and it's great b/c I am a poor college student. After driving 2 hours from Santa Cruz to get some good dim sum, I came here.

The hostess lady told me they were giving away free samples and I was smitten with good hospitality (supposedly). 2 dishes later with my friend, we were charged a CRAZY amount for a $25 meal!

I SAY, AVOID THIS DISGUSTINGLY DISHONEST RESTAURANT @ ALL COST!

DIRTY EATING ENVIRONMENT, POOR FOOD QUALITY, & RIP-OFF PRICING from OWNERS!

BEWARE AT ALL COSTS and EAT ELSEWHERE!!!!! 


0 Stars if possible.
author: Tram D.

description: God this place is as bad as advertised. Food, service both extremely awful. The only reason I'm giving this place one star at all is because I got to sit on the balcony. Yippee. Don't let flyers suck you in, move on.
author: Peter N.

description: It's a tourist trap so don't even bother. They usually have one or two waitresses standing outside who would convince you to come in by showing pictures of their food. Picture looks okay but check out the prices!  Way too overpriced for Chinatown! Go two more blocks up, hang a right on Stockton where all the yummy dimsum and bakeries are at. Got my fix at Good Mong Kok. It's the one with the long line outside :)
author: Ritz B.

description:
I had the Braised Mushrooms and tofu.  I thought it was pretty darn good.  The place isn't sexy at all.  and yes, they did seem disorganized.  My husband had a shrimp dish that was pretty darn good too.
I asked some of the people in the lobby how their food was and everyone I asked said they were very pleased.
I guess you just have to go on a good day... according to some of the reviews.

I say try your luck and see.
author: Kris J.

description: Got rip off. Felt violated and why would servers argue with the customer with what they order. Don't be fooled by the flier. Paid for the lunch special for 5. No where on the menu states is was $15 a person.
author: Rich S.

description:
I can't be that different from all the other Yelpers!  

I've been coming to this place for 10 years and I have never had a nasty experience.  The service at this place is quick and friendly.  Are people mistaking poor English skills for being rude?  That's not very fair.  The food in this place is top notch... NOT THE BEST... but top notch.  The prices are the same here as most sit down Chinese joints in San Francisco.

Now, the building is rough.  It's definitely not your expertly built high rise or trendy yup yup restaurant, but that's part of the Chinatown feel.  Chinatown, like China itself, is an ancient place filled with many wonders.  If you keep an open mind and accept that sometimes things can't be perfect, I think you'll love this place too.
author: Nick M.

description:
=(
We were so hungry that we came here without checking Yelp!!! My bad!!! 
The food was the worst Chinese food I ever tasted...  
Only one advice for my fellow yelpers - Trust this review, Do not come here.
author: L. O.

description:
Went here on my birthday, food was okay. was very overpriced, definetly not worth it.

also, am I the only one who was there when they were blaring the loud communist party music?
author: Stevie D.

description: I wish I'd consulted Yelp before eating here. What a WASTE of our only night in Chinatown. Terrible, slow service even though they weren't busy. Brought soup at same time as entree. Duck was cold and had to send it back to be warmed. No type of sauce.  Boring. Chicken with vegetables was marginally better. Definitely do not recommend eating here.
author: Karen W.

description:
Decent place for a group for lunch. The outdoor balcony was fun on my first trip. The prices for the quantity of food you get on the group lunch deal is excellent. The service we experienced was quick and friendly. We even were allowed to use the coupon for free wontons and ice cream with the special, so I'm not sure what others are talking about when they say they had a bad experience regarding the coupon.

Not the best, but if everything else is busy it's a decent little place for a quick lunch.
author: Melissa O.

description: If you walk in with no expectation you won't be disappointed. We were really hungry and just as others were pulled in by the flyer. My friend really liked the idea of having dim sum so we did the dim sum sampler and added the chow mein dish for $3.95. The food came quickly and it was ok in taste. Unfortunately they didn't clear anything out so we kept piling our dishes. Also no one refilled our drinks. The place was packed so service definitely needs work.
author: Vicky R.

description:
Like many, I fell into this tourist trap after failing to find a good spot in Chinatown. I was essentially funneled into this place by the female workers passing out flyers for free pot-stickers with an order of the entree. 

The food was the standard oily stuff that I can find in a white takeout box, but instead presented on a white platter. The price for one entree here is about the price of a 3 item combo at any Chinese fast food joint, which hurt even worse when I realized that I couldn't go against my morals and not tip their rather slow service (that failed to even bring me any water). Next time I know better to do my homework first.
author: Jon T.

description:
Like many posters here, we were lured into the Chinatown Restaurant by coupon wielding females hard selling us on the Dim Sum that was served.  We were entertaining some out of town guests and were looking for restaurant at the time so decided to give it a shot.

First off, we climb the stairs to see a number of other "white" people standing in line, somewhat nervously joking about the hard sell them brought them in.  We had a table of 8 and were seated ahead of everyone else in line - this is how they earned the single star.  Everything else is downhill from here.

It took 10 minutes before anyone even came to our table to acknowledge our existence.  One we did order, our first dish came out 20 minutes later!  It was a dumpling dish that was meh.  The wait staff was harsh, abrasive unhappy people.  Most of the dishes tasted like reheated leftovers or microwaved, previously frozen crap that probably should have been thrown out. Terrible, terrible terrible.

When the check came, they had already included the tip!! What a racket.  We are done and ready to leave by the time our last dish showed (room temperature chowmein).  We paid, however on the way out, a woman sitting in the waiting area asks us if was worth the wait, to which we replied no, run like hell to another restaurant.

Food: bleh
Service: terrible
Ambience: sketchy
Value: horrendous

Steer clear, my friends.  This place should be shut down, IMO.
author: Cory S.

description: We got pulled in off the street to come here and we were feeling adventurous. The service was HORRIBLE. The staff was very rude and even shuffled around people who were already dining there to accommodate more customers. It was confusing why they were so eager to stay full but tarred the people who we're trying to eat like shit. I'll never go here again and I really hope you take my review seriously. Should be 0 stars.
author: B B.

description: They have girls outside passing coupons out to get customers into there restaurant's if you order from the entrees you get free 5 pot stickers with not much sauce and green tea ice cream in a foam cup with a plastic spoon's staff was nice but this was the kicking I got the bill they had written the word tip in $6.00 I have a big problem with someone telling me what to pay....so when she came to get my card I kindly told her to take a dollar off the tip,she said I don't understand I held up my hand and said five dollars only another staff came to bring the receipt she was nice,takeing advantage? or rude?
author: Tommy M.

description: I mean, it had nice big tables that could accommodate large groups well.  It wasn't wildly expensive.  They had a pre set menu so I didn't have to choose things, which was nice.  It tasted like... chinese food?  Definitely not suggesting, but I didn't leave feeling bad...
author: Sarah C.

description:
Reading the other reviews of this place, made me think I was reading about somewhere different.

The place that we wanted to go to was closed at the time, so we decided to take advantage of the flyer that was handed to us on the street.

We were funneled upstairs (4 adults and 4 kids...two strollers...no elevators so those in a wheelchair, beware) and into a standard looking dinning room.

Please keep in mind, that if you are a fan of air conditioning, this place isn't for you!

The food was ok. Not great, but edible and I did not think it was as bad as some of the other reviewers are saying.

I would actually say some of it was pretty good!

Would I go back? not if I had any other option but it would certainly be preferable to nibbling off a body part, if I was hungry enough.
author: Dane C.

description: Nine of us are here last Monday during a trip to Chinatown, San Francisco.  We walked around quite a bit because most restaurants were closed at 4:00pm. We found this place using Yelp. As we were walking in, someone gave us a coupon to use in the restaurant. It was for free pot stickers, green tea ice cream and a discount on Peking duck. As we were ordering the waitress told us the duck discount was 30%. This made just a little more than the roast duck we were going to order.  When we confirmed the order, the waitress said it was 20%. We told her two of us heard 30%. She got rude and said no. We ordered the cheaper duck. We received the higher price duck when the food came. We had to ask twice for the pot stickers. When they came it was one small plate for the 9 of us. The food was very good but we feel like they were trying to mislead us and not honor the coupon. It was an unpleasant situation. If you don't go to Chinatown between 4:00 and 5:00pm, there are plenty of other places to eat. I would choose one.
author: Jim M.

description:
I went with my family (6 of us) into Chinatown.  There was staff standing outside the restaurant with coupons for "Free Pot-stickers & Green Tea Ice cream w/purchase of any entree," which promised NO MSG, and as my dad is allergic to MSG, we thought we would give it a try.

We were seated within 5-10 minutes.  The table has a large lazy susan in the center so that made it super easy to pass the different dishes around to all of us.  We ordered the combo special for 4-or-more.  It came with 4-5 dishes & desert for $11.95 per person.  However, since there was six of us, we ordered two additional appetizers & one additional entree.--AMAZINGLY GOOD food, large portions, great service - staff is super nice, even patiently taught us a few words of Chinese when we asked (yes, my parents are tourists).  The large pot of hot tea that I ordered stayed hot the entire time that we were there, even though she offered to refresh it, and it was only $3!!!

The only downside is the bathrooms are at the bottom of three flights of stairs.  However, it was very clean & smelled great too.

I am very happy with my experience and plan to go there again soon...
author: L B.

description: My onion pancake was okay, but the siu mai tasted like something out of the supermarket's frozen section. Add to that the extra looooong wait for these two little things. The ice cream while we waited was a nice touch, but it went downhill from there. Yes, we got suckered by the nice ladies handing out coupons on the corner--broke the rule-of-thumb right then and there.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I give it a one not because of the food or the service, but because of the rat. The service is a little slow, but has been pleasant. i just saw it as slow because of sitting outside. The food decent.

I've been here a few times. The food was ok and better than a lot of the other China town restaurants.  The only reason I have been more than once is to sit outside. It's the best part of the place... until... one night, I was outside with my friend and a rat joined us. Yep, it was popping in and out of corners. It freaked me out a little, but at least it was outside and not in (that I know of). I do know people who work in the food industry and there are rats everywhere. I will not go back because I prefer to not know where the rats are. There are a lot of fabulous places to eat at in the city. Honestly, as a person who lives close to chinatown, I think the majority of that whole area stinks and is probably where all the city rats are. It's the only area I have seen rats openly come out. 

You'd be better off sticking to a nice place in another part of town. If you are in the area and super hungry, just walk a few blocks to the financial district.
author: Kimber C.

description: The hot and sour soup was incredible! And the rest of the dim sum dishes were very tasty. The service was just ok- I had to ask for a glass of water three times after they only served the tea, but based on the food and the incredible view, I would definitely go back.
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Our group asked the table under name of our organizer, but we were directed to different tables and different floors. Some late people was told not table booked under the name. It took us a long time to find each other. Hope they could improve their service in the future.
author: snowwhite w.

description: To keep it short: our food came before our drinks, because they completely forgot our drinks, and we had to reorder because they had no record of what we ordered. The rice came last and the Shirley temple tasted like water.
author: Courtney W.

description: Not sure why the negative reviews.  The food was good and there was PLENTY of it.  As far as the staff?  They are Chinese! It's a culture thing, get over it.   If you have spent anytime in the East, it's not a rudeness issue, it's a overly polite and if they are not comfortable with the language, they are a bit standoffish out of embarrassment.  Get over it.  Nice place and I recommend it for dinner
author: Ken G.

description: The only reason I give it two stars is because they where pet friendly and allowed us to go in and sit with our Yorkie.  This was my second time here but never again as they tried to collect twice on the tip for 3 people.  I should have read the reviews, they do charge for water and even if you ask them for a second glass of iced tea.  Food was not so bad but make sure you check your bill because they do overcharge but if you want to be adventurous and not listen to these reviews my hat off to you.
author: Sandra A.

description: We were approached several times to visit the restaurant so we stopped by after shopping in Chinatown. We went with the Dim Sum platter and overall it was so so. The flavor on the steamed dishes were lacking. Maybe i should have went with a regular entree. I would have went with 2 stars but the Green Tea ice cream was real good. Ill skip this joint next time. Soany others to try that are near by.
author: Ray P.

description: My son and I visited this place last year (04/06/14) and I see that it hasn't changed.  We were kinda pressured into going into this place because it was late and we were hungry and the girl was persistent.  Anyway, it was hard to figure out what were getting in the end.  They definitely need people to explain who can speak clearly (and I'm not trying to be mean, but I'm keeping it real).  We had a pushy waitress, and though the food was alright, I've had better in my hometown.  The waitress ended up adding a tip for herself, which I to be honest, didn't know what to do about.  Needless to say, not going to visit again!
author: Al E.

description: We were practically chased down with a coupon flyer only to be completely ignored the majority of the time we dined. Our server even seemed hostile!  The food was decent but this is the first time I have EVER seriously considered NOT tipping.
author: Rachel S.

description:
We ordered the lemon chicken but instead they gave us lemon shrimp. Even though it was the wrong order the dish looked pretty darn good. I really enjoyed what I ate and loved sitting on the balcony with the view of China T\own and the Transamerica building. 

The food was very yummy but I can see what people were saying about being ripped off. The bill was way too overpriced for just two dishes of shrimp and steamed rice.
author: Rebecca R.

description:
Another Entertainment Book find.  We went there because of the coupon.  What a big mistake.  Lunch was very expensive for a greasy spoon.  Food was not good either!  

It's true, this place is a sweat shop and the owner is a jerk.  But alls wells, she got carted to jail for hiding her assets during a bankruptcy proceeding (can you say fraud?).  This is the same person that owned a sewing company that went belly up and owed the workers a lot of back pay.
author: Wendy H.

description: If I could give it zero stars I would.  I never felt so violated after eating at a restaurant.  My girlfriend and I decided to give it a try after our favorite restaurant was closed on Wednesdays.  After being accosted by some woman waving a menu in our face, we decided to give it a try as we were both starving.  A red flag should have gone up when she escorted us down the street to the restaurant and practically shoved us in the door.  They seated us outside basically on the roof and it felt very unsafe so we asked if we could be seated inside. Once inside we were given menus and realized that the prices on the menu which we were handed outside were far cheaper than the menu inside the restaurant.  My friend asked for a water and the waitress stated they didn't serve tap water.  She had to shell out $2 for a 12 ounce bottle of Arrowhead water.  Really?  If you want tea, it's $3.  She asked us on 3 different occasions if we wanted appetizers.  Apparently, she didn't understand what no meant.  I ordered the kung pao chicken and my friend ordered the kung pao tofu.  We both love spicy food but that wasn't even edible.  I knew as soon as it came it was way too spicy as it was red in color and had 15 chili peppers scattered on the plate - you know the ones you can't eat.  The waitress kept coming over and looking at our plates so I'm pretty sure it was intentional.  I'm also pretty sure she also thought we were tourists.  Then the bill comes.  We see a $7.49 charge on it and question it.  She tells us it's the tip they think they deserve.  Really?  I tell her to take it off an we will leave what we choose to leave.  Who does that?  Needless to say, we will never go back there again! We both wanted to bring the meals home so we could show our respective spouses.  Unfortunately the bags and containers they gave us had holes in them and well you know how that ended.  Gee I wonder if that was intentional.  Do yourself a favor and avoid this tourist trap at all costs!
author: Paul J.

description: I have never made a post on a restaurant, but I felt compelled to let everyone know that this is the biggest scam/rip off in all of San Fran. The food was garbage the service was rude then the check came and looked like I gave a pen to 5 year old and told them to write it out. Questioned the check and she made it out to be that I was stupid. Home of the 5 dollar bowl of white rice, seriously??? It's a trap!!! I would not go back if someone else was paying! TRAP! Been to better 5 dollar buffets!!!
author: Joe H.

description:
Horrible food! Yes they attack you with flyers and chatter. The food was so bad and unappetizing. I really regret coming here. It's pricy and small portions as compared to other Chinese restaurants I've had. We ordered Mongolian beef and orange chicken. The orange chicken was so disgusting. The batter tasted sweet as in donut flavor. Service was equally bad. 
I would never eat here again and really regret not looking on yelp prior to setting foot in this place. 
Please do yourself a favor and don't eat here. Unless you would like green tea ice cream as your complete dinner.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Horrible food, bad service and over priced.
Restaurant was packed until I noticed that there is not a single ASIAN in the restaurant!

I WONDER WHY!!!!!!
author: David N.

description: Total tourist trap! Avoid on principle - they change prices after you order then slap on gratuity without agreement- food okay but not worth the money-Panda Express for $50 for 2 people ...grrrr
author: Cynthia O.

description:
-Food quality-less than average
-horrible, horrible service
-staff has major attitude
-overpriced
-relatively small portions
-charge approx. 20% gratuity upfront which is ridiculous for the service they provide
-AVOID AT ALL COST!!!!!!!
author: Sanjiv G.

description:
Took a coupon from a lady on the street during the Autumn Moon Festival that offered free appetizers and green tea ice cream as the restaurant was celebrating 90 years in existence.  

They got us in quickly and seated us, and we noted no Chinese people eating the food, a bunch of tourists like ourswelves, but we pressed on anyway as we've had some extremely ethnic Chinese food in Chinatown before that defied our Western sensibilities of the palate so we elected to stay.  We ordered standard fare, Beef and Broccoli, Fried Rice, Chow Mein, etc. and the food was out fairly quickly.  We mentioned to our waitress that we ordered fried Won Tons and we didn't get them, probably because they changed servers right in the middle of our order and she retorted that she had read our order back to us and we didn't say anything about it then.  Okay, you win, we won't order any.  We thought this might affect the tip, but it was already included in the bill. We were pretty hungry coming in, and found the place to be a little pricy for the portion size, but it was apparant they are there to low ball the customer on food and service, take the tip automatically and probably don't care if you come back again as there's an airplane landing at the airport with the next round of victims on board.
author: T L.

description:
I opened a Yelp account for the sole purpose of expressing my views of this establishment. 

Part 1 - Food: The Bad
This was hands-down the worst chinese food I have ever tasted in my life. I have been served fresher and better prepared veggies at a buffet; their meat (and we order beef, chicken and swine) we either tasteless or reminded me of jerky and their prices are quite excessive for what you actually get. 

All of my party, native chinese people, agreed that their pork dumplings (which are supposed to be steamed in a manner that the buns contain soup) was largely inedible and tasted as though they were store bought from frozen. 

We essentially covered all of our food with chilli oil and soy sauce and called it a day. 

Yet this typically would only have caused me to say "oh well" and move on. 

Part 2 - Service: the Worse

When we first sat down, we were placed at our table by a server who immediately asked us what we would like to order. We said water and our plates, utensils etc... while we looked. I kid you note, she said we'll give you stuff when you order. When we did order and we kindly asked to keep our menus, she proceed to rip my literally from my hands. Unfortunately, this was not a language barrier issue as she proceeded to be rude to my entire party through the entire meal (woe be to us whom may want a second glass of water - the nerve of us) in two dialects of Chinese as well as English. Talk about an all encompassing experience. 

Part 3 - the Bill

The audacity of the restaurant came when we received our bill. A) they first charged us tax on our alcohol, added it to the grand total and then calculated a second tax based on the same - B) they automatically billed us (hidden inconspicuously under the tax) 15% post-tax for tips, FOR A PARTY OF 4! if we were 6+, 8+, I would understand that auto-tipping - further, at the very least if you ARE going to do this at least TELL US. There is no doubt the purpose of this - our neighboring tables unawares, tipped on top of the 
"total" which of course the waitress did not advise them of - you can be certain that we did and the patrons were none the more pleased than we were of the circumstances. 

In sum:
This restaurant says its a historic landmark since 1919 - I think it speaks volumes that nobody in 100 years has written a positive review about this place. Beware. Next time, I'd rather eat the paper currency itself then to set foot in this place.
author: David Z.

description:
I should have read the reviews for this place before accepting that blasted coupon from the lady on the street. REMEMBER TO LOOK AT YELP REVIEWS BEFORE YOU GO PLACES, PEOPLE.

The bestie and I were also lured in by a coupon offering free appetizers and green tea ice cream (how can you pass up free green tea ice cream?!) with purchase of any entree, and a cheerful woman on the street. We were verbally warned by another woman on the cross-street advertising for a different restaurant in Chinatown, but, sadly, chose to ignore her words of, "Expensive there!"

We went upstairs and were immediately greeted by the sight of NO CHINESE PEOPLE eating there. Should have been hint number one that something was up. We were seated somewhat promptly by a disgusted-sounding hostess (my Chinese is fluent, and just because I don't have a Mainland accent like you, doesn't mean you're better than me, thankyouverymuch, jerk), and after seeing the menu with nothing under $10/dish, and since we weren't really hungry, we chose one dish -  (a flattened green bean dish with preserved tofu). It took 5 minutes for a waitress/waiter to notice that we were ready to order, and when she came to take our order and coupon, she huffily notified us that we had to order one dish/person in order to get the free appetizer and ice cream. That's not what it said on the coupon, but fine, we really wanted free green tea ice cream and the potsticker appetizer, so we added another vegetarian noodle dish to the order, but specified that we wanted it with the Hong Kong style crispy noodles instead of regular chow mein noodles. 

The food took 20 minutes to come out, and while everyone else was getting their free potsticker appetizer, we sat with empty water cups. When we asked about where our free appetizer was, the waitress made a snooty comment about us ordering vegetarian dishes and that we wouldn't eat the meat potstickers. That was just frustrating, but we clarified we just like eating vegetables (not mentioning that the vegetarian dishes were the only ones that were less than $15/dish) and would happily eat the potstickers. So they brought out the potstickers for us and, no surprise, they were 4 little Ling Ling potstickers from Costco. 

Anyway, 25 minutes later our food finally came out, and the green bean dish was not even made the way it was supposed to have been made. It didn't taste bad, though, but it was overly salted with those salty black beans. The vegetarian noodle dish was actually quite delicious - noodles were crispy and vegetables were cooked pretty well with a full flavor - but the bill at the end was the most irritating. Our bean dish was priced at $9.95, and the vegetarian chow mein was also priced at $9.95 on the menu. BUT when the bill came, it showed that our vegetarian chow mein was priced at $14.95 (SAME PRICE AS THE DUCK HONG KONG STYLE NOODLE DISH) simply for the change of noodle! AND they probably figured people would never tip them for the crap service they offer there anyway, so they had the audacity to AUTOMATICALLY INCLUDE TIP IN THE BILL - FOR TWO PEOPLE. 

Saddest thing: THE GREEN TEA ICE CREAM TASTED NOTHING LIKE GREEN TEA. ):

I was tempted not to sign the merchant credit card receipt. 

DON'T BE FOOLED BY THOSE CHEERY WOMEN HANDING OUT FLIERS ADVERTISING FREE CRAP ON THE STREETS, PEOPLE. Make sure you Yelp the places you go! Sigh. 

Oh, they also supposedly offer free wifi, but it was password protected, and none of the waiters/waitresses ever look at you while you're there, so it's impossible to even order food or get there attention, much less get a wifi password.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Horrible!  Should have known better since they need hawkers on the street to push people into the place.

Service was poor but the food was even worse.  A few Dim Sum items which were tasteless and kung pao chicken which was equally bland and disappointing.
author: Randy W.

description:
I don't understand all the bad reviews of this place.  This place is perfect if you are entertaining someone from out of town and they want to have Chinese food in Chinatown.  I don't think many SF residents really eat Chinese food in Chinatown, so if you have to entertain and help your tourist friends check this box, this can be a tough call.  You want to go someplace that's right in the heart of Chinatown, that seems authentic without having a pig's head in the window, clean, not too upscale but not a hole in the wall.  I think Chinatown Restaurant delivers.  

Ambience.  Probably the best part about this place is the ambience.  I was thinking of going to R&G based on Yelp reviews, but then when I walked in and checked it out, it had no charm at all - I don't even consider that Chinatown, I consider it FiDi or North Beach.  If I want Chinatown I want someplace on Washington or Jackson or Stockton or Grant, crammed in the middle of the street with all the action.  This place is right on Wash & Grant.  Also, I think it's cute that you get to climb upstairs.  The outdoor tables were great and the inside area is clean and nice, too.  Also, I don't know what folks are talking about, b/c every time I go,1/2 the patrons are Chinese.  All of the folks in R&G were white. I think very few places in Chinatown meet that middle ground of being authentic looking but presentable, and this is one of those places.  

Food.  First of all, I think Chinese food is kinda like pizza, not sure I've ever had a truly "bad" version of it.  We got the family prix fixe share thing for $15 a piece.  The food was not absolutely scrumptious, appetizers like the chicken skewers were bland, but the potstickers were great, springrolls were good, and all of the main dishes including the lemongrass chicken, shrimp fried rice, sweet and sour pork and some kind of beef dish were quite good, hard to mess up these dishes, and they didn't.  The green tea ice cream is not real ice cream, it's some kind of synthetic substance, but nice flavor and since it's free, I can't complain.  Also, the beer selection is nice and the flavored soju was the star of the evening b/c they bring it out in a tall carafe/dispenser that looks like an oil and vinegar bottle which you can share with the table; it's quite fun and delicious.

Price.  There were 4 of us and the total was $130.  We were delighted that the tip was included.  Unless you are a cheapskate and were planning to jip the waitstaff, you should not have too much of a problem w/ a 15% tip being included, although they should notify you of this policy ahead of time, and there should be an opt out option if the service was bad, which ours was not.  So, we walked away with $33 a piece, which is a bit expensive for Chinese food, but not ridiculous, and we did all drink, as well.

Service.  No complaints.  Drinks took awhile and bill took awhile, but they were busy that night and our conversation at our table was good so no real issue.  The food came out very quickly.

Coupons.  I've never heard of people complaining about coupons.  If you don't like them, don't use them.

Anyway, if I didn't have people around I needed to entertain, I would probably just go to Sam Wo or House of Nanking or U Lee over on Wash & Hyde.  But to entertain tourist guests who feel they must have Chinese food in Chinatown, Chinatown Restaurant fits the bill quite well.
author: Ginger R.

description:
This place is an abomination of Chinese food and Chinese dim-sum.  I live in the middle of the desert (Tucson, AZ) where acceptable food is very hard to come by, and the dim sum in Tucson is far better tasting than the "food" that I ate here. 

This was my first visit to San Francisco, and I was really disappointed after my experience eating here.  On top of that, we paid $50 for "food" for 2 people (no drinks, we only drank water), it was outrageous.  There was hardly enough "food" on the table to justify even half that price.  I estimate I could have gotten approx. twice as much dim-sum for about 1/3 the price in Tucson (and it's better tasting here, which is insane).

Lesson learned -- if you're dining in an ethnic restaurant that's not crowded with ethnic diners, then you're getting ripped off.  (There wasn't a single Chinese person in the entire restaurant, despite the fact that it was completely filled).

Lesson #2 learned -- learn how to say "no."  If someone is pushing you into selling their product without giving you the time/energy to think and make a decision, then you're being robbed.

Do yourself a favor and never come here.  I hope this place goes out of business soon.
author: Erica M.

description: My fiance and I wanted Dim Sum. We try to go somewhere different every anniversary trip we take to the city- this one was completely awful. I wish I had read all the reviews before going to eat. We also were basically pushed into the restaraunt by the girls advertising for them on the corner and the fact that the Dim Sum place thath had been referred to us (Eastern something...) was SUPER busy. I wish we had just waited. The Dim Sum did not taste fresh, nor was there any real flavor and the pricing was ridiculous. No Dim Sum carts that were going around the room either, which was a disappointment.  I see a lot of food poisoning/getting sick stories here. Do yourself a favor and do not go here.
author: Jenn L.

description: I can't stress enough for one to stay away from here! I curry chicken was dry, the lettuce wraps were too saucy, and then tried to complain and they tell you "there isn't a manager and instead of a $6 auto gratuity, I can just add $3?! Really???!!! As if I would leave anything! The food is awful and the service was just as bad. Tourists...walk further and get a better meal elsewhere!!!!!
author: Charley B.

description:
Husband's Review:

They trick you.  They have single dish prices and they charge you that price per person.  The food isn't that good.  The service is bad.  They're impatient with what you want.

Wife's Review:

Boy, am I glad to see an average of a two-star  rating for this restaurant.  I have to say that I am very, very, very disappointed with this restaurant that mocks to be professional.  They make it all fancy, dandy, but there is absolute no quality to their service and food.  I felt so cheated that I wanted to scream at their face.  

I think they get their business from tourists who would probably never ever get a  chance to go back or don't know how the heck Chinese food taste like.  I should have followed my instinct to know not to eat at a restaurant that has waitresses standing on the street corners trying to get business.  

They don't deserve a 15% tip, but they add it on for you anyway!  Oh, their single shark fin soup tasted so bland (just water) and looked like toilet water.  There hardly was any shark fin.  The shark fin was one piece. The single bowl was close to $8.  

The Thai Style chicken wrap was the only thing I like from that restaurant (they charged us double on this one and the serve looked like a single serving.)  They have some very old photos of the first few waves of Chinese, so that's a bit of historical atmosphere.

We had to wait a long time to get our check, and they didn't give us the discount.  Of course, we had to ask for it.  I think they are trying to bank of people who don't check the bill.  

We wanted to eat light, so we didn't order much.  The check came out to over 50$.  &*@#$!

I'm getting more pissed off at this restaurant after reading the rest of the reviews.  

For this stinky experience, we're getting a Blackberry.
author: Joelle C.

description: AVOID this place if you want your order right. Not only did my order arrive wrong and a long wait but the table next to me also got the wrong order. Run by a bunch of idiot kids more interested in chatting in the kitchen than getting the orders right. I even brought it to the attention of the waiter and of course no English. I should go over to China and open a place and serve them with bad and wrong service. Not all San Fran places are like you might hear for food quality. Not this place for sure.
author: Mark K.

description: This is probably one of the worst restaurants we've ever eaten at. We paid a ridiculous amount for 9 people and still left hungry. I was furious. Completely over charged for the family style dinner. Never will I recommend this place to anybody.
author: Teresa O.

description: We arrived in town late and hungry. The place we were looking for was closed. We decided to walk around China Town to see what was open. This restaurant  had a huge lit up menu out front and it looked OK.  The actual restaurant was on the second floor, but the music was very pleasant and the vintage photos with captions were interesting.  The service was prompt (it was close to closing) and the waiter was helpful. We shared the steamed sea bass in garlic sauce and a huge plate of steamed vegetables. The food was excellent, well worth the price we paid.  We would definitely be back.
author: Harry A.

description:
I sincerely recommend that you avoid going here at all costs. 

Common sense would say that any restaurant that feels the need to pass out coupons and fliers on the streets of the city is probably a place that you should not bother with. I really should have thought about that prior.

The service we received: Terrible. Rude. Painfully Slow. Attitude-ridden. (And no, the restaurant wasn't busy so there was absolutely no excuse.)
- We waited 20 minutes after being seated for our waitress to even stop by the table. 
- We asked for separate checks for our small group of people and were flat out told "No, absolutely not."
- When we finally did start to place our order, our waitress walked away from the table in the middle of us ordering, no warning from her or anything. She just walked off as if we weren't talking.
- While waiting for her to return for take two of placing our order, we had random servers bring us THREE entrees THREE separate times, each time ending in us telling the guy we didn't order that - or anything yet for that matter.
- After placing our drink order, we waited 15 minutes and still had no water. 

I never leave restaurants due to terrible service; I'll typically just remain patient and wait it out. But for the first time in all of my dining experiences, simply tolerating the annoyances was just not an option so we got up and left. Being that I can't speak for the quality of the food, I must say that the other Yelpers do a fine job of describing the lack of quality enough to have made me incredibly glad that I did in fact leave prior to eating. Considering the extent of service we received, I would fully expect the food to be lacking in quality as well, so I trust the judgment of other reviewers.
author: Heather V.

description: We agreed to eat here when street hustled because we needed a bathroom.    Avoid this place. The food is bland and greasy at best.  The service was ok but they refused to honor their own coupon that they enticed us in with.  So sad that we wasted a vacation meal in chintown on bad chinese. :{
author: Neil O.

description: This was the worse Chinese food I have ever had. First of all the service was crap, the waitress was horrible everything would ask for something she would remind us that we had to leave a "nice" tips! We only got two entrees and a side and it was over $80, and that's because they had the guts to charge us for tap water and she was including $20 of tips!!!!! I was really upset with this restaurant we didn't give a tip. My husband is usually very nice on tips but for her to point out that's how much she wanted in tips we got really upset! And it wasn't like she was a good or anything! Secondly the food was horrible it was cold, and flavorless. I advise you not to go here! There is more restaurants in Chinatown!
author: Alondra G.

description: Food was okay but there is much better available nearby. Service was a bit slow too. Note: only got dim sum and cannot speak for entrees.
author: Alex H.

description:
Seriously......
We finished 1 course in 2 min... So little food.. The fish taste not fresh. Should have checked the review before come... 1main course and 1 side dish cost 48. Really really regret it.
author: Paul S.

description: horrible!!!!!!!! do NOT go here. the food is extremely overpriced and not good in any way. Seriously people. also they are very rushed and won't let you see the check.. this is because they add a tip and don't want you to know. If the food was decent this wouldn't be a problem but it was literally horrible.
author: Tea F.

description:
