I tipped her personally becuz I don't think she'll get a dime if I left the tips on the table for the Witch to collect.

Witch came after waiting for a long time, and spoke English, "yes, what happen?" I told her, we asked you if this is a soup and you said yes. But this bowl is full of hot chili oil. She said, yes, this is how its made. Its Szechuan food, you never eat Szechuan before? I said no. And she laughed at me and said, you're Chinese and never eat Szechuan before with a smirk. So I said, we specifically asked you if this is a soup and this ain't no soup, its a bowl of fat chili oil! I told her I want that item cancel off my bill. She said, I can only exchange to another item, that's our policy. So I said, what policy, show me, you don't have that written anywhere and you didn't tell me before I ordered, and you have false advertisement. I don't want to order any more disgusting fat chili oil food. 

We also ordered the chicken appetizer, and beef tendon. Both used the same greasy chili oil with slices of cucumber, but again, the flyer picture showed a bed of rice noodles under the mouth watering chicken, false advertisement again!!! We were skeptical about the weird Chinese name, "mouth spit chicken", should have known better by that name!!! I'm such a sucker!!! I guess the last laugh's on me!!!!
author: Lp L.

description:
THEY RIP OFF THEIR DINERS! DO NOT EAT THERE!

I'm an SF native who  went there today for a bite and found that  they're ripping off tourists. 
They change a service fee of 15%  no matter how many people actually ate there,  then add 15% tip. 
The whole bill in in chinese so you cant read what the f*#( it says. They tried it with me too, charging over $65 for a lunch for 2 people!  I  finally put 2 and 2 together about the couple sitting next to me who got ripped off  none of the staff said anything or explained the bill. 
 They were not pleased at all when I called them on it, they were nearly yelling at me.
 they charge $2 each for tea that you dont order.
The food is passable but they're pulling fast one's on all the diners who go there- and it's only all tourists.
author: Tasha A.

description:
Mediocre food, slightly high prices, tourist trap restaurant.  Regarding service, I didn't experience any rudeness, but I can see how this could happen.  The service is "rough-around-the-edges", but they seemed well meaning.

The cuisine itself was unspectacular and slightly expensive.  If you're expecting stellar food, you've come to the wrong place.  I'll skip this place next time I'm in town.
author: Parris B.

description:
Alright, So I'm hearing a lot about bad service and sometimes dodgy food quality.  I'll say that these are both valid critiques from the times I've been here, but I will say that people seem to be a little on the whiny side.  This place has solid positive elements, as well.

The service isn't exactly "bad", at least from what I've experienced, it's "brisk".  They're running a restaurant and you're a customer and not a guest, and you're made to feel that way.  When I ordered food both times I came here some dishes were hot, some were lukewarm, it took more than a while to get water.  Also, it isn't particularly cheap, though it's acceptable.  On the plus side, they got the order right, so they only lose one star for the service and price.

As far as the food quality goes, I'm no expert on dim sum, I'm a total white devil, so this may be as Americanized as Panda Express for all I know (not to say that it tastes like Panda Express, this is much better, don't worry).  My yardstick for measuring whether the food is good isn't based on a word like "authentic" (because I don't know what authentic would taste like, cause I've never been to China nor dated a Chinese girl who cooked for me), my yardsticks are "tasty" and "not poisonous" (because I can tell if I enjoyed the food and I can tell if it made me sick).  This food is tasty and not poisonous.  I've gone for combinations both times (one the combo lunch and one the dim sum sampler) and both times I was very happy with the variety and taste of the dishes offered.  It wasn't the best chinese food I've had, but it was on the top half of the list.  I don't need much more than that in my food experience.

The best part of the restaurant is by far the location and the existence of 2nd floor outdoor seating.  I'm willing to admit that my review may be somewhat more forgiving than I am generally inclined to write due to the fact that both times I went I sat out on the balcony and looked out on the Chinatown street as I ate.  I'm a sucker for a view and this place delivers that in spades.

All in all, this is a good place to take folks from out of town who don't really know any better and just who want a fun Chinatown experience (dim sum, view of Chinatown, rude service).  That being said, it may not be the best place to go and just get some food when you're in the area (my bet for that has got to be Sam Wo's, just a block away, cheaper and food is more consistent).
author: Matt R.

description:
I'm a native San Franciscan -- maybe that's one of the main differences to start with in my view of this restaurant - I'm guessing that most of these negative reviews were written by tourists.   I grew up in HK (ex-pat) in the 70's and while that doesn't "qualify" me as an expert, it sure gives me some frame of reference.  And if nothing else, the fascinating historical photographs of Chinese history in SF throughout the restaurant provide an introductory backdrop for what is about to arrive -- GOOD CHINESE FOOD!!  Tourists -- isn't this what you should be paying attention to?

And -- ironically, the fact that the staff IS so polite (I still don't understand these negative reviews on this topic) made me a little suspicious since a "good" Chinese restaurant should have rude waiters.  The food was great, yes I used the coupon, they gave me little takeaway containers of the AWESOME spicy garlic sauce that you can never find in regular grocery stores, etc.  We lacked for nothing.  Climbing the stairs?? This was a critique?  Wow, one flight, nothing excessive. Maybe the tourists aren't used to our SF hills.  

I guess most of these negative reviews were written by tourists and i guess where they have come from might serve chop suey or the like, it's the only reason I can think of as to why they thought the food didn't taste good. Sure it's not the DOWN HOME Chinese place, but for a place smack dab in the middle of touristy SF, this is more than a decent Chinese restaurant.  

Take heart, Chinatown restaurant, we liked you!!!
author: Marie D.

description:
The spring rolls were light and crispy. sesame rice balls were tasty  Entrees not so good. Kung pow chicken, house tender beef & fried rice were all garbage.

 I wish my phone was working so I could of avoided this china town disaster.
author: Mr B.

description:
To be fair it wasn't the best chinese food I've ever had BUT it was MUCH better than my mediocre expectations. It's true that a good rule of thumb is to stay away from restaurants whoring themselves on the street corner or giving away "free" pot stickers, but in this case, is was quite decent if you stick to a couple of ordering guidelines:

1) Stay away from buffet style entres like beef and brocoli or lo mein. Go for chef specials and other oddball dishes like the creamy shrimp or pepper beef. 

2) Order the combination meals, like "the good stuff for five". Here you're given tastes from all the higher end lower margin dishes. Total meal should be $10 to $20ish per. More than that you're probably going overboard.  

3) Have low expectations and be patient and you will be quite impressed. 

At the end of the day this place was far from the worst reviews I read on this site, even if it wasn't the best I've ever eaten at. No one on party got sick and I would certainly go back. So don't feel bad of you end up here.
author: Seth K.

description:
I am the BF of estimed Michelle H and i have to back her up on every front on this place. its horrendous. however, the porch is fun, kinda like a NOLA porch and we had great weather. and as she said, the experience was totally worth it because of the stories. next time i'd go just for a beer on the porch and skip the food. 

one hilarious post script. we were watching the tail end of the chinese new year parade at columbus and kearney in front of an indian restaurant when we noticed the couple that michelle mentioned who had also had terrible service at this restaurant. but oh golly, was the gal not looking too swell, not at all. in fact upon second glance, it became apparent that her fella was supporting her as she booted all over the sidewalk and in fact on the front door of this indian place. 

pretty soon, the poor indian owners appeared at the door with very disturbed looks on their faces. obviously a slow night was about to grind to a screeching halt as a result of the unsightly visitor leaving all her chinese food on their doorstep. eventually, the poor fella, who was now also covered in her boot, found some other poor fella to help him haul her off. i didn't see where they got to but i can only imagine that this was the beginning of the longest night in this fella's life; she told us that she was visiting from Gilroy...

the poor indians did their best to conceal the mess with a whole mess of newspapers on the ground. thank god it was a quiet night, as i was fearing a typical SF gust picking them up and depositing them in people's hair, boot and all. we were there for quite a while and i never saw anyone go into the restaurant, or out for that matter. 

yeah, chinatown restaurant sucks ass.
author: tommy p.

description:
Food was not very good.  I ordered the vegetable tempura and the batter was too doughy and pretty tasteless.  My husband had noodles and chicken...it was decent...but nothing too special.  The hot tea was not good.  No flavor whatsoever.  :(  I do have to say that the complimentary green tea ice cream was delish :)  

The restaurant was clean.  I felt safe eating there.  We were actually scared to go in because of how we were "recruited" on the street by very bold employees.  I guess you have to be forward if you want customers!  Good for them!  We would have never eaten there if they did not "recruit" us :)   Unfortunately we will probably never eat there again.
author: Lindsey K.

description:
Since its the Chinese New Year, my friend and I wanted to get some Chinese food after the parade.  We came across this place after a girl gave us a flyer, and it looked decent enough.  The wait wasn't too bad despite the crowds in Chinatown.  The hostess/waitress/cleaning lady seated us, and we sat around a bit.  The drink girl came, we placed our order, and then we sat.  And sat. And sat.  My friend got his food.  So I sat. And sat. And sat.  After asking, and waiting some more, my food finally arrived.  I downed my meal in a few minutes, and we sat for a while before getting the check.  We spent almost two hours there.

I give it two stars, since theses things do happen and they did give us $5 off for the wait.  However, the food wasn't that great, the service was terrible, and the drink girl never came back for refills despite sitting there for so long.
author: Jim C.

description:
I'm afraid that despite the amazing experience, this time I can't factor that into my rating. After having a few beers at Li Po's cave of wonders (and basketball we decided we'd better start looking for a place to eat before it got too late, and seeing as it was 9:30 and seeing as those nice ladies handing out fliers that we'd been handed earlier were still on the street and seeing as we were hungry, we gave it a shot.

The potstickers, egg drop soup and chow fun were all good, but it's kind of hard to mess up vegetable chow fun. The lemon chicken however was way too sweet. The chicken was good and not fatty at all, and while I didn't actually eat any, my friend said was cooked well. The sauce though tasted like ground up lemon pez mixed with goo. Blech.

And then we were subtly encouraged to finish up and go, but why stand on the street handing out fliers at 9:30 if you want people to be done by 10 when you close?

It was an all around good experience though. The staff was very friendly and sitting out on the balcony was perfect.
author: Kimberly C.

description: best chinese food ever, the prices are moderate, the service is very forward and lacks all common forms of customer service, but the food makes up for it.  Eating on the outdoor balcony was great for watching foot traffic.  i think people are extremely too critical of cultural restaurants, its definitely worth checking out.
author: Steven S.

description: Love the food and service here, I will bring my family there for Chinese New Year dinner!
author: Li Z.

description:
Worst restaurant I have been to! I went out for a day in the city with my friend and she had been to this place before and said it was pretty good so we decided to go in. From the beginning the lady who was downstairs was rude and just told us to go upstairs. Once at the top we were greeted in a rude manner again. The waitress holding stuff to deliver to a table grabbed two menus and just put them on a table without really saying much. My friend and I sat down, waited really long, we felt forgotten since we were kind of on a corner. 

Finally they came to take our drink order and i ordered ginger ale and she ordered punch NO ice. The lady come drops off the drink and her punch has ice and my ginger ale is a can of Safeway brand ginger ale (which they sold for $2) we both were really hungry and decided to order the lunch/dinner for two which came with a big variety of egg rolls, pot sticker, shrimp etc... we also decided to get chow mien. Our pot stickers were ser ved first and then the chow mein came both of which we both ate, it was definitely not the best that I have tasted but we both ate it. 

We continue to eat and at the top our our this bamboo container there was some white ball that seemed to have some sort of meat in the middle. My friend was brave and tasted it first and said she did not know what it was but that it was good. She then put it on her plate and proceeded to eat it. she was not even half way done eating and and she finds a HAIR in the food, not even on top but INSIDE. At this point we were both grossed out and told the waitress which did not know what to say so she called someone else. That lady who seemed to be the manager was just like Oh where is it, tells my friend to put it on the table very rudely and then says its just hair, we are have it, it happens..... we were both looked at each other like wow did she really just say that?!!! They took it back and came back with a new order of those things and we both decided we would like eat those again so we moved that off the top to eat the stuff under it. 

My friend then grabs an egg roll and we start to eat again, on the table there is bottle of sweet and sour sauce and she pours some on her plate, takes a bite of her egg roll and pours more sauce on the plate where she then notices a FLY in the sauce! At this point we are all fed up with this place and call the lady over again and AGAIN she tries to say oh well there are flies around because it has been so hot lately and it probably went through the opening at the top. We then said this is the second this we find in our food and we do not want this food anymore! We told her to take it and that we would only pay for the drinks and chowmein which we finished. She did not seem very happy and just picked up all the food and and left. After a long time of waiting we finally got our check and the total was $10 just for the drinks and reduced price of the chow mein since it was ordered with the special. I put a $20 bill to pay for it and the girls just said Thank you and walked away. We thought she was going to keep the change as her tip and so we waiting until she looked and saw that we were still there waiting, she then came back with the change and we left. We both decided to NEVER go back to that place again! 

-THE SERVICE SUCKS! 
- THE FOOD SUCKS! 
- WE FOUND HAIR AND FLIES IN OUR FOOD! 
- ORDER WAS NOT GIVEN CORRECTLY 
-OVERPRICED 
-THE LONG WAIT FOR THINGS WAS UNACCEPTABLE 

I will NEVER go back to this place again and I recommend no one else does either! 

p.s I gave it one star but it does not even deserve that!
author: Gardenia T.

description:
haha, the reviews of this place make me chuckle.  i've never seen such unified loathing of a restaurant.  for myself, i'll say, yeah, this wasn't exactly the best chinese food, but didn't make me recoil in disgust.  like many others, i was touring around san fran, and popped into the first place i saw that didn't look terrible.  zero research before hand. 

the dim sum menu is very limited, so i wouldn't recommend coming here if you're into that.  also, there is an amazing lack of vegetables on their menu.  we got some steamed pork buns.  you can skip those.  actually skip all the dumplings/buns on the menu.  the house special beef wasn't bad.  a little sweet for my taste, but definitely edible.  the complementary green tea ice cream you get if you happen to be brandishing one of their ubiquitous fliers is really bad.  skip it, and just eat the fortune cookie on top.  

the prices (i thought) were pretty fair.  yeah, they charge you for tea.  i'd never been charged for tea at a chinese restaurant before, but we were in the heart of tourist area.  still it was only like $15 per person for a hefty amount of food.  plenty for left-overs if we hadn't been staying at a hotel, sans refrigerator and microwave.  

overall...yeah, no need to go back here, but certainly not worth the freak-out reviews it's received.
author: Rachel H.

description:
As long as I have lived in San Francisco, I have always thought there is NO WAY a bad Chinese restaurant could survive.  

BUZZ!!!!  Thank you for playing.  Feasting on the lost innocence of tourists,  I have been proven wrong.  Bad food AND expensive?  What a bonus meal that was.

Really, can't even begin to explain how disappointing this was.  We only chose it because I wanted to try something different as we walked around Chinatown.  In this case, trying new things is totally OVERRATED as is giving it even one star.

As we left, I couldn't even look the other Asians in the restaurant in the eye.  Oh the shame we all felt.  Bring on the ZERO star yelp gods!
author: Bruce R.

description:
We had gone to San Francisco and wanted to have dinner at Chinatown Restaurant. The restaurant was not very busy. But they made us wait a lot before taking the order and also serving the food. The sizzling rice soup was neither hot, nor sizzling. The Chef's special chow mein was not liked by my family. The only dish we liked was the Hong Kong style crispy noodles. It was quite tasty. And the green tea ice cream was nice too. But overall we felt we have had a lot better Chinese food at a cheaper price.
For food quality I would give it 2 stars. But for lack of service I give it 1 star.
author: Somnath M.

description:
Home of the Hard Sell
Chinatown Restaurant, according to their pamphlet has been in its current location for the past 87 years.   It's rare to see a restaurant stay in one place longer than a generation, at least in my opinion.
 
I have an idea of why they have been able to remain viable for so long. They have greeters walking up and down Washington Street who invite you in and provide you with a coupon for free pot stickers and 20% off an entree. They also boast Dim Sum from 10 AM to 10 PM.

The  Location
Great location. This is not too far from the BART. They catch anybody just getting into China Town or on the way down to the Hilton. They have a charming little park directly across the street from . This is a prime piece of real estate.

The Lay Out
My pals are afflicted with Tiny Bladder. We were seated on the second floor and the only patron restroom was on the first floor.  They weren't too thrilled to climb the steep stairs for that single purpose. The walls could use a paint job, not because it's old and peeling but because it is not an enticing color. I suggest changing from that shade of yellow to a nice golden color to really make the red accents pop.

The Service
It is definitely rushed and not particularly courteous. During the middle of our order the waitress walked away. Now, it is quite likely that she was once in used car sales.  She could definitely push a menu item. We got the Thai-Style Chicken Wrap.  My friend was extremely disappointed and said, "she made it sound like it was from heaven." I thought I saw a little tear escape from her eye during that lamentation. She was even more distraught after catching errors with our bill.

The Food
Chicken Feet -- Dry. Chewing off that skin was a chore. Ironically, so were the pot stickers!  I really enjoyed the apple. Although I didn't sample the Honey Spareribs my heart broken friend said they were great.  The pancake was nifty but a little to thick for my tastes.  The crystal chicken dumplings were okay. The spring rolls were about the same. 

Given its number of yelps with food critiques must I truly go further?

Reasons to go here:
A serious jones for free pot stickers and apples
A desire for green tea ice cream after your meal
author: Joanna B.

description: Visiting  from Anaheim, CA seen these lady's giving a flyer so we went in. Sat on the top outside (balcony) it was nice food was good not as bad as everyone says but I did not like the fact that they add 15% tip automatically a little over prices ,That's why I did not give 5 stars.
author: Marcas E.

description: I would have given this a one for sticky soy sauce and condiment bottles, but they did have a fairly big menu, and the food was ok - but not great.  It gets a two.  Best thing was the free potstickers and green tea ice cream. Watch out, the tip is included in the bill.
author: Paul S.

description:
My brother and I were in SF for about 2 hours and decided to head to Chinatown and have a snack before dinner. After exiting the parking garage, a lady stopped and inquired what we desired, we asked if they served Chinese porridge and she said yes. We were taken upstairs where there were mostly Caucasian patrons except for 1 large table of Asians.  

The 2 items we wanted were not on the menu she brought us, but the waitress was nice, she said they had the items and we said to ourselves how bad can they mess up porridge. 

What we ordered:
Rice Porridge - a consistency of soup broth, rice, a 1,000 year old egg and pork. Didn't ask for the pork, but very good.
No Mai Gai - Sticky rice wrapped in a tea leaf. Very small portion, but quite tasty.

When she brought the bill, it was quite a shock as it was $30 for a bowl of soup and a small pad of rice with meat, not more than 6 bites for a $30 bill.  

I feel what made this restaurant unique was their "Hot Chili Oil" base for the pot stickers. I normally do not like anything spicy or hot but this was the best I've had. When I get home, I'll try and recreate this item.

My suggestion to this restaurant, LOWER YOUR PRICE! What you get is not worth the price you're charging!

We did not experience any of the negative incidences that other reviewers had.
author: Anette H.

description:
I am sure my review will not change the number of stars this restaurant has gotten... but all I am going to say is that the food is phenomenal! All the seafood is excellent quality... I am super picky about smells and greasiness. The fish here does not smell at all and is SUPER GOOD.

The owner is really sweet as well and always up for making great recommendations. I would recommend this place for great chinese food!
author: Fee J.

description: Terrible. My wife and I travelled from out if state looking forward to a good authentic Chinatown meal. Well, I guess I let my hunger get the best of me. We were suckered in off the street from an employee pushing flyers, I should know better as I've travelled the world! Service was slow, food came out at different times and frankly the Chinese buffet by our house in Florida is better. As for the price I'd feel better paying the IRS more taxes... Enough said!
author: Joe T.

description: WOW! I can't believe all of the bad reviews! I recently went here as of the 24th of Sept 2010 to visit the San Francisco area and my girlfriend and i had a positive experience here! She ordered the sweet & sour chicken and i ordered the lemon chicken. Both dishes were amazing and we also got white rice. The sauces were amazing and the chicken itself was very flavorful and not too salty or anything like that. The waiting staff could've made more frequent trips to our table to check on us in my opinion (they only came to our table twice), but other than that it was fantastic! They also served us with free potstickers and green tea ice cream which was great! Neither of us are from the bay area, but we absolutely loved it!
author: James O.

description:
MY THOUGHTS ON THIS PLACE ... WHAT A CROCK OF SHIT!!

So,

     Like the rest of you,  my girlfriend and I were suckered in by the coupons!  Like the rest of you our dining experience sucked!  For what its worth I have some downtime at work, and was checking out some of the reviews on Yelp regarding this China Town Dump!  So heres our story...
      Since we originally wanted to go to Shanghai Dumpling King,  which we have been craving since we saw it on Check Please Bay Area,  we never had any intention of ending up at Chinatown Restaurant.  Turns out Shanghai Dumpling King was closed for vacation.  So Plan B was Red Jade,  as also seen on Check Please Bay Area.  But no,  I come up with the brilliant idea to go to Chinatown (district) and just wing it.  Play it by ear and see where we end up.  Well that lasted about 5 minutes from the parked car on Stockton st. to the intersection at Washington where we were harassed by these woman in red chinese dresses.  
        She rudely bumped my arm and said "You,  you hungry?"  Before I could answer she had multiplied into like four woman in red chinese dresses all ushering my girlfriend and I into this shit hole looking restaurant called Chinatown Restaurant.  Now the balcony looked nice,  but the emptiness of the place told me it was a real shit hole.  
        My girl looked at me and said,  "This place looks sketchy babe,  lets get outta here"  But before we could make our escape, the asian version of Hitler was hovering over us,  about to lead us to our table.  She then disappeared for a moment,  only to return, demanding our order.  I guess she was the owner or something.    My chicks face told the story.  It said " Babe, you stupid Italian man you!  You need to check yourself and get over the free coupon deal and believe me when I say, we need to get the F outta here,  NOW!!!"
        So I said,  "lets give em a chance, it may be good, come on...?"  As I'm saying this an older caucasian lady behind us began complaining to the waitress / owner that "Her chicken has got to be the most disgusting that she has ever had!"  I missed it but once we left my girl was like, "Babe,  you didn't hear her,  I wish you did!"  
        Anyway,   my girl who wanted to escape this torture chamber agreed to give it a try.  She was so shocked by the prices on the menu!  Being a filipina and eating asian cuisine 6 out of 7 days a week,  she knows this stuff.  Me being Italian / sicillian,  I don't.  But I had the whole what if approach...  Like what if it turns out to be good?  What if we really like it?  What if we want to return over and over again?
      Didn't think about the "What if we get ripped off?  Which we did.  $28 for an order of Mongolian Beef ($15.95 wtf?),  5 steamed pork dumplings,  and a side of white rice with a coke to drink?  Sure we got the free pot stickers,  which tasted like ka ka,   and the green tea ice cream,  but what happend to 20% off?  
      Oh I forgot,  many times during our meal my girl kept saying that we should of just left,  despite hitler and her troops of the ripper offers.
I said,  nah lets just try it,  we can't do that.  We it turns out we could of because we watched a shocked looking couple come in,  sit down,  Get sticker shocked,  and 2 minutes later walk out talking about "hell nah,  not happening"   Miss Hitler chasing her screaming "You no buy you no go!  YOU NO BUY YOU NO GO!!  HEY!!"  Hella funny!  So we should a left...

       So I give this review no stars.  But Yelp won't let me so I give it one star by default,  but again it deserves zero stars!  Place is a joke.  Food is blah blah.  I have had so much better for so much less,  and,  I did not have to be enticed or forced to eat there.   If your reading this,  take my advice and the advice of all users on here,  AVOID THIS DUMP AT ALL COSTS!
author: Steven S.

description: When I went to San Francisco by myself for the first time (this was three years ago), I was very confused and didn't know where I want to eat in the Chinatown area. While I was walking, there were two ladies passing coupons for a free desert at this place and I thought, "I'll just stop by here to eat". Little do I know is that this place does look "fancy" but my mind was suspicious, while I totally ignored. It was packed and the waitress seems to be nice at first but the service went downhill a bit. I ordered some Dim Sum and it took me around 25 minutes to get, which is very unusual in a restaurant and when I got the food.....a long story. I never had Dim Sum before but what they served is nothing like what the pictures say about. It was small in portions, looks bland and stale, and when I ate it, it lacks in flavor and taste and I was not happy with it. I am an avid Chinese food fan but this place isn't even authentic Chinese cuisine and most of the clientele were tourists being victims of this scam that I call it a "restaurant". Adding insult to injury is the price...nearly $16 for a small portion meal that did not satisfy my cravings and I regretted going into this place and wasting my money in this heap of a dump. My advice is to avoid this place and go to another Chinese restaurant or ask a local for a better restaurant so you will never be scammed and walking out broke. There are better options in Chinatown but this place is not and I mean NOT recommended.
author: Ramon R.

description:
Very good dim sum (especially the pork and shrimp dumplings), good lemon chicken, good pork chow mein, good pot stickers.

The chicken corn soup was horrible.

Waitresses were very nice, but ultimately this restaurant is a very overpriced tourist trap. The little hole-in-the-wall bakeries around Chinatown have better food for far less money.
author: Michael B.

description:
Boy, if I had read these reviews I would have stayed away from this place. And I would have missed out!!

My office was in town for MacWorld and during our trip to Chinatown we decided to go to the first place that handed us a flier. Well, Chinatown Restaurant was the winner!

The atmosphere is a little strange with the actual seating being upstairs and it does seem like you're in someone's house versus an actual restaurant. However, our waitress was very nice and the food was the best I've ever had. Really, it was! Of course, what does a guy from Cincinnati know about Chinese, right? But I liked it, and the rest of my group liked it, so it couldn't be too bad.

Big, family style portions and the green tea ice cream is a great way to finish the meal.

Give this place a chance, because it's not as bad as they say.

But..the bathroom is really scary, so avoid it if possible.
author: Lewis R.

description: This place has AMAZING food and pretty terrible service. We go anyway. The food is that good. We live in SF, and we take friends and family who are first timers to the city. I wouldn't recommend this place for anyone traveling with hungry children or who get low blood sugar (i.e., cranky) when they go too long without eating.... but if you can stand the slow service, the food is REALLY amazing! (I guess the service isn't TERRIBLE- the people are plenty nice, and they get your order right, they're just a little slow.) They also have a full vegetarian menu (though you might have to ask for it a few times!).
author: Jaimi B.

description: The food wasn't bad and we felt we got what we paid for. We were interested in going before we were solicited. The fliers for restaurants in Chinatown are annoying so it's always buyer beware.
author: Vic W.

description:
PLEASE DO NOT GO HERE!!! I am giving everyone a fair warning right now. This is coming from someone who is usually really lenient when it comes to customer service, but I am not cutting off any slack for this place, what so ever. 

We were drawn to the bustling amount of customers who were already seated and eating, who I'm assuming were also tricked by their flyer-waving employees who were constantly passing out flyers left and right. Not to mention, the flyer we received was a promotional coupon for an order of free pot stickers (we never received them). 

We waited for over 20 minutes to be waited on. We thought we'd be nice and patient, given it was a 2-storey building, they were busy, and they also seemed short-staffed. After the waitress took our orders, we waited another 30-35 minutes for our food to finally arrive. And I must say, that we paid for 40 dollars worth of food and had only received about 13-15 dollars worth of food (something I could have easily ordered from Panda Express). The portions were very small, and the food was ridiculously over-priced. I, had an easy time keeping quiet, while my bf on the other hand was cussing up a storm...so we had to hurry up, eat, and leave; which wasn't hard to do at all since our food portions were so small. All in all, it was a horrible experience. JUST KEEP ON WALKING WHEN YOU SEE CHINATOWN RESTAURANT.

We asked for more rice - waitress never returned - zero
They charged us four dollars for hot tea - zero
Portions and prices - zero

They dont deserve any stars
author: Mey S.

description:
Ok, maybe my idea of good Chinese food is different from everyone else's? I'm not sure why the ratings are so bad for this place.  I checked the reviews after I went here and was very surprised.  I'm really glad I didn't read them beforehand otherwise I might have avoided this place.
So anyway....my family and I were on vacation in SF and we were shopping til we dropped in Chinatown when the most obnoxious thing happened! These ladies on Washington Street were bombarding us with coupons for two different restaurants across the street from each other.  The Chinatown restaurant coupon gave us 20% off a free order of potstickers and free green tea ice cream!! I was hungry!  My kids were holding out for something better later on but all that shopping can make a girl hungry for dim sum! 
So we went here...  I actually decided to go here because it looked very retro-Chinese and kinda kitschy with a balcony and I cannot resist the kitsch or free potstickers for that matter...20% off!!  I also wanted dim sum!  
I thought the food super! I don't know what kind of crap they are serving us in New York but it's been going downhill in the past couple of years.  I was happy with everything I ate here and ate it twice, we came back 2 days later and ate the same thing, mom had something else and the second time the kids ate here to and were very pleased.  The food was delicious and all the meat in our dishes was very good.  Nothing was rubbery which I find occurs way too often in the Chinese food that I've been eating in New York.  The dumplings were out of this world! We had bbq pork buns and steamed pork dumplings (which were even better the second time!!) the free potstickers that someone else mentioned in another review as really horrible were really delicious chicken potstickers.  I'm really picky about my chicken and the texture of it and found the chicken in my chicken and vegetables to be very good and a very nice non-rubbery texture.  My mom was also very pleased with the food that she ate here... I can't remember what she had the first time but the second time she had Mongolian beef which was very spicy, but the beef was very nice and tender.  
I am definitely keeping this place in mind for my next visit and I'm hoping that I'll get a coupon! Maybe it's not the cheapest or friendliest Chinese joint in Chinatown but it was worth my whole family enjoying their meals!  Eat here instead of that absolutely horrible tourist trap the Empress of China! More on that later!
author: Betty T.

description: This was THE worst chinese food I have ever had.  Overpriced and greasy.  We accepted the coupon from the street girl only to find out that we could not use it on what we ordered.  The service was ok but the woman who was running things was rude.  Worst Chinese food in Chinatown...  Go to Sam Woh up the street... It is quirky, cheap, and yes you get rude service but that is what it is famous for... ask Conan O'Brian...:)
author: Chaise M.

description:
My best friend is the "adventurous" type, meaning that she wouldn't let me go on Yelp to research Chinese restaurants before we left the house. "Let's just play it by ear!" she said. "Let's explore and find something in Chinatown!" So we did. And we found Chinatown Restaurant.

Yeah, so...the food was mediocre, the waitress was pushy, and when we went downstairs to leave, there was a COCKROACH on the wall.

That's about all I have to say about that.
author: Lisa N.

description: This is by far the most terrible place people can go to for chinese food. For all the tourists and people skip this restaurant.
author: Jayden M.

description:
EAT HERE IF YOU WANT TO:

1) Get ripped off - all the food is "discounted from original price"
2) get naucous - after my meal I was burping somthing foul for hours
3) be mistreated - staff tries to rush you and then swindles you on your bill
4) have a miserable evening

Absolutely the worst restarant in SF, let me know if you have found a worse one.  I need to go see if they can top these 

SF Health department.  Do you job please!!  Shut this place down, its a health hazard, and a disgrace to san francisco dining.
author: Toxic W.

description:
Definitely took the bait with the ceaseless hollering of the lady at the front door yelling "Free pot stickers and ice cream".  After going up the stairs, I was shocked to see all the patrons there were all non-Chinese.  My hunch is that they were all tourists that were suckered in like myself with the great FREE word on the ads.

Anyway the food was great for the portions.  It's definitely the Americanized Chinese style food that we all have adapted to that we've ordered.  As for the flavor, it was so-so.  The Mongolian beef was very tangy and the Kung Pao chicken had it's extra kick as always.  The dim sum comes via the kitchen and not the carts, no biggie for us.

The part that surprised us the most was the amount of free items we were given.  It was beyond the items listed in the coupon.  We were given free iced Thai tea, three plates of pot stickers, green tea ice cream, and a large bowl of rice.  On top of that was the 20% discount!  Talk about customer service :P.  We were scared that they'd tack these freebies onto the receipt but they did not.  Maybe because we were Asian?  haha I don't know but it was great gesture :)
author: Brian B.

description: The people who run this place really work to sell it! After literally being accosted numerous times by ladies with coupons, we decided to give it a try. While the food itself was okay, the service was horrible. It had a decent ambiance and was conveniently located, but we won't be back.
author: Sheila R.

description: I came to this old style chinese restaurant for lunch once. Chinatown Restaurant feels like, I am in the very old chinese movie set because once you get inside the hostess will guide you to your table. Chinatown Restaurant from the inside is a very old restaurant.
author: William B.

description:
I wish we had seen all the yelp reviews before checking this place out..  But there are really not that many restaurants open in Chinatown at 10:30am Friday mornings, so we just picked the first one we saw :(  

I liked the fact that there was outdoor seating.  The restaurant is on the 2nd floor and even though the ledge was really narrow and seemed precarious, it was actually pretty solid.  AND there was somehow no bird poop on our ledge even though the awning on the next building over was completely covered in bird poop.  Impressive.  So enjoying the beautiful weather and people-watching was nice...  But when we saw the lady who greeted us in the restaurant walking out to the corner to hand out restaurant flyers to tourists while pointing them in the direction of the restaurant, that's when we knew we were in trouble :P

The food took FOREVER to come out even though we were the only ones in the restaurant.  The dumpling skins and the bread for the pork buns weren't very fresh.  The xiao long baos had kind of a clear gelatinous substance in them that was strange..  It tasted OK but the jelly-like stuff was just weird.  The spare ribs were nice and meaty but the black bean flavor somehow didn't quite get into the meat..  And my water glass had a strange sticky pinkish blob on the inside - a tiny blob, but still a blob :P

Fortunately the refreshing pistachio ice cream and the fresh crunchy fortune cookie at the end were delicious.  Think next time they'll let me just sit on the ledge with some free ice cream?.. :)
author: Marilyn L.

description:
Stopped in for dinner last evening. I had not read any reviews prior to this, but decided to eat here after wandering around a bit.

I was directed to the dining room upstairs. I found the waitstaff to be very attentive, not overbearing as some posts have mentioned. As I was traveling by myself, I did not opt for the Dim Sum (although there were a lot of interesting choices), but could not decide what I wanted. The waitress suggested a combo dinner - it's  usually for 2, but she said they could do a single-serving version for me.

The food came out hot and fairly quickly. Some of the appetizers were from the Dim Sum menu - shrimp shumai (nice chunks of shrimp) in a steamer basket, chicken pot stickers, the egg roll & fired prawn were crispy fried but not greasy. Got talked into Hot & Sour soup (not part of the combo, but a weakness of mine) which was very good & a large portion. Couldn't finish the entree (Mongolian beef & very spicy Kung Pao shrimp & chicken dish), so ended up taking that with me.

Love the green tea ice cream at the end - it made for a nice finish. With all that (and a beer), the cost was well within my company's per diem!

Lots of tourists there, but no one seemed t be disappointed with their meals.
author: Jim G.

description:
on our trip to chinatown, a couple friends and I were handed a coupon that read 20% off entrees, free green tea ice cream

walked in and the place felt really sketchy. looked at the menu and god, I was instantly disappointed; everything was way too expensive. tourist trap much? 

our waitress was rude. when we asked her if we could use the coupon on our order (we tried out the $11.95 per person "deal"), she kept writing on her notepad and sternly said "NO" 

our food came in really small portions. what an awkward dinner, no? and after asking our waitress for the tea about three or four times, the tea finally came half an hour into our lunch

overpriced chinese food is bad enough, but man, with all that bad service to top it off...f this restaurant
author: kathleen d.

description: I got misled into here thinking I was going to get an ordinary workday lunch, but instead was duped into spending way more than anyone deserves to for average food.  They don't mention that tea costs extra, nor do they actually deduct the 20% off your entre which they promote because it's there 91st anniversary.  91 years?  What kind of an anniversary is that?  I'm sure next year there will be a new scam to lure in more tourists and other walker-by's - 92nd anniversary!  woo-hoo!! yeaaa!!  Put on some party hats and drum ur chopsticks over your plates.  Some shrewd hustlers at this spot.  Disgusting scam artists.  Don't ever eat here!  VERY OVERPRICED!
author: AJ B.

description:
Very Good!  We were enjoying the festivities at the Moon Festival and a woman handing me a flyer and pointed to where the restaurant was located.  We walked in and given a very friendly welcome.
We had a coupon for free pot stickers and green tea ice cream.
We ordered the Dim Sum for two and the waitress suggested an order of small noodles for our lil one, and Jasmin tea.  The lil one had a sprite.
order came to $42.00.  We thought it was reasonable for what we ordered as far as Dim Sum.  We also thought the food was very tasty and very well flavored. We could taste ginger in one of the steamed goodies.  The Spring rolls were tasty and went well with their secret spicy sauce.  Pork Buns were fresh and very meaty and not dry.
The young one liked the Pot Stickers and ate the curry chicken on a stick that came with the Dim Sum. 
Every thing was tasty.  Green tea ice cream was creamy and a wonderful ending to a filling lunch. 
I couldn't wait to get home and Yelp about this place.
So GOOD!
author: Ari L.

description: Do not go or u want to try overpriced, terrible, horrible and nasty food. I suggest u to leave immediately if u havent placed an order yet. Or Run now if u dont want to eat shit
author: Pang C.

description: The last couple of times I've been there, the food was good and the service was good. I don't see what everyone is fussing about... It's a Chinese restaurant. I do agree that there are tourists but come on, you are in Chinatown. It's expected. Anyway, our waiters were friendly and helpful when helping us select our entrees. The walnut prawns here are to die for and the Kung pao chicken is just how I like it. It did get busy due to lunch time and we had to wave them down twice to get the check. I do agree that the price is a little overpriced that is why I subtracted a star. Overall, a good experience in Chinatown Restaurant.
author: Ashley B.

description: Hmm after reading the reviews I guess I got lucky. I wasn't acosted to enter but walked in of my own free will :). Went upstairs and ordered a range of dumplings to try and the duck with special fried rice. I got a huge range of dumplings to try and the duck and fried rice were devine. On reflection after eating at Scomas and Mortons the following two nights this was by far the best of the three for food. Service was adequate but not pushy. I was left to enjoy my meal without being pestered every 5 minutes to see if I was enjoying it. Would happily eat here next time, however with so much on offer would like to try somewhere else too.
author: Steve H.

description:
This used to be our favorite restaurant in Chinatown. But today at dinner we discovered two things that completely ruined this restaurant for us. The first is that they serve shark fin soup and dumplings. Considering shark fins are gathered by cutting fins off of live sharks in the wild and then tossing the sharks back in the ocean to die, I am not interested in supporting an establishment that supports that appalling practice. Secondly, we noticed a mysterious charge on the bill for $6.50. The notation next to it was just a scribble, and it was added at the end very discretely. We asked what that charge was, and we were told it was a 'service charge' (tip). We were a party of 2. I told her we didn't want to have that charge added, and she said that we didn't have to pay it. If we hadn't noticed that added fee, we likely would have paid it AND tipped on top of that. It was very shady and questionable. 

I am sad to say we will not be returning there again.
author: Amanda S.

description: biggest piece of $hit of a chinese restaurant i've ever experienced in my life.  makes me ashamed of being chinese with such a place like this passing as a chinese restaurant.  way way overpriced and terrible quality of food.  WARNING:  IF YOU ARE IN SF CHINATOWN DO NOT EAT HERE!!!
author: Andrew P.

description:
Very good (although not cheap) dim sum. Soft shell crab dim sum=California-ized in a good way. Did the ownership change? Didn't seem dirty when we were there. Watch the bill, gratuity is included.

UPDATE: Ordered off the standard menu and was underwhelmed. 1 demerit. Sticking to dim sum.
author: Brandon R.

description:
I was suckered into eating at this place.  Very hungry, craving chinese and not really caring where we went, I just wanted food.  Needless to say it sucked.  No need to elaborate, it just sucked.  I just wanted to forget about it, therefore I never wrote a review.  

And now today, I have come across their clean score..........once again I'm offended.  I think the time has come to make ALL restaurants display their score or grade in the window like they do in LA.  Maybe this will save someone from putting their lives in jeopardy.

The scored a 44.  20 days ago.  severe rats or mice.  

UNACCEPTABLE!
author: Jamie B.

description: Ok, first of all, this place doesn't even worth one star! Not only the food taste bad, the prices is outrageous! They acted all high class and serve you fruits and hand wipes (for additional fees) and they don't even have the courtesy to tell you that they're charging you extra! The lady who was passing out the flyers on the corner said the dim sum was good, so I thought, okay, I'll give it a try. Obviously, that lady lied! When the food came, the dishes were small and the food tasted bad. Three dishes of dim sum came to a total of twenty something dollars. This is the worst restaurant I've ever been to! I've only been to this restaurant once, it was my  first and last time going there!
author: Jane Z.

description: Such a horrible experience at this restaurant..it was so bad we walked out before even ordering! We got lured in like most with the coupon...then the rude hostess said it would be 15 minutes for an outside table about 40 minutes later we were taken to the table... and that wasnt even the bad part. As soon as we sat down the waitress came over and was so rude, I asked a simple question about the coupon and she completely yelled at me just for asking the question. This restaurant is such a tourist trap, in looking at the menu the prices were so ridiculous, I am so glad we just walked out and didnt spend the money on this miserable place.
author: Clarissa S.

description: Avoid. Bad service. Free Potstickers tastes old.
author: Mr J.

description:
The people who give out the leaflet about free stuffs from the restaurant is just a gimmick to trick tourists.. Don't judge a book by it's cover..

1) Please check your chopsticks before you start eating because when I pull my chopsticks out from the cover, it was moldy & when asked for a new pair, the waitress rudely threw the new pair on the table.
2) Bad service. Waitress took our order rashly & we haven't finish our main course, they served us desserts. The whole time, the service was as if they can't wait for us to get out of the restaurant. There weren't many customers so why the rush?
3) They did not tell us that they added TIPS to our bill without us knowing. So if we had not realized the extra charges, we would have given them extra tips.
4) Toilet facilities is really bad for such a nice outlook restaurant.

Don't go here!!!!!!!
author: Willie A.

description:
Overpriced, greasy food.  Some of it isn't outright offensive, but then again, some of it is.

The management are awful as well.  I had a run in with the owner last time I was there and she was a total b*tch.

Avoid!
author: Jeff W.

description: We sent our touring relatives out for the day in Union Square/Chinatown.  They decided to eat at this restaurant - they were taken advantage of.  Charged for tea - charged for rice - main courses came several minutes apart.  Charged for rice they never received.  There were only the two of them but were charged for the tip.  Would never suggest this place for tourists or locals.
author: Jim L.

description: Awful!!!!Rip off!!! Please don't bother to look at the menu. They charge for tea and add their own tip. Food was not good. Service...NO Service. Better off buying Chinese food at Pastry shop. A visit there is dangerous to your health.
author: Glory V.

description:
My only regret in writing this review is that I wished I wrote this a year earlier, to save some of you folks from wasting your hard-earned money, especially given the current economic climate.

Having grown up in NYC and of Cantonese decent, I can say with utmost confidence that I know good dim sum when I see it and taste it. Thus, you can only imagine how high my expectations were when I walked into Chinatown Restaurant. There were inauspicious signs everywhere, warning me to stay away from the place, but the rumbly in my tumbly had full control of my mind, body, and soul. Perhaps it was the name of the restaurant itself that should have warded me off from entering ("Chinatown Restaurant"?!?! Come on! Can you get any less creative than that? You're better off calling it "Ching Chong Restaurant". ) And then of course, there was that lady dressed in a qipao, handing out coupons (when the hell did Chinese people offer COUPONS?) for free pot stickers, a free scoop of green tea ice cream, and 20% off your total bill with a $20 purchase. That alone should have had me bee-line the hell out of there. But no, I walked in there like a happy-go-lucky kid on her first day of school, all wide-eyed and bushy tailed.

So we headed upstairs and well, the first thing I noticed was uh...the lack of Asians in presence, other than the wait staff. Folks, not to be racist or anything, but if you don't see any elderly people of Asian decent in a "dim sum" restaurant, GET THE HELL OUT OF THERE. Senior citizens of the Asian community pride themselves in being able to just "chillax" at their favorite dim sum place, while kicking back and reminiscing about the "good old days" over a nice steaming cup of oolong tea for hours and hours. There was none of that going on. All I saw were a bunch of yuppie tourists, drinking their tea with their pinkie finger extended.

Nonetheless, we decided to cut the restaurant some slack. We were in the heart of a giant tourist trap, after all. So we sit down, and the hostess hands us a menu. Yes, a MENU. And that's when I realized there were no goddamn carts in sight. For as long as I could remember, all dim sum places have loud-mouthed, but smiling, Asian ladies pushing carts (filled with steaming hot dim sum!!!) around. But alas, that never happened, and we had to resort to ordering from the menu. (I felt so dirty doing it...) We only ordered three dishes (hargao, shumai, and chicken feet) because we felt a little obligated to at least give the food the benefit of a doubt. Half an hour later and there was no food in sight. And, not only was I suffering from malnutrition, but dehydration as well, as I was out of oolong tea and no one came to replenish our empty teapot. We decided to call the hostess over and inquired about our lack of edible goodness. She snapped at us and said, "This is not a cart service restaurant. You can't expect food to come out that fast. We make everything fresh in our kitchen!" Well, my thoughts on that comment was, "I'm sorry, lady. But where I come from, if you give me that kind of attitude, I would open up a can of whoop-ass on you." But I held my tongue and decided to wait a while longer - patience is a virtue, after all.

Fifteen minutes later and the hargao (shrimp dumplings) came out. To say it was pathetic would be an understatement. I would have had a more enjoyable meal had I purchased it on the frozen food aisle at 99 Ranch Market...or even got it from Costco. The shrimp was not fresh - it looked and tasted like something you got from a pre-cooked frozen bag of shrimp from a private label company. Well, that was the last straw for us and we decided to ask for the check. The last two dishes were taking too long and I still didn't get my tea. The hostess tried to talk to us out of leaving, but it was too late. I politely declined and asked for the check. She leaves and comes back with the two other dishes, which was oh-so-conveniently prepared just as we was ready to leave. We asked her to take it back to the kitchen - we were done. She brings the shumai and chicken feet back to the kitchen, and brings us the check...and two scoops of green tea ice cream. We ignore the ice cream and looked at the check - $20, plus 20% gratuity. Four pieces of crappy shrimp with a stupid rice wrapping for $20? That's highway robbery. After 20 minutes of arguing with the hostess over the bill, I decided to just walk out, leaving them a $10. Chinatown Restaurant can suck my she-balls for all I care...there is no way in hell I will ever go back to that place ever again.

And by the way, that lady is still handing out those damn coupons...
author: Blenda L.

description: ZERO STARS What ever you do DON"T GO HERE the service sucks and the food is horrible. I love Chinese food but this place is pure evil. The Food tastes very vinegary and salty. The pot stickers are mushy and don't look cooked in some areas.( call the food inspector ).Don't get lured in by the nice lady handing out the coupons outside.There is an evil lady and her minions waiting to take your order inside. It has a nice view from the balcony I guess that's why the food is expensive.
author: Jenifer P.

description: Terrible place. Amazingly slow service. The worst Chinese food I have had in my life. It is sad but as a tourist, I will never take a special trip to San Francisco Chinatown again. The food is crap there.
author: Ken P.

description:
it was baad

but i give it 2 stars cause i was with my best buddy from virgina paul horse cow man and his pregnant wife!!!

congrats guys :)


also never go here ever
author: Cristopher K.

description:
Anything over a 1 for this tourist trap is not worth it.

Don't get suckered in by the lady handing out coupons at the door, across the street or a couple of blocks away. She'll escort you up to the 2nd floor to make sure you go. Because once you hike those stairs, you're unlikely to go back down, EVEN WHEN YOU SEE THERE ARE NO CHINESE PEOPLE EATING THERE.

TOURIST TRAP. My parents and I ate there because I was pregnant and it was not far from our parking spot. We should've walked further to one of the restaurants with chickens hanging in the window. My parents wanted noodle soup and the woman said "Won ton lo mein soup" even though there was only won ton soup on the menu. I warned my dad that she would probably say anything to get people up there.

Funny-we're Japanese and we were seated at the 3rd table in- to make it look like Asians like the place? The free potstickers were all right. Note- coupon isn't good for the rice, appetizers, soup or dim sum. 

The entrees are ridiculously priced. Even 20% off doesn't make them reasonable. 

We ordered a bowl of rice, an individual won ton soup -large bowl that could be shared among 3-($9!), eggplant and salt and pepper shrimp. The salt and pepper shrimp weren't the crispy kind you get at better Chinese restaurants- they looked like a batter version of General Tso's shrimp. Tasteless. 

Eggplant- bleh. Won tons- bleh. The green tea ice cream tasted like celery. I drank one sip too much of water and puked near the bathrooms (one on the 1st floor, or men's and women's in the basement- two floors down).

AVOID AVOID AVOID
author: KD D.

description: I too was suckered in by the lady outside offering free pot stickers with any order. These pot stickers were the kind you can buy in  Asian markets for about $4 for a 2 pound bag so you can imagine how they tasted - Ugh.  The entrees came and after one bite, I knew I would never come back.  If you like very bland and nearly tasteless Chinese food then this is the place for you!
author: GORDON M.

description:
aside from the decent service, everything else was ridiculous. most especially portions and the expensive cost.  

wish we could have yelped and avoided. But the choice was not ours.
author: Daniella B.

description: the hagow potsticker is tast so very bad.......bad....do not go here !!!!! on washington street.  foood not tasty, watch out for a 2 chinese ladies trying to pass out a menu flies. they will over charge you on your bill very bad chinatown restaurant waitress not even care about refill your drink. very bad restaurant is not a very dim sum restaurant, do not go eat here...........! i had been to many chinese dimsum restaurants this is the worst chinese restaurant i ever meet?  the food tast very terrible, taste very bad......and  smell bad.
author: jay s.

description: oh my FREAKIN god..... this is the place to go to when on vacation in San Francisco.  Had the lunch/dinner for two.... they must have gave us everything on the darn menu, but we didn't complain.  Everything was cooked to perfection, I don't know if this was a good thing or not for most but the FOOD was coming out the kitchen to fast.... we couldn't even fit everything on the table.  Stairs Stairs and on yeah more Stairs, it seems asif your working up stairs forever to get to your sitting area, but once your there.... be ready for the time of your life.
author: Q A.

description:
I created this yelp account solely for the purpose of rating this restaurant. So, obviously, this restaurant is either heaven on earth or something way on the opposite end of the spectrum.

BEWARE-- ILLEGAL BIZ PRACTICES--THEY HIDE A TIP IN THE BASE TOTAL depending on which group you are in: (and then they ask for more tips! wtf?)

THEY ALSO DO NOT VALIDATE PARKING LIKE THEY SAY THEY WILL

Hidden tips:

Foreign European tourists--25%
Any Other: 17.5%

So after a poor/lackluster meal (we'll talk about that later),
my father gets the bill. We look over it and see that there is a 25% tip. This is really wierd. The dishes aren't even ours. So, we tell the waiter there's been a mistake. She grabs the bill and gives it to the table on the right of us. We look over and see that they are french tourists (I heard them speaking french)

The waiter then gives us the correct bill, with a 17.5% tip (scrawled as misc). My dad figures like most restaurants they'll charge us a base then we put tip on the table or add it ourselves. But, we see that they charged us a 17.5 % tip and they give us *another* reciept to ask for more tips!

Isn't it illegal to forcefully add the tip and charge the patrons that amount? My dad politely told the waitress that as a part of principle they can't legally overcharge his credit card for the amount w/ their tip *without his signature,* he will tip his own amout and write it on the reciept and the first words out of the waiter's mouth is "we cannot validate your parking anymore!" "we cannot do anything"

wtf? There was *nothing* about a gratuity charge (more about that later) or tip in any of the menu papers. How shady.

Get this: the table on our left were some Euro-tourists,from Britain,  and earlier I heard them say something about a 25% tip "must be a gratuity charge David" Haha, yea right, a grautity charge for two people? come on people. 

Basically, they charge you different amounts depending on whether you are foreign or not, bc they figure you might not understand american customs so they can get away with a 25% tip for extremely shoddy service (plates took 40 min to come, had to ask for water, tea, servers borderline rude), charged us $3 for water?

The food is definitely 2 stars, akin to Panda express but 3x more expensive. for a $28 dish simple spicy fried chicken dish we got 7 quarter sized medallions of chicken. What a ripoff.

This place feed off of lots of advertising, good looking interior, and good location (next to the presidio parking sturcture and claims of validating parking). Also, the pictures on the wall they are so proud of that supposedly tell the story of the owner's family's journey from china to america is probably just an enlargement of something they got off a history book. 

My sister was upset at the waiter for talking so rude to my father , so she took the teapot from our table and poured it onto the plates. We were in the corner so nobody really cared to watch. That same waiter must have taken a hell of a time to carry those plates back!
My father was scolding my sister on the way out of the restaurant until he realized that the waiter had REALLY overcharged us for a 22% unauthorized tips. Those bastards.
author: Jessica H.

description:
We got sucked in by the coupon.
The free pot stickers made my mom sick, she ate 2 out of 4.
The waitress was EXTREMELY rude.
She brought me a beer without a glass .. and 2 thai ice tea's without straws ... stir the tea with the umbrella?
We asked for water, twice - which never came.
She asked us 3 times if we were ready to order ... within about 2 minutes.
We weren't giving off any kind of sign that we were ready.
After we ordered, the waitress started walking away - then my little sister said "They don't have very much vegetarian shit"
The waitress snapped her head back in our direction & said "What did you say?!" ... Like she was going to start a fight with my 14 year old sister. 
The food was ok. The thai tea blew.
After the food was on the table the waitress didn't come by once to see "how everything was" A bus boy came by to bring us our check, we then asked him for some water - and he brought it to us.
Our waitress returned to snatch the bill, then asked "how is everything?"
Oh ... thanks for asking .. everything was fine ... we're leaving now .. and we aren't coming back.
I didn't say that .. but, she knows that we won't .. not after that.
author: bettie p.

description:
MiL has been craving chinese food from a place called Golden Dragon from back in the day. Tis close to her birthday so we all trooped over the Bay Bridge to go to this Golden Dragon spot... unbeknownst to MiL, GD was closed and renamed Imperial Palace... something about a shootout between rival Chinatown gangs- something straight out of a 90's Bruce Willis/ Mel Gibson movie... so we go to IP- walk in and are acosted by the maitre d' who promptlyu shooed us out saying it was closed for a private party. MiL was upset... but hey we're in the middle of Frisco Chinatown so there's a myriad of places to eat. We walk down Washington- MiL was eyeing  Grant Palace or somethiong like that when we were  acosted by a young lady in red passing out coupons... she then "escorted" us to the Chinatown Restaraunt- even stopping traffic in the middle of Washington so we could jay walk to the restaraunt. Ok whatever, lets do this.

We sit a t a round table and while looking at the menu, are told we shoul\d REALLY go with the special menu priced at $15.95 but "on special" for $11.95 per person. We had 4 adults three kids. Yeah... best to go this route.The young man taking drink orders was a punk-- slamming menus around tossing straws here and there and just being plain rude. Service was OK after that. Food was about what I could get from your typical donut and Chinese food place you find in any 'hood. Nothing special. Kung Pao chicken had no taste (maybe becuase their were kids, they didn't spice it up). For seven people, the rice wasn't nearly enough. Overall, you get a lot of food (besides the rice). However, there are no highlights here. This place is geared to  non discriminiating tourists. Skip this place unless you really have no other choice just happen to be here and are hungry.There are better options throughout SF and over to Oakland.
author: Anthony M.

description:
glanced at the menu:
$25 steamed fish with soy sauce.
$35 peking duck.
$10 penny size wonton soup.
$25 garlic shrimp.
$5 order of pork dimsum dumpling.

wow.

ok i confess, i got suckered in by their free dumpling coupon, sh*t me, we were hungry!

three waitresses came by and tried to rush us to order something, even upselling their ridiculously expensive (3 times the norm), yet mediocre tasting food. 

but we just ordered $20 worth of food.  haha lady looked pissed!

mushu pork was ok, very greasy, but too many chunky ends of cabbage thrown in, a great way to rip off diners.
shrimp and pork wonton soup was bad:  ten penny sized pieces of meat stuffed in palm-sized wrappers... like those jellyfish on national geographic: small head, long tentacles. 
soup sucked: basically salt and four strips of bokchoy in hot water. not broth, hot water.

so after paying with credit card and signing the slip, she rushes over to point out "tip not included yet."
REEEEELAX LADY! I was gonna tip with cash! 

the ONLY star of this review goes to: one of our waitresses, the young teen. nice, laid back, no pressure.
author: Ethan L.

description: I'm getting grossed out just remembering my experience there. YUK.
author: Angelica B.

description: I dropped in to have a quick lunch because the menu looked OK.  It was a big mistake!  A server came over immediately after I sat down and try to push the alchohol menu.  When I ordered an ice tea, she went away and never came back to take my order.  I had to catch some one else's attention to order.  The fried dumplings came out literally 30 seconds after I ordered and was only lukewarm.  The Dan Dan noodles were OK but the portion was small for the price of $9.50.  The chicken feet dim sum was just OK.  When I got the bill, the ice tea was $4!  And their suggested tip of 15% included the tax, instead of 15% of just the food (a pet peeve of mine).  When I gave $40 for the $24.45 bill, I just got $25 back without the 55 cent change!  This was definitely a tourist trap (for they were pushing the dim sum sampling menu on others around me for $14.95 per person).  The prices were expensive and food was not very good.  I recommend going somewhere else!
author: Joe C.

description:
So bummed we didn't use yelp before we sat down....

We went there because we were given a "coupon" to go inside...we should have known right then.  We went inside, and from the beginning didn't have great customer service.  The waiter took our "drink" order in a hurry, forgot one of the drinks we ordered, then we had to flag him down because he walked away so fast we couldn't place our order.  when we got our food, we were pretty disappointed.  Very bland, not much flavor.  And again, poor waiter service the whole time.  He didn't even ask how everything was nor if everything was good or not.  At this point, we already had thought we should have yelped the place prior to, but our fault for not doing so.  We received the bill, then had to flag someone down because the bill didn't seem correct....it wasn't.  They tried to ADD ONTO THE BILL a "suggested tip" but it is written in chinese so if we had not have asked, we would not have known and just paid it.  Needless to say, we did not tip nor will we ever go back.  Horrible service and not the greatest food.
author: K. N.

description: I'm surprised by all the poor reviews! But then again, I was lured in off the street and expecting nothing. My friend and I ordered a bottle of Sake and a lot of dim sum, and it was totally delicious. We were even given two servings of dessert (not that we needed any of it, let alone two). I have nothing bad to say about this place besides the fact that the ambience is not stellar, though the balcony did look nice! I have no complaints, and it was a good meal before hoofing it over to Beach Blanket Babylon!
author: Corinna L.

description: Gave this disgusting place one star cuz you have to give star to complete review. I'm so MAD at myself for not reading yelp reviews before trying this place...what a shithole! The prices are more expensive than a five are restaurant...oh wait they must be charging extra for hair in the food. I am so MAD being a resident of SanFrancisco and getting suck in to this place cuz they had outdoor seating.   If I end in hospital with food poisoning come visit me!!!!!!!
author: Toni K.

description:
I wish I'd read these reviews before we went out - my boyfriend & I found ourself in Chinatown in the late afternoon this past Saturday - got sucked in by the flyer - at first everything seemed pretty nice (someone brought heated, scented towels for us to wipe our hands with) but things went from surreal (a nice little plate of fresh apple slices with, erm, a tiny American flag stuck in the top; terrible music that sounded like piped-in karaoke) to bad (a plate of rice shoved in front of me before I had finished my soup; our dim sum didn't arrive before the entree so we canceled it, but then a dim sum item we didn't order arrived with a muttered "this free"; later, after we were finished, the dim sum we tried to cancel showed up ) to horrendous, when we were presented with a bill that looked like someone with Turret's syndrome had written it (the only recognizable thing was a "x 5" - there were 2 of us there - no idea what "x5" was supposed to mean) followed by an impossibly large number almost twice what we believed we owed. Fearing for our lives (the dining room is on the upper level and we were worried we wouldn't get out unscathed), I successfully argued the amount down with an incredibly insulting woman who had come out and surreptitiously removed our coupon halfway through the meal, and responded to my growing outrage with complete disrespect.  (She actually tried to convince me that dim sum comes *after* a meal... ) Even if there had been a misunderstanding (we thought, because we had inquired, that the rice, soup and tea came with the entree - I guess our server didn't speak English well?) even if we added what they said those things cost to the bill it *still * didn't come to the ridiculous total. We ended up unintentionally spending much more than we wanted to - and we didn't even get the discount.

I have reported this restaurant to the Better Business Bureau.  I suspect they are losing business due to their poor service, mediocre food and inflated prices, and I bet they'll lose a lot more due to their execrable business practices.  They give Chinatown a *very* bad name.
author: Marianne S.

description: NOTE: I've lived on the border of Chinatown since 1976, I have never been to MOST Chinese restaurants on Grant Ave and Washington St (below Grant) simply because it's geared towards the tourist/weekend visitors than are unfamilar with the area. This restaurant is similar to Paris Massage/The Green Door of the Massage World. In both cases, if you want a happy ending, follow where the Chinese folks go! LOL
author: Peter L.

description: I'm one of those fools who ended up getting suckered in by the coupon.  To be fair we were in a rush, and weren't expecting much.  The service really is as bad as everyone is saying.  It took 30 minutes for us to get water, and we only got one glass for 3 people.  The good thing was the food wasn't bad...but it wasn't really that good either.  My iPhone battery died a few minutes before we made the decision to eat here....
author: Iftikhar K.

description: This place is good for the location and atmosphere. Other than that, it was terrible. Service was horrible. Food was nasty and way to overpriced. Just ick!
author: Danielle B.

description: We were about due for lunch after a lengthy walk from Union Square and the financial district when we came upon this restaurant.  It looked interesting from the outside and was nicely decorated on the inside so we decided to give it a shot.  Very wise decision on our part.  We were seated very promptly and our drink orders we taken. After several minutes of reviewing the very extensive menu we decided on the fixed-price dinner special that included appetizers, several entrees, fried rice and dessert.  Dinner was promptly served, the food was excellent and the service was very good.  Considering this is San Francisco,one of the most expensive places in the country,the cost of the meal ($60) including drinks and taxes but sans tip for our party of 3 was a real bargain especially when you consider the quality and quantity of the food we were served.  I would highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Jerry M.

description: Don't be swayed by the flashy name, this place kind of sucks.   Eating here is like attempting to dry hump Rue McClanahan in a rented sedan while smoking with the windows up...not as fun as it sounds.  Hey! I just realized why it's named after "Chinatown!" You'd rather slice your nose with a switchblade than come back!
author: J P.

description:
This is the worst dining experience ever.  It is almost impossible to find a restaurant in Chinatown that serves bad food, but it happens at the Chinatown restaurant.  I was not so excited about going to this place, but my BF was really excited about dining on the porch.  I don't know if it is legal to sit on the porch though...  Anyway, it took us almost 2 hours to finish a 4-dish dinner.  The dishes were served in 30-minute interval.  Go figure... 


When we were having our 2nd dish, we over heard the patrons who sat next to us asking for their last dish.  Apparently their last dish never arrived, but they were given the bill for a dish that they never had.  Then the same thing happen to us.  I was waiting for the honey BBQ ribs.  Sure enough, before we got our dish, we got our bill.  When the BBQ ribs finally arrived, they didn't look very good. The meat was very chewy...  I was not happy with the service and food...  We paid our bill and were ready to leave the restaurant.  We ran into a patron who was complaining to the waitress that he still had not got the sake that he ordered an hour ago.  My BF and I looked at each other and then decided to chat with this gentleman.  We never learned the name of this gentleman.  Anyway, we shared our story at the restaurant with this guy and he invited us back to his table to drink with his friends who were sitting on the other side of the porch facing Washington St.  Then we started talking to another 2 patrons who sat right next to the gentleman and his friends.  It turned out that it took FOREVER for them to get their dishes as well.  They were still waiting for the Mongolian Beef when we talked to them.  A patron at another table said that the waitress got their order wrong...  What's up with the restaurant that keeps on messing up people's orders???


Despite the dining disaster, it turned out to be a weird kind of fun experience that my BF and I would always remember and talk about.  After all, it doesn't happen very often when you are not the only one who are screwed at the restaurant.
author: Michelle H.

description: Luckily we stuck with the dim sum, but it all was tasteless and rubbery. My kids went bat-shit crazy in there and now after reading everyone's reviews, I don't feel guilty about it at all.
author: Aimee M.

description:
I was taking my relatives around Chinatown and we were craving Dim Sum. After we were aggressively urged by Chinatown Restaurant staff passing out flyers, we decided to give it a try. As we walked up to the main floor of the restaurant, we were greeted however, it took awhile to seat (4) of us, when the restaurant was 1/4 full. The dim sum was made to order, not passed around at the time. Once we got our shrimp dumplings, it didnt seem fresh-it actually just tasted like heated up leftovers from the previous day. The pork-buns also just didn't seem fresh, the bun wasn't as fluffy as I thought it should have been.
