I also noticed while I was eating, the other customers who were waiting to be seated were left waiting for awhile even though the restaurant had plenty of room-I think this restaurant needs to work on their initial greeting and hosting service. For as much as this restaurant sends out staff in the streets of Chinatown to attract people to come in, they should be ready with hostesses to greet and seat customers.

By the way, the coupons that we received claimed to take 25% off the lunch-however after we  were presented with a full price bill for lunch (that was worth at least 5 full entrees about $55), they turned it down because we only ordered dum sum and soup.
author: Dessa R.

description: So lately i have been on a steamed pork bun kick. I love going to the little hole in the wall places you can get 3 for a buck sometimes... I love it! I decided to try Chinatown Restaurant... what a mistake. first of all it took 20 minutes for 3 little pork buns. Yes they were hotter than most i receive, but they were less than half the size of what I am use to and 3x's the price i normally pay. Call me cheap but I was not happy. I can't comment on the rest of the food, but if its anything like the pork buns, I will stick to my tiny gems...
author: Miguel V.

description: The food here was good (especially compared to our midwestern hometown's Chinese places), and we got suckered by the coupon for free potstickers, ice cream, and 20% off our entrees.  What SUCKED was, they charged us for rice, which I thought was a given when ordering Chinese food.  Am I wrong about that?  We took home plenty of leftovers for later, so that was good.  But we did pay too much, and the food came out at all different times.  Also, I had no idea who our server was.  One lady took our drink order, and while we waited for her to come back, two different ladies came and asked us for our drink order.  When we said we needed time to order, the same three people took turns coming back to our table about every 30 seconds.  Weird.
author: Amber W.

description: Dont even bother.  We dont get to chinatown that often, and made the mistake of attempting to have lunch here.  my son wanted chicken fingers.waitress said they had them.. you know what they brought?  Sweet and sour chicken with the sauce on the side.  I said that we did not order this, and the waitress argued with us.  We paid for our drinks and left.  There was no attempt to correct the situation at all by the staff.  They were rude.  We did have some potstickers that were ok, but do some research so you dont get sucked into this one.  Its about as bad as it gets
author: Jim C.

description: if i can leave a 0 star, i will definitely do!! Rude services, over price for everything!! I'll never come back!
author: Yana Z.

description: Rude and pushy ladies are working the corners near this place passing out fliers. As if that's not enough, the place they are so pushy about has food that tastes like... cardboard dipped in grease. AVOID!!! There are a ton of restaurants nearby that taste a lot better. Ask a local teen nearby and they can probably point you in the right direction.
author: Wade L.

description: I liked this place. I am quite experienced in eating Chinese food, from the very, very authentic (which I don't like much), to the more Westernized California Chinese food. It is true, this place mostly caters to the tourist crowd. However, we had the Kung Pao Chicken, which was excellent, and the walnut prawns, which was good. The free potstickers were OK, but they were free in the first place so that makes them automatically "good." The green tea ice cream at the end was fair, but again, it was free. This place is spacious and not overcrowded. The wait staff was working hard and tried their best. I chose this place after waiting in line at the way over-rated R&G over on Kearny. This place is as equally as good as R&G. I liked this place more than R&G because they appreciate your business versus R&G. Plus, they validate your parking at the garage across the street.
author: Dan A.

description: Worst restaurant in Chinatown and obvious tourist trap. Do not get suckered in by the ladies outside offering coupons. I'm not going to waste too much time on a review, so the short of it is: bad food, high prices for food ($16 for a plain broccoli dish !?!?) and tea and rice, bad service. For the love of all that is good in the world, do not go here.
author: Frey V.

description: Friendly service, great postickers and thai style prawns.  The meat in the sweet and sour pork has too much batter on it, but it tastes great.  The servers almost always forget at least one item that you ordered, I guess they don't check your order, so be sure to remind them about what else you have on the way.  They do have outdoor balcony seating with a view of the park and the Washington & Grant crossing, just veto the idea if there are pidgeons about.  The food really is great, but can be pricey, so be careful with what you order.
author: Jonathan B.

description: For chinese food, this is a great place.  Make sure to get one of the flyers or card (to your left when you walk in) or from their workers handing them out on the street corners for 20% off.  The dining is family style and the food is all pretty good.
author: Jared F.

description: Stopped going there after the bill kept coming back higher than expected. You can only say " I didn't order that" so many times.
author: Jenisel J.

description: I was leaving the business district and was tired and hungry.  This was the first place I came upon, and I figured how bad could it be.  The food was not even up to take out standard.  The service was passable but it is expensive for for the quality.  They obviously cater to the tourist trade and work on volume.  Avoid this place.
author: Robert H.

description: I would never come here again. Mainly because of service. My party entered the restaurant and there were several parties already eating. It took us 3 times to ask to get water on to our table. One waiter was unresponsive and seemed like he did not even know English at all. Ironically, the lady, possibly the owner, was only catering to the specific tables... Why? The customers are Caucasian. Me and the others are Asian and we got less attention. Same for the other Asian couple across from us that came in later. Otherwise food... it was decent. Some of the dishes were a bit bland. I certainly have tasted much better Chinese food else where.
author: Ada L.

description: Wow, I can't believe I actually finished the food, because it was HORRIBLE. My bf and I totally caught the tourist trap, only because we were starving, and the lady gave us a coupon, so decided on trying the place out. Even though my mind was screaming, 'NOOO!!," we went along with it. Upon climbing up the stairs to the restaurant, the initial panic settled in, all the patrons were Caucasian! Bad sign if asians don't venture to this restaurant, the food will be either mediocre or bad. Next, looked over the menu, and wow, they were pretty expensive! Finally decided on the prix set dinner, which was $16 bucks per person, and some chrysanthemum tea, and that pot cost $5.50! Anyway, we received our order of pot stickers (nasty, frozen ones that are greasy and gross), and then our main entree. It was a tower full of nasty dim sum, and some fried crap that we didn't like at all. The only good thing out of this meal was the green tea ice cream. Never will I venture again to this place. Overpriced and disgusting! Try a more ethnic chinese restaurant in Chinatown, that's half the price of this place.  Don't bother with this tourist trap.
author: Sharon K.

description: Anytime there are multiple chinese ladies on the street corners handing out coupons for a restaurant, pretty sure it's a bad sign.  Went to this place because hong kong clay pot was packed, and the wait was long.  After 30 minutes of the waitress ignoring my girlfriend and me and serving others who clearly came in after us, we left. Worst service imaginable.  Will never come back to this shit show.
author: Roger L.

description: I went to this restaurant recently and my gosh, the worst restaurant I've ever been to. My party and I ordered a few items, and not only is the quality horrible, the size of the dim sum was too small. Dim sum was horrible, very disappointing. $45 for less than 10 items, automatic gratuity. Pretty dirty restaurant as well, flies are everywhere.
author: Ella C.

description:
Tourist trap, poor service, inflated food prices, and falsely advertisements of  discounts and validation of parking.  Be sure to read their fine print if you can even find it.  Avoid.

Almost didn't feel like tipping, the experience was that bad.
author: Bruce K.

description:
I just wished I read yelp before stepping into this so called "restaurant". Like most of the reviewers, my friend and I got tricked by the coupons that 2 ladies were handing out on the street! Way overpriced, service too long and rude, cold food and barely average.
On top of it, they had 18% gratuity on our $50 bill (for 2 people) maybe because they know that you are not likely to come back! My worst experience in SF in 3 days! it's a shame for Chinatown to have a place like that! We notice 2 others tables asking questions about the check. One couple even spilled the soy sauce and spicy sauce on the way out! Avoid at all cost!
author: Chris B.

description: Did not like the food at all.  It was also a bit overpriced for a lunch for three people.  Next time I will find a street vendor or buffet.
author: Lauren S.

description: Saturday, while shopping, we decided to get yummy bubble tea smoothies from chinatown, and j said hey let's eat dinner here in chinatown, we havent in a long time! He was right, we had not in a long time, so I said ok, and it was all pretty for new years so might as well. While wandering around, deciding where to go, it got colder and colder, esp with our drinks, so we decided to go to one called chinatown restaurant. It said it was historic. Should have checked yelp, now that I see the HORRIBLE reviews. We were seated right away, and although we were in chinatown, there were no chinese people eating there. That is probably a bad sign, since that never happens. They had a dim sum special, which was $16 per person, and we each added soup, because we were freezing to death, so that upped the price. The dim sum that came was not that good. It wasn't horrible or anything, just not special. Very bland. There wasn't a ton of it either. The dinner ended with green tea ice cream, which was good, in styrofoam bowls (ew). I was almost too freezing to eat it, since it was still cold in the restaurant. Service was good, and the waitress was able to answer our question of whether there were nuts in the meal, which has been an issue in the past in eating at chinese restaurants (since we both have nut allergies and have had allergic reactions before, due to the language barrier). The bill ended up coming to $40ish for two people, which wouldn't be a lot in a normal place, but for cheap tasting bland not great chinese food, it was. I do not recommend anyone going there.
author: Merredith L.

description: My friend and I were touring Chinatown in May and the chinese restaurant that I had found on Yelp and intended us to go to for lunch... was unexpectedly closed. So we walked a bit more and were looking for somewhere else to eat, when we encountered the flyer ladies. I thought the coupons sounded like a nice deal. You got a free order of potstickers, green tea icecream, and a discount off of your entree, I believe. So I figured that this must be serendipity and decided to go along with it. It's not the best chinese food I've tasted. My sweet and sour chicken tasted a little more like orange chicken than sweet and sour, but it was still yummy. And my friend's chow mein tasted good too. The prices were neither cheap nor overly expensive, and they had a decent selection of entrees and dim sum. I ordered the bbq pork buns (okay) and the shrimp dumplings (pretty yummy), and my friend ordered some curry chicken skewers, which weren't at all spicy, but tasted good. Portions were big enough to fill us up, but not so big that we had to box them up, which was just fine with me because we still had more sightseeing to do. The wait staff was not lacking anything that I noticed, and everything went perfectly fine as far as I was concerned. I don't know if I'd go there again, but I was perfectly satisfied with my meal, and happy that we ended up in a decent restaurant.
author: Jennifer M.

description: This is probably THE worst restaurant in history.  Why?  I'll tell you why, they had sent out the ladies out passing flyers for free potstickers, and 20% off entrees.  Wrong!  We ordered some beef ribs for appetizers.  Guess what, the entrees came first before the appetizer.  We ordered one dish and one appetizer, in addtion with the free potstickers. Well, the manager said, you need to ordered two entree, because the entree is small.  I said, I am a really small eater.  I just have two bites and I'm done. So I ended getting beef and tender greens, and my honey ordered sweet and sour pork.  So, okay...they charged hella expensive, for very small portions.  I mean, really small.  The first entree arrived, the sweet and sour pork.. My entree hasnt even arrived until 10 minutes later.  I was like, where is the rice that we ordered.  I always have rice with my entree, so I asked the waitress that we had ordered rice, well....apparrently, they forgot to bring the rice, at least five minutes later, after I called them out on it.  Another thing that bother me was the fact that after the two entrees have came out, we were starting to think our appetizer wasnt going to come,  Finally, it came after we finished our entree.  I was like WTF.  Okay, they gave us the check.  Okay, their big promotion was 20% on all entrees.  WRONG!  She must think I am some dumb stupid tourist.  I read the bill from top to bottom.  When I saw that 20% wasnt deducted, I called the manager, and she fixed it.  When I gave my card to another lady, she charged the same price without the discount.  I was like, this is a sham.  These people must think we are pretty stupid to not noticed what they are doing.  I noticed that 90% of the customers are tourist, and sometimes when you travel, you dont noticed these little things.  But, for god sake, that's not how you run a business.  Again, I went to the manager, and she didnt want to redo the whole bill.  She felt it was a hassle to print up a new receipt. She said, well..you dont have to pay the tip.  A five dollar tip, for lousy service.  My boyfriend was like "I aint paying five dollar for tip".  It was really stupid all the way around.  They never came to check to see if we like our food, and the sneaky way about getting customers in, and not giving them the discount sounds so conviving to me.  My advice....DONT GO THERE!!!
author: Jenny W.

description: after $150 of crappy imitation chinese food for three people, this place is over priced and bad.  beware, like other yelpers posted, don't eat in a chinese restaurant with no chinese patrons especially in chinatown.
author: Pickle R.

description: don't waste your time here. service was pushy and prices were too high. they talk all good english to you when they need you to order and pay, but don't understand shit when you request for things or change. i felt totally hustled dude.
author: Saechao M.

description: We were in Chnatown for just a couple of hours, and decided to have lunch there. We were suckered in by the "special" coupons they were handing out on the street (should have known better). We sat out on the tiny balcony, which was fine for us because it was great for people watching. The only problem was the fact that we mostly watched the waitstaff ignore us. Good thing there were great views to take it. Overall, the service was abysmal, and the food was no better than what I get at the local Chinese buffet in Wisconsin.
author: Stormy J.

description: stay away! possibly worst meal and service ever. the only reason they exist is because tourists get sucked in. i thought it looked cute because of the balcony seating, but nothing is worth the meal i had to endure.
author: Jenna E.

description: This is why you shouldn't eat at restaurants that pass out flyers. They are obviously desperate for business and that is probably for good reason. Advertised as Dim Sum yet not a cart in sight. Also not an Asian patron in sight - another bad sign. Right after being sat I had to go potty. So I go down two flights of stairs. By the time I come back up, my friend decided we didn't want to eat here. We get up to leave and get accosted. Accused actually of only pretending to want to eat here to use the bathroom which most certainly wasn't the case. My friend explained we were leaving because it wasn't as advertised on the street but the hostess/waitress/whatever she was wouldn't let it go. She actually demanded a $2 fee for using the bathroom. I tried to explain that if I only wanted to use the bathroom I would have chosen somewhere much more convenient but she wasn't having it. I finally just threw $2 on the table so we could leave.
author: Sara B.

description: Food is not good.  Service is not good.  Relatively expensive. Please, there are better ways to spend your time and money.
author: Al V.

description: This place is ridiculous. PERIOD. I got lured in because of their promotion for free potstickers, green tea ice cream & 20% off. When I first went up the stairs I was like "ok it looks nice" but when I looked at the menu, I was like WTF?! First of all, they are wayyyy to over-priced for what they serve. I'd rather spend $15 on a plate at cheesecake factory (the portions here are wayyy to small for what the prices are). They took a long time to give us our food and my mom was ready to leave the place without telling them. All together me and my mom ordered Black Pepper Beef, Hot&Sour Soup, a Tofu platter & 4 dishes of rice and the total was $48?! ARE YOU KIDDING ME??!?!?!! I COULD GET BETTER FOR HALF THE PRICE SOMEWHERE ON MISSION ST. I mean seriously though! That place is just ridiculous! All I saw were a lot of tourists there. I can understand the comments about tourist traps because that's exactly what it looked like to me & I'm a SAN FRANCISCAN! UGH! Oh and we also ordered their VEGETABLE EGG ROLLS.. do NOT get those! THEY TASTE/SMELL LIKE LICORICE! What kind of freaking egg rolls taste like licorice though? I mean I gave them 2 stars because their platters were not bad tasting but everything else was not worth it. HIGHLY NOT RECCOMMENDED!
author: Sarah E.

description: Overall I would say that this restaurant is "not bad," but I've certainly had better.  I, like so many others, was lured in by the persistent coupon lady on the corner.  She even walked me and my group of friends to the restaurant door!  When we got upstairs to the dining room, I saw a room full of 100% white people.  Naturally, in the middle of China town, this worried me.  My boyfriend, who is Chinese, told me that the food was great, in his opinion.  (Of course, he also loves Panda Express...)  I ordered sesame tofu.  My entree cost $11.95 and was the only item that the infamous 20% coupon applied to, for some odd reason that our server could not explain to us.  Anyway, the tofu was tasty, but it was literally just a huge plate of steamed sesame tofu - about 30 pieces of tofu!  I was hoping for some rice or veggies, but I guess that's asking too much.  :oP  I couldn't eat the free potstickers, which were filled with chicken.  The green tea ice cream was good, I'm told, but I had to pass on that too.  Service was alright.  Overall, not a bad place to hit in a pinch, but you'd be better off eating at one of the many better quality restaurants in the same neighborhood.
author: Heather D.

description: what an original name for a restaurant in Chinatown. We couldnt decide where to go because there were so many chinese restaurants here, they all look the same. We got inside, walked upstairs and there were a good amount of people, we waited for about 5-10 mins to be seated since all the tables were taken so they finally seated us in the VIP room (how special) The menu is a typical chinese restaurant menu with typical chinese food, they also gave us a special menu for dinner which includes appetizers, a couple of entree and dessert for $11.95 per person which was a pretty awesome deal! we all ordered the special. We had fried rice, chicken and vegetables and kung pao chicken and sweet and sour chicken (i just realized we had a lot of chicken) the appetizers were shrimp wrapped in bacon (really yummie), eggrolls and satee chicken (chicken again) it was more than enough to feed 4 hungry people. The food was actually pretty good and service was good also. For dessert we all had greentea ice cream with a fortune cookie on top. My greentea ice cream tasted like grass, maybe it was. =)
author: Leyna V.

description: This place overcharges ridiculously... it gets the tourists.. i'm a local around here... what got me mad was.... and not only me... MY GRANDMA even had to talk some smack to them... THEY CHARGED US FOR TEA???, This place over charges rediculously for food that is NEVER CHARGED THAT HIGH ANYWHERE ELSE in Chinatown... the one thing that got my grandma mad was they CHARGED US FOR TEA??, my grandma has been in SF for over 50 years, and Never was she charged for TEA during the EVENING HOURS... also, not only that, they brought us a bowl of rice which cost $5, which we didn't even order...we thought it was for free.. any other restaurant.. during evneing hours, gives free rice...anyway.. my bill was $133 something.. i had the resturant coupon which took $50 off... making it about $83.. my whole family agrees, for $83, they can have a MUCH MORE Satisfying Meal, with Better service, and No UP the sleeve scam with that tea charge, and bringing out the rice without asking us... Overall, I'll avoid this place.. mainly for the OVER PRICED meals...
author: Mr. AzzHole A.

description: This place is a rip off.... Do NOT eat here!!! Their fried rice had no flavor, and the over charged us for items that we did not order. I also didn't like the fact that they were really pushy in trying to get us to order more items. The pot stickers were bleh, the frozen pot stickers that you buy at costco have more flavor! My husband must have felt bad for the little chinese lady standing at the street corner handing out flyers. Like one of the other posters said if you don't see a lot of chinese clientel eating in a chinese restaurnt in the middle of Chinatown then leave and find a place that is full of asians then you'll know its a good place to dine! And one final thing we sure as hell didn't get our 20% discount that was stated on the flyer! If I could I would give this place a -5 stars.
author: Rachel B.

description: my family and I ate at this restaurant on 5/30/11 and it was the worst experience!  first, they gave us coupons for free potstickers and green tea ice cream.  so we checked it out.  there are no elevators, just long flights of stairs until you reach the mid level floor with dingy carpetting, dated decor and dirty tables, linens, silverware and plates.  even the walls looked like they haven't been painted in decades.  once you're in, it's hard to get anyone of the many waiter's attention.  the prices aren't reasonable either.  once we ordered, we waited and waited.  one dish at a time was served and not all at once.  so we had the entree w/out the rice.  then at the end of the meal, we still have not been served our free pot stickers.  when we asked, the waiter said we had to take turns.  but the table next to us was served theirs and they were just seated minutes ago while we waited at least 30 minutes.  we asked for water at least 4 times.  when i served myself tea, the tea pot handles were dirty.  even the soy sauce containers on the lazy susan were dirty.  when we got served our dessert it was in a styrofoan cup and it was vanilla, not green tea w/ a fortune cookie.  it wasn't even a full scoop.  when i asked about the green tea, i was told they ran out.  when we received the bill, we were charged $3 for which was tea.  most restaurants do not charge for tea.  it would have been nice for them to inform us that tea was not complimentary.  they also charged us $10 for service charge.  we were only a party of four so I don't understand why they charged us a mandatory 15% when their menu stated that 18% would be charged for party of 5 or more.  i was told that chinatown charges automatically at 15% service charge.  this was news to me.  especially when the service they provided did not deserve it.  I will not be eating at this establishment ever again. Do not fall for the free potsticker or the ice cream dessert.  they are a total rip off.    once they get you their restaurant, they will take advantage of you.  I'm not a tourist and have lived in SF area all my life, so I feel sorry for the tourist who don't know any better.  The food wasn't all that great either and on the salty side.
author: melanie N.

description: what's interesting in this restaurant is its being around for such a long time (i can always learn so much from them, as to their secrets of longevity).  good, helpful, attentive service is notable althroughout our dining experience (which was rather early the time we were there).  i noticed real tough competition from among other restaurants, eating places here in this side of the city.  we had their own version of fried rice (which is a complete meal by itself), a steamed fish dish, plus pork-chops done their style....very good and filling.  just be aware that this whole experience comes within a bit pricey range.
author: Jerome Espinosa B.

description: This is the THIRD time my extended Lee Family have reserved this place for our annual Chinese New Year dinner. We are almost all Chinese American San Francisco-born. Each time, the owner, Anna and the food have been excellent. Anna attends to our every need and request. She makes suggestion for our 9 to 10 course menu. The cost averaged $200/10 person per table, a typical Chinese-style banquet. Our 1st and 2nd year, we had 10 banquet size tables. This year, we had 7 tables. The ladies attending us were great. The food was tasty and large portioned. We used the amplifier provided  and we mingled after the dinner for a fun evening. For next year, I was chosen as the host so I've already told the family, I'll will pick The Chinatown Restaurant for 2012!  I feel the one star ratings are from Caucasians who don't know what to order, or who are expecting a "PF Chang" experience. I'm sorry for he customers who received rude service. No one deserves that! I can only tell you my/our experience(s).  Maybe asking for Anna might have helped.
author: Gerry P.

description: After walking around Chinatown and finding ourselves famished for lunch, we were drawn in by the 20% off flyer and free potstickers. The restaurant seemed fairly clean, and the woman who seated us was nice enough. We had a selection of 3 dim sum dishes, 1 entree, 2 small bowls of rice, a sprite and lemonade and a pot of tea, and the complimentary green tea ice cream. Overall the food was ok - some dishes better than others. The service was slow - we had to wave the waitress down each time we needed something - right down to the bill. We weren't sure if we ordered enough food to feed 2 adults and 2 children, and were surprised when the waitress wouldn't let us keep the menu in case we wanted to order more food (something about not wanting us to get water on it, even when we said we would put it on the floor). When the bill came, we realized why. Over $40 and all in Chinese so we couldn't decipher it. We could figure out that the food was $32, and our drinks totaled $9. The 20% off was MAYBE applied - when you read the fine print you will see it is only on select entrees, so who knows if we qualified? I think she kept the menu so we couldn't recheck the prices - at around $5 per dim sum dish, it just didn't add up! We chalked it up to getting sucked into a tourist trap, but will know not to do that again! Another reason to always check Yelp before eating somewhere!!
author: Krystie B.

description:
I consider this restaurant as the worst restaurant I had eaten  in San Francisco Chinatown so far (I had tried about 10 Chinese restaurants in SF Chinatown.)

1) Not be lured by several ladies on street begging you to try this restaurant. Good restaurants do not need such ladies standing on the street.
2) Those coupons distributed by those ladies are misleading. You can NOT get any discounts or any free potsticks if you only eat dim sum. Read the coupon carefully before I like to enter the restaurant! 
3)  Food sucks. Potsticks are not fresh at all. Many dim sum are made from low-quality stuff such as ribs.
4)  If you eat dim sum, there are very few choices. And you have to order first and then they make it for you. For good dim sum restaurants, I think they should always have cart going around, on which there are all kinds of dim sum food ready to pick.
5)  When they give you the bill, they already include 15% tip of after-tax cost, which you may not notice. Then when you are given the  bill, they consider after tax+15% tip as base fee and you may be tricked to pay more tips. 
6)  High price of each dim sum food. If you compare with dim sum restaurant close by, I find the price of this restaurant is higher than other restaurants. 
7)  Once you enter the restaurant, you should notice that almost all customers are non-Chinese. Then you should think about it, why Chinese people do not eat here?
author: Tim C.

description: Avoid this place like the plague - it's a rip off.  The food is mediocre at best and they treat customers like crap.  Our waitress completely screwed up our order and tried to insist that we pay for items we didn't order.   Tourist trap with crummy dim sum and there were FOUR errors on my bill - a charge for dim sum we didn't order, a $2 overcharge for a Tsing Tao beer (they said it was for tea!!), a 15% service charge that is not disclosed - we were a party of two) and a refusal to apply my friend's 20% discount coupon for an order of Szechuan Green Beans  - they said it wasn't an entree!!// know my friend is reporting these crooks to the BBB and may be filing a small claims case because the owners acted like such crooks.
author: Charles Y.

description: The food here was great, but, the service was horrible.  We too were accosted by the flyer waving employee at the corner, waving a 20% off coupon.  We were tired and hungry and she was pushy (she actually took ahold of my arm at one point and started walking to the restaurant).  The food smelled good and the half the tables were filled, so we gave it a try.  We had a party of 7 and it took approximately 15 mintues for them to take our order.  Two of us ordered Dim Sum (we specifically noted that we were eating it for dinner), three ordered entrees (to take "advantage of the coupon" and the last ordered spring rolls.  The spring rolls arrived about 15 minutes after we ordered, the Dim Sum 5 minutes later, the first entree 15 minutes later and the last 2, twenty minutes after that.  the first three people were done eating before the last two got their food.  We asked numerous times during the "serving process" where the other items were and why the vast majority of dinners who came in after us already had their food.  Wereceived a variety of answers, which included...we thought everyone was sharing the Dim Sum (did I mention we told them it was our dinner), we're really busy and its the best we can do, and their meals take longer.  That's strange all 3 entrees were chicken, why did 2 take longer than the others.  After all the poor service and rotten excuses, we were all charged an 18% gratuity, which they would NOT delete from any of the tickets.  Then they didn't even bring any change.  Granted, it was less than a dollar for each ticket, but, it was the last straw.  I had the Dim Sum, which was very good, but, I will NEVER return to this restaurant, due to the service.   By the way, you may get a 20% discount on your entree, but you will pay $1.50 for the rice and get it 20 minutes before your meal.  Stay away!!!
author: Tammy H.

description: Avoid this place by all means if you don't have the desire and guts to explain greedy, unfriendly and disrespectful people that hospitality business is not their call. Go for it in case you are tired of "suspiciously" friendly waiters, who bring out your food in a regular boring order: drinks, app-zers, soup, salad, entre, dessert. The place is an experience. Unlucky enough to come across the lady with flyers, we found ourselves in a "living room" of the Chinatown restaurant. There were huge tables with piles of dirty dishes that remained untouched up until when we left, frustrated guests waiting for their food. There were 2 huge and very observable garbage bins next to the kitchen and very close to the dining room. Their restroom, two floors down, would be a scary site for a susceptible person. When we sat at one of the dirty tables, a woman started putting huge sheets of paper to cover the mess. Then there came a waitress that was very pushy when taking our order and took our 20% off flyers. First, we got our lukewarm pot stickers with a burnt chili flakes souse. Then we received our sesame chicken made of chicken tenders, breading, an ultra-sweet souse and a pound of raw sesame seeds. Then there came rice, about 10 minutes later, mixed with peas of acid-green color and the remains of an omelet (I wondered if they served breakfasts as well). A few minutes later I received my seafood plate, which was quite good, but for the fact that it lacked 2 out of the 4 seafood ingredients. The food was brought to us by one of the cooks and the only time we saw the waitress was when she took our order. We were impatient to pay and go, but the check made us stay for quite a while. The prices were very high generally, but such mediocre food and horrible experience on their own should have been a bonus. The check contained hieroglyphs and numbers and we figured we had to pay for both rice and the tea as well which turned out to be rather expensive. The gratuity was included in the bill. My boyfriend and I have worked as servers for quite a while and have been in quite a few restaurants, so we know from our experience that gratuity is sometimes included for big parties OR some UPSCALE restaurants include "suggested gratuity" into the checks. Needless to say, we also had to ask for the discount (it was not taken off as with other 2 tables that paid at the same time) after the waitress has picked up at least 4 coupons from our table (I made sure to grab them twice). We subtracted the "imposed" gratuity from the check for the above mentioned reasons, left cash and left to NEVER come back again. We've been to several Asian restaurants in the Bay Area and were generally pleased with the experience, but THIS PLACE is a real shame of SF Chinatown.
author: Mysh K.
